ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
    All terms used in this chapter shall be defined as in R.S. 26:2 and 26:241 inclusive and as amended, unless the intent is specific herein. 
    Tax administrator shall mean the Rapides Parish tax administrator in the Rapides Parish Sales and Use Tax Department. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 1, 2-26-2008) 
Sec. 4-1.1. - Alcoholic beverage and drug abuse control commission. 
(a)  The Alcoholic Beverage and Drug Abuse Control Commission is established for the city as a municipal authority to advise the mayor on certain matters in this chapter and shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the council, and shall serve at the mayor's pleasure. 
(b)  The commission shall consist of five (5) members who are residents of the city and who are not directly employed by or have an interest in any establishment which has an alcoholic beverage permit issued by the city. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 1, 2-26-2008) 
Sec. 4-1.2. - Powers and duties. 
    The commission shall have powers provided in this chapter or as set out herein in relation to: 
(1)  Advising the mayor on complaints regarding permit applications for new business; classes A, B, and R as set out in section 4-14. 
(2)  Advising the mayor on the issuance of orders setting fines or for the suspension or revocation of permits issued to persons engaged in the business of dealing in beverages of high or low alcoholic content, who are doing business in the city. All hearings shall be conducted by the commission in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and appeals from rulings shall be made directly to the Ninth (9th) Judicial District Court. 
(3)  Advising the mayor and city council on matters related to drug abuse and matters regulated by this chapter when requested to do so. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 1, 2-26-2008) 
Sec. 4-2. - Scope of chapter and exceptions-Governs selling, handling, distributing, etc. 
    The business of selling, handling, distributing or otherwise disposing of alcoholic beverages in the city shall be regulated as provided in this chapter. 
(1)  Any person, firm, corporation or association of persons who, as a business or as a means of employment, manufactures, blends, rectifies, distills, processes, imports, stores, uses, handles, holds, sells, offers for sale, solicits orders for the sale of, distributes, delivers, serves or transports any beer, porter, ale, fruit juices, wine or spirituous beverages of an alcoholic content not exceeding that now or hereafter permitted by law, but greater than one-half of one percent (0.005) of alcohol by volume, or, any malt, vinous, spirituous, alcoholic or intoxicating liquors containing more than six (6) percent of alcohol by volume, within the limits of the parish, shall be deemed a retail dealer, or wholesale dealer, as the case may be, for all purposes of this chapter. 
(2)  Any person, firm, corporation, or association of persons, who conducts an establishment as a business where any of the alcoholic beverages as defined herein are stored, used, consumed, handled, sold, given away or otherwise disposed of, shall be considered as conducting such establishment as a retail dealer for all purposes of this chapter, and shall pay the same permit fee as that required of a retail dealer selling for use or consumption on or off the permitted premises. 
(3)  This chapter shall not apply to the sale or disposition of the following: 
a.  Patent, antiseptic and toilet preparations. 
b.  Flavoring extracts, syrups and food products. 
c.  Scientific, chemical, mechanical and industrial products. 
d.  Alcohol for industrial use or purposes only and which is so denatured as to be unfit for human consumption. 
e.  Liquor sold on the prescription of a licensed physician and for medicinal purposes only. 
f.  Wines and other alcoholic beverages used bona fide for religious or sacramental purposes by any ordained priest or minister as a part of any religious duties and as authorized by the rules and regulations of his church. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 1, 2-26-2008) 
Sec. 4-3. - Hours of operation; penalties. 
    The hours of operation of all Class A, B or R license holders shall be from 6:00 a.m. daily until 3:00 a.m. the following day, Monday through Sunday. It shall be a criminal offense and as well a violation of this article for any holder of such detailed dealers license permit issued under this article, for a servant, agent or employee of same to dispense, in any manner, beverages described in section 4-1 of this chapter between the hours of 3:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
    Whoever violates the provisions of this section shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor imprisoned for more than sixty (60) days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 1, 2-26-2008) 
Sec. 4-4. - Permit required generally; payment of permit fee prerequisite; posting. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation which is required to be licensed under the provisions of R.S. 47:354, to sell or offer for sale or have in possession for sale, or to handle or distribute, or to give or engage in the dispensing of, or otherwise dispose of or permit the consumption on the premises of, any alcoholic beverages in this city without first obtaining from the tax administrator a permit to engage in such business and paying the required permit fee for engaging in such business. Each person obtaining a permit under this chapter shall post the same in a conspicuous place in the establishment where the business is conducted and shall keep same so posted during the life of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 1, 2-26-2008) 
Sec. 4-5. - Permit required for each location; application for change of location; sale or services beyond scope of permit. 
(a)  Separate permits shall be required for each place where alcoholic beverages are sold, either at wholesale or retail. 
(b)  The sale either by wholesale or retail, where authorized, of such beverages shall be conducted only in the place of business specified and designated in the application for the permit, and no change of location of such business shall be allowed, except after written application on a form provided by the tax administrator . 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to serve alcoholic beverages outside of the place or premises for which a permit is granted, provided that nothing in this section shall prevent the delivery of such beverages in unbroken packages or containers. 
(d)  Exceptions: 
(1)  This section shall not apply to applicants holding a Class A caterer's permit. 
(2)  This section shall not apply to any permit the mayor may by written permit authorize under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 1, 2-26-2008) 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSES, PERMITS, PERMIT HOLDERS 

Sec. 4-6. - Annual permits. 
    Before engaging in the business of dealing or doing any act as a dealer in alcoholic beverages within the corporate limits of the city, all wholesale and retail dealers shall obtain from the tax administrator, annually, for the period from January first, a permit to conduct each separate wholesale or retail business and shall pay for each permit according to the following schedule: 
(1)  Dealers in beverages of low alcoholic content: 
a.  Wholesalers: One hundred dollars ($100.00). 
b.  Retailers, Class "A", which authorizes the retailer to sell for consumption on or off the premises: Seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
c.  Retailers, Class "B", which authorizes the retailer to sell in sealed containers prepared for transportation and consumption off the premises: Sixty dollars ($60.00) 
d.  Class "R" (Restaurant): Seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(2)  Dealers in beverages of high alcoholic content: 
a.  Wholesalers: Five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
b.  Retailers, Class "A", which authorizes the retailer to sell for consumption on or off the premises: Five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
c.  Retailers, Class "B", which authorizes the retailer to sell in sealed containers prepared for transportation and consumption off the premises: Five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
d.  Class "R" (Restaurant): Five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(3)  Dealers with Class R (Restaurant) permits. Each applicant for a Class R (Restaurant) permit shall meet the following criteria: 
a.  Must meet the requirement of holding a City of Alexandria Class A (high or low) Alcoholic Beverage Permit. 
b.  Must operate a place of business whose purpose is primarily to prepare for consumption and to serve meals and meal times to the general public. 
c.  Must serve food on all days of operation. 
d.  Must file a copy of the applicant's menu together with the application, both new and renewal. 
e.  Must furnish an affidavit from the local health department showing compliance with all applicable health and sanitary requirements with new application. 
f.  Must gross sixty (60) percent of their monthly revenue from the sale of food, food items and non-alcoholic beverages. 
g.  Must maintain separate sales figures for alcoholic beverages. 
h.  All applications for Class R permits, whether new or renewal, shall be in writing, sworn to in front of a notary public, and shall contain the full name of the applicant along with a complete description and correct address of the premises in which the restaurant is located. 
i.  The Class R permit shall be subject to revocation by the city at any time following a hearing as provided for all other licenses and/or permits issued under this chapter and a determination that the permittee fails to meet the criteria set forth in this chapter. 
j.  For new businesses without prior business experience on which to base a determination of alcoholic beverage sales to total sales, a temporary permit may be issued by the tax administrator for sixty (60) days after which time evidence of all sales, as may be deemed necessary by the tax administrator, will be required to make their permit permanent. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-08) 
Sec. 4-7. - Special event permit. 
(a)  Permit fees. There may be issued by the tax administrator a three-day special event permit to individuals or organizations for a permit fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for beverages of high and low alcoholic content or fifty dollars ($50.00) for beverages of low alcoholic content. 
(b)  Time limitation. Permit shall be issued for three (3) consecutive days only; provided, however, that the holder shall observe all the requirements of section 4-3 regarding hours of operation. 
(c)  Frequency. No more than four (4) such permits shall be issued to any one (1) person or legal entity within a single calendar year. 
(d)  Location. The holder shall observe all of the requirements of this article except the requirements of section 4-22 regarding location. 
(e)  Applications. Applications for the permit shall be filed in writing on a form prescribed by the Rapides Parish Tax Administrator. 
(f)  [Issuance of alcoholic beverage permit for special events.] The mayor, by written permit, may authorize the sale of alcoholic beverages, by dealers, individuals or organizations upon public property in connection with a festival, event, or the rental of any public building or property owned or controlled by the city. The mayor may stipulate conditions for the issuance of such permit. Employees or servers of the individual or organization at special events are exempt from the employee or servers requirements of this chapter. 
(g)  [City sponsorship of event.] Whenever the city is the sponsor or co-sponsor of an event described in subsection (f) above, the required permit may be issued by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-08) 
Sec. 4-8. - Caterers. 
(a)  The tax administrator may issue a Class A caterer's permit to persons who meet the qualifications and criteria in either paragraph (1) or (2) below: 
(1)  Holders of any Class A or B liquor or beer retail permit will be allowed to sell and serve alcoholic beverages, on a temporary basis, limited to three (3) days in duration, at events other than on the premises for which the holder's regular permit is issued. 
a.  This holder of a Class A caterer's permit must use the permit in conjunction with their Class A or B liquor and/or beer permit and shall expire at the same time as the regular Class A or B permit. 
b.  Any fees listed within this chapter shall be in addition to the fees required to secure a caterer's permit. 
(2)  Persons who do not otherwise qualify for a Class A or B permit, but who operate a facility with a fully equipped kitchen where food is prepared for the purpose of catering functions, will be allowed to obtain a Class A caterer's permit under the following conditions: 
a.  This holder of a Class A caterer's permit must derive seventy (70) percent of their gross annual revenue from the sale of food or food-related product, and forty (40) percent of the gross revenue per event must be derived from the sale of food or food-related product. 
b.  This holder of a Class A caterer's permit must maintain separate sales figures for alcoholic beverages. 
c.  This holder of a Class A caterer's permit must furnish proof that he/she holds a valid retail dealer's permit as defined in R.S. 47:354 with their domiciliary jurisdiction. 
(3)  All fees as required in this section including but not limited to the caterers permit fees, caterers employee permit fees, and associated penalties and interest shall be equally distributed to jurisdictions that allow the use of a caterers permit within Rapides Parish and whose fees are collected by the Rapides Parish Sales and Use Tax Department. 
(4)  Applicants for Class A caterer's permit that are domiciled in an area in which the sale of alcoholic beverages has not been authorized by local option election must also hold a Class A or B liquor and beer permit. Fees collected shall be equally distributed to jurisdictions that allow the use of a caterers permit within Rapides Parish and whose fees are collected by the Rapides Parish Sales and Use Tax Department. 
a.  Applicants shall meet all requirements of this chapter with the exception of section 4-22 and shall not be required to meet the requirements in 4-14(a) and 4-14(b). 
b.  An applicant for a Class A caterer's permit that is domiciled in an area where the sale of alcoholic beverages has not been authorized by local election shall be required to advertise in the official journal of the Rapides Parish Police Jury that he/she is applying for a Class A or Class B liquor and beer permit. This shall satisfy the requirement to advertise a specific location when applying for a Class A or Class B liquor and beer permit. 
(5)  If the regular Class A or B permit ceases to be valid for cause, the caterer's permit also ceases to be valid. 
(b)  Application and permit: 
(1)  An application for a Class A caterer's permit shall be made on forms prescribed by the Rapides Parish Sales and Use Tax Department. 
(2)  The cost of the Class A caterer's permit is two hundred dollars ($200.00) per year or any portion thereof; costs shall not be prorated and are non-refundable. 
(3)  A Class A caterer must display the permit on the premises of the event being catered. 
(4)  A Class A caterer must only cater events in an area in which the sale of alcoholic beverages has been authorized by local option election and can only serve alcoholic beverages that do not exceed the alcohol content allowed by such elections. 
(5)  All alcoholic beverages at a catered event must be dispensed by the holder of the Class A caterer's permit or his employee, agent, or servant. Employees must be permitted as stated in section 4-9. 
(6)  Class A caterers must comply with the provisions of the Responsible Vendor Program or R.S. 26:931, et seq. 
(7)  A Class A caterer must provide the office of alcohol and tobacco control and the Rapides Parish Sales and Use Tax Department with written notice of the date, time, and place of each catered event at least one (1) week prior to the date of the event and shall adhere to all other provisions of state and local law. 
(8)  A Class A caterer's permit may not allow a caterer the ability to cater an event in a wet area outside of Rapides Parish or in certain jurisdictions within Rapides Parish if such is not allowed by the respective other jurisdiction 
(c)  The mayor, by written permit, may authorize the sale of alcoholic beverages, by caterers upon public property in connection with a festival, event, or the rental of any public building or property owned or controlled by the city. The mayor may stipulate conditions for the issuance of such permit. 
(d)  Whenever the city is the sponsor or co-sponsor of an event described in subsection (c) above, the required permit may be issued by the mayor. 
(e)  The holder of a Class A caterer's permit who is found to be in violation of this section may be subject to revocation of his/her alcoholic beverage permits. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-08) 
Sec. 4-9. - Employees in general. 
    Classified employee shall also mean any person employed or used in a Class A or R licensed retail business who, as a function of their duties, dispenses, sells or serves any alcoholic beverages as described in section 4-1 of this chapter. Persons required to hold permits under this section shall be referred to as classified employees and that classification, as used in this section, shall include, but not be restricted to mean bartenders, barmaids, waiters, waitresses, exotic dancers, bouncers, disc jockeys, cocktail waiters and cocktail waitresses, except that this subsection shall not apply to persons holding a dealer's permit, or to a person holding a waiter/waitress alcoholic beverage permit as described in this chapter. 
    Retail clerk means any person employed or used in a Class B licensed retail business who, as a function of their duties, dispenses, sells or serves any alcoholic beverages as described in section 4-1 of this chapter. Persons required to hold permits under this section shall be referred to as retail clerks and that classification, as used in this section, shall include, but not be restricted to mean sales clerks, retail clerks, and check-out counter clerks. 
    Waiter/waitress means any person employed or used in a Class A, R, or Class A caterer licensed retail business whose primary function is to take orders for and serve food and food items and who also takes orders for and serves alcoholic beverages in conjunction with the serving of those meals. Persons required to hold permits, under this classification shall be referred to as waiter/waitress. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-08) 
Sec. 4-10. - Employee permits; types, fees, penalty for violation, exception. 
(a)  Classified employee permits allow persons who meet the requirements as set forth in section 4-9 to be employed after payment of a fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) for issuance of an annual permit. 
(b)  Waiters/waitresses permits persons who meet the requirements as set forth in section 4-9 to be employed after payment of an annual fee of twenty dollars ($20.00). 
(c)  Retail clerks permits persons who meet the requirements as set forth in section 4-9 to be employed after payment of an annual fee of twenty dollars ($20.00). 
(d)  All classified employees, waiters/waitresses and retail clerks as defined in section 4-9 above shall renew their city permits by January 1 of each year and shall be deemed delinquent if not renewed by March 1 of each year and the applicant shall be assessed a penalty of twenty-five (25) percent. If not renewed by March 1 of each year the procedure and requirements for a new employee may be imposed. 
(e)  Employees shall have in their possession the permits required hereinabove during working hours. Whosoever violates this section shall be subject to a fine not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) or more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(f)  All classified employees, waiter/waitresses and retail clerks as defined in section 4-9 shall meet the requirements of section 4-23 except the requirements of section 4-23(2) and (3). Employees who participate in the state responsible vendor program shall also be exempt from the age requirements of section 4-23(1). 
(g)  All permit fees listed above are non-refundable and shall not be pro-rated. 
(h)  All classified employees, waiters/waitresses and retail clerks as defined in section 4-9 shall furnish a copy of their permit to each employer. The employer shall maintain a current copy of each permit from each employee and may be subject to audit and review by the appropriate law enforcement agency or the Rapides Parish Tax Administrator. 
(i)  The penalty for violating subsection (h) above shall be a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or revocation of the employer's current alcoholic beverage permit. 
(j)  All licenses and permits shall be displayed on the premises and it shall be the responsibility of the owner and/or manager to have available for inspection, all permits of employees upon commencement and for the duration of their employment. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-2008) 
Secs. 4-11-4-13. - Reserved. 
Sec. 4-14. - Permit application and renewal. 
(a)  New business; classes A, B, and R. As a prerequisite to the filing of an application for permits for new business hereunder, the applicant must file a statement of intent for a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) to apply for a permit. This statement of intent shall be submitted to the tax administrator, disclosing the proposed location of the establishment. At such time, an appointment will be made for the applicant to meet a parish representative at the proposed site whereupon the representative will determine if the site meets location requirements as covered in this chapter. 
(b)  Application of application. Upon approval of the site, the applicant will be furnished with a sign to be placed upon the proposed location in a place designated by the parish representative. The sign shall be placed in a standing position posted near the street or road on which the building is addressed at the property line. Such sign will remain in the designated location at all times for a period of thirty (30) consecutive days. If no complaint or opposition is made, the tax administrator shall issue an application in accordance with this chapter. If, however, complaint or opposition is made within the 30-day period, the tax administrator shall refuse to issue the application and shall order the complainant(s) and the applicant to appear before the alcohol beverage control commission to show cause why the application should not be approved. The burden of proof shall be on the complainant(s) to prove justifiable grounds for denying the issuance of the application. The alcohol beverage control commission may consider as grounds for such denial, any grounds set forth in R.S. Title 26, this chapter, or any other grounds which might adversely affect the public health, safety or morals. If the alcohol beverage and drug abuse control commission dismisses the complaint(s), it shall order the issuance of the application, and the applicant may proceed in accordance with the provisions of this section. In the event the alcohol beverage and drug abuse control commission sustains the complaint(s), it shall advise the mayor to refuse to order issuance of the applications and the mayor may take such action as he deems warranted under the circumstances. The applicant or any aggrieved party shall have the right to take a devolutive appeal to the Ninth Judicial District Court within ten (10) days of receiving written notice of the decision of the mayor. The decision of the mayor shall be final unless appealed within the time and manner set forth above. 
(c)  Compliance with state law. Application for permit shall be made in accordance with the provisions of R.S. 26:284 as may be amended. Denial of application for permit shall be made as provided in R.S. 26:288. 
(d)  Proration of permit fee. When the business is begun on or after July 1 of any year, the tentative permit fee shall be one-half (1/2) of the applicable minimum annual rate as set forth in this ordinance. However, a caterer's permit shall not be prorated. 
(e)  Renewal based on general purpose and intent. The application for renewal of a permit issued under this chapter will be approved or denied based upon the general purpose and intent of the requirements for an original application. Renewal of a permit shall be construed as an extension of those qualification requirements that permitted issuance of the current year's permit plus any amendments thereto. 
(f)  Denial. The application for renewal of a permit may be denied on the same grounds and in the same manner as an original application. However, any condition, act or reason which would have been grounds for suspension or revocation of the permit for the previous year shall be grounds for denial of the application for renewal. 
(g)  Deadline for application. All applications for renewal of a permit for the ensuing year shall be filed with the office of the tax administrator on or before December 31 of the present year, together with a remittance therefor. 
(h)  Penalty for failure to apply for renewal. Should any retail or wholesale dealer fail to file an application for renewal together with the necessary fee(s) as required in section 4-6 above, a penalty shall be imposed of twenty-five (25) percent of the amount due. 
(i)  Denial of application for renewal. If the application and fee(s) for renewal of a retail or wholesale permit is not filed before January 31 of the current year, the application for renewal may be denied and the procedure and requirements for a new business application imposed. If the renewal application is granted, however, it shall be subject to the penalties assessed hereinabove. 
(j)  Authority to waive penalties. Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (g) above, the Rapides Parish Tax Administrator shall have the authority to waive the penalties provided under the following circumstances: 
(1)  Where the tax administrator determines that the reason the application and fee for renewal required under this section is not due to the fault of the applicant; or 
(2)  Where the original license and/or permit is issued after November 15. 
(k)  Deadline for applications. No application for renewal of a permit shall be accepted after July 1 and any application filed after that date shall be required to qualify as a new business. 
(l)  Waiver of fingerprinting. The requirement to fingerprint permittees is hereby waived when such persons apply for a renewal permit, provided there has been no change in ownership. 
(m)  Applications to meet chapter requirements. All applications for renewal shall meet the requirements of this chapter. 
(n)  [Temporary alcoholic beverage permit.] Any person, firm, corporation or association of persons acquiring an existing retail or wholesale business licensed to sell alcoholic beverages under the provisions of this chapter, as an owner or lessee may be permitted by the tax administrator to operate on a temporary basis until the tax administrator approves or denies the application, as set forth above. In the case of a retail business, such an applicant shall be required to post a sign, at the applicant's cost, in a place on the premises designated by the parish as is required of applicants for new places of business. The provisions of this paragraph shall apply to businesses which have been licensed during the current year. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-2008; Ord. No. 266-2009, § II, 9-8-2009) 
Sec. 4-15. - Applicability to fraternal, social organizations. 
    All of the provisions of this chapter shall be applicable to clubs, fraternal or social organizations which are hereby defined as being those organizations or associations of persons, whether incorporated or unincorporated, organized for fraternal or social purposes. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-2008) 
Sec. 4-16. - Application for permit; separate places of business. 
    Before any permit is issued as provided hereunder, a true and correct application, under oath, must be filed by the applicant, or their duly authorized representative, containing the following information: 
(1)  The name and the residence of the applicant or their duly authorized representative and the duration of their residence in Louisiana. 
(2)  Particular place for which the permit is desired, with as complete a description thereof as will identify the premises. 
(3)  The name of the owner of the premises upon which the business is to be carried on. 
(4)  A statement that the applicant is a citizen of the United States, no less than twenty-one (21) years of age and has never been convicted of a felony or the violation of any liquor laws of the State of Louisiana. 
(5)  A statement that payment is attached to the application covering the permit fee. 
(6)  A statement that the applicant, as an individual, intends to carry on the business authorized by the permit for himself and as an agent of any other persons; that the applicant intends to superintend in person the management of the business permitted; and that if permit is granted, he will superintend in person the management of the business; provided however, that in case the applicant is a corporation, firm or association, the name of the person who is to be in charge of each place of business shall be designated and he shall have all of the qualifications of an individual applicant; and provided further that a separate permit shall be taken out for each place of business. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-2008) 
Sec. 4-17. - Personal nature of permits; death of partner; bankruptcy; noting change of location. 
(a)  Permits issued under this chapter are not assignable or heritable and are good only from the time of issuance to the expiration date of each year in which issued, unless suspended or revoked sooner. 
(b)  In the event of the dissolution of a partnership by death, the surviving partner or partners may operate under the partnership permit. Receivers and trustees in bankruptcy may operate under the permit of the person succeeded. 
(c)  Where the location of a place of business is proposed to be changed, the change proposal shall be received and must be approved by the tax administrator before such action is taken. It shall be noted on the permit by the tax administrator and the permit shall be invalid unless the notation is made. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-2008) 
Sec. 4-18. - Penalties. 
    All penalties imposed by this article shall be payable and recoverable in the same manner as if they were part of the permit fee imposed. If the failure to pay any such permit fee when due is explained to the satisfaction of the tax administrator, he/she may waive payment of the whole or any part of any penalty. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-2008) 
Sec. 4-19. - No refunds. 
    The revocation of any license or permit to deal in alcoholic beverages or the abandonment by any person of his business in dealing in such beverages at any time or for any cause whatever shall not entitle the dealer to claim or recover from the tax administrator or the city any portion of the amount paid for any of the above permits. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-08) 
Sec. 4-20. - Payment prerequisite to sale of beverages. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of selling, offering for sale, having in possession for sale, or otherwise dispensing of any of the alcoholic beverages covered by this chapter without first paying the permit fees as above required. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-08) 
Sec. 4-21. - Applicants to be fingerprinted, have felony conviction check. 
(a)  All applicants for the issuance of alcoholic beverage permits and employees as defined in section 4-9 shall be fingerprinted and subjected to a felony conviction check by the Rapides Parish Sheriff's Office or applicable law enforcement agency as a condition precedent to the issuance of any permit for the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(b)  The Rapides Parish Sheriff's Office or applicable law enforcement agency shall sign a certificate of eligibility attesting to the successful completion of the above-mentioned procedures. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-08) 
Sec. 4-22. - Sale near church, school, public library, or playground, full time day care or correctional facility. 
(a)  Prohibited. The sale of alcoholic beverage of high and alcohol content within three hundred (300) feet of any church, synagogue, public library, school, playground, full time day care center as defined in R.S. 17:405 (A)(4), or a correctional facility housing inmates, including but not limited to a halfway house. 
(b)  Computation of distances. The distances within which the sale of alcoholic beverages of high alcoholic content and alcoholic beverages of low alcoholic content are prohibited shall be measured as follows: 
(1)  In areas which are divided into subdivisions with streets, blocks and sidewalks the distance shall be measured as a person walks using the sidewalk from the nearest point of the property line of the church, synagogue, public library, public playground, school, full time day care center, or correctional facility housing inmates, including but not limited to a halfway house to the nearest point of the premises to be licensed. For the purpose of this section "premises" shall be defined as the definite closed or partitioned-in locality, whether room, shop or building wherein alcoholic beverages are sold. 
(2)  In areas which are not divided into subdivisions with streets, blocks or sidewalks, the distance shall be measured as a pedestrian would travel if there would be a sidewalk or paved walk-way along the edge or parallel to the edge or side of the street or roadway from the nearest point of the property line of the church, synagogue, public library, public playground, school, full time day care center, or correctional facility housing inmates, including but not limited to a halfway house to the nearest point of the premises to be licensed. For the purpose of this section "premises" shall be defined as the definite closed or partitioned-in locality, whether room, shop or building wherein alcoholic beverages are sold. 
(c)  Violations, penalty. Any person, firm, association of persons, corporation or partnership violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for not more than thirty (30) days, or both fined and imprisoned, in the discretion of the court. 
(d)  Should any premises licensed to deal in alcoholic beverages be located within a distance less than that provided by a city ordinance pursuant to this section from property which is purchased or acquired after the license was obtained for the construction, erection, movement, or development of a public playground or a building used exclusively as a church or synagogue, public library, school, full-time day care center, or correctional facility housing inmates, including but not limited to a halfway house, such subsequent purchase or acquisition shall not be grounds for the revocation, withholding, denial, or refusal to renew the permit on said premises. 
(e)  The prohibitions in this section do not apply to any premises which have been licensed to deal in alcoholic beverages for a period of one year or longer prior to the adoption of the ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-08; Ord. No. 132-2016, § I, 9-6-2016) 
Sec. 4-23. - Qualification of persons, businesses, etc., for license/permit. 
    Each application for Class A, B or R low or high alcoholic content licenses and/or permits shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Is a person of good character, reputation and over twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(2)  Is a citizen of the United States. 
(3)  A person who has been a resident of the State of Louisiana continuously for a period of not less than two (2) years. The requirements as to citizenship and residence do not apply to officers, directors, stockholders of corporations applying for retail permits only. The corporation shall be either organized under the laws of the State of Louisiana or qualified to do business within the State of Louisiana. The requirements as to Louisiana citizenship do not apply to wholesalers or retailers who held permits on or prior to January 1, 1946. 
(4)  Is the owner of the premises or has a bona fide notarized written lease. 
(5)  Has not been convicted of a felony under the laws of the United States, the State of Louisiana, or any other state or country. 
(6)  Has not been adjudged by a board or convicted by a court in this or in any other state or by the United States or any other country of soliciting for prostitution, gambling, letting of premises for gambling, contributing to the delinquency of juveniles, keeping a disorderly place, or illegally distributing or intent thereof in controlled dangerous substances as defined in Louisiana Revised Statutes. 
(7)  Has not had any authorized license or permit connected with alcoholic beverages revoked, or been convicted of a felony. Has not had a judgment of court rendered against him involving alcoholic beverages, by this political subdivision, or this or any other state, or by the United States, for two (2) years prior to the application. 
(8)  Has not been adjudged by any board or convicted by a court of violating any provisions of R.S. Title 26. 
(9)  Has not been adjudged by any board or convicted of violating any municipal or parish ordinances adopted pursuant to the provisions of R.S. 26:494. 
(10)  Has not had any certificate, permit or license to dispense alcoholic beverages as described anywhere in this chapter, issued by any other parish, municipality, or state, suspended or revoked. 
(11)  Is not the spouse of a person whose application has been denied or whose permit has been revoked, unless judicially separated or divorced. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-08) 
Sec. 4-24. - Reserved. 
Sec. 4-25. - Prohibited acts on licensed retail premises; suspension or revocation of permits. 
    No person holding a retail dealer's permit to sell alcoholic beverages within the city, and no agent, associate or employee of any such person, shall do or permit any of the following acts to be done on or about the licensed premises: 
(1)  Sell or serve alcoholic beverages to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years unless such person submits any one of the following establishing the age of the person as being twenty-one (21) years or older: 
a.  A valid, current Louisiana driver's license which contains a photograph of the person presenting the driver's license. 
b.  A valid, current, driver's license of another state which contains a photograph of the person and birth date of the person submitting the driver's license. 
c.  A valid, current, special identification card issued by the State of Louisiana pursuant to R.S. 40:1321 containing a photograph of the person submitting the identification card. 
d.  A valid, current, passport or visa issued by the federal government or another country or nation, that contains a permanently attached photograph of the person and the date of birth of the person submitting the passport or visa. 
e.  A valid, current, military or federal identification card issued by the federal government containing a photograph of the person and date of birth of the person submitting the identification card. 
Each form of identification listed above must on its face establish the age of the person as twenty-one (21) years or older, and there must be no reason to doubt the authenticity or correctness of the identification. No form of identification mentioned above shall be accepted as proof of age if it is expired, defaced, mutilated, or altered. If the driver's license, state identification card, or lawful identification submitted is a duplicate, the person shall submit additional identification which contains the name, date of birth, and photograph of the person. In addition, an educational institution card, check cashing identification card, or employee identification card shall not be considered as lawful identification for purposes of this paragraph. 
(2)  Sell or serve alcoholic beverages to any intoxicated person; 
(3)  Permit, aid or intentionally entice any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years to visit or loiter about any place where alcoholic beverages are the principal commodities sold, handled, or given away or consumed; provided that this section shall not apply to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years of age when such person is accompanied by such person's parent or legal guardian who is twenty-one (21) years of age or older and shall not apply to person(s) lawfully employed by the retail dealer in accordance with this ordinance. The provisions of this section shall in no way prohibit the presence of any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years on or about a licensed premises for any function sponsored by a religious or charitable organization with tax exempt status under Section 501(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of the United States, or by a fraternal beneficiary society with tax exempt status under 501(8) of the said code, and no alcoholic beverages are sold, handled, given away or accessible during the presence of any such person. 
(4)  Permit any prostitute to frequent the licensed premises or letting the premises for prostitution; 
(5)  Permit any disturbance of the peace or obscenity, or any lewd, immoral or improper entertainment, conduct or practices on the licensed premises; 
(6)  Sell, offer for sale, possess or permit the consumption on the licensed premises of any kind or type of alcoholic beverages, the sale or possession of which is not authorized under the permit; 
(7)  Permit any illegal distribution or intent thereof of any controlled dangerous substance; 
(8)  Pandering; 
(9)  Permit any gambling or letting the premises for gambling; 
(10)  Permit any act which might adversely affect the public health, safety or morals; 
(11)  Employ or permit any person to frequent the premises and solicit patrons for drinks, or to accept drinks from patrons and receive therefor any commission or any remuneration in any way; 
(12)  Any acts prohibited under R.S. 26:286 and 26:287 as may be amended. 
(13)  Permit or allow any nude or partially nude person, dancer, host, hostess, waiter or waitress on the premises whether in the capacity of an employee, entertainer, guest, invitee, patron, or otherwise. 
For the purpose of this article, the word "nude" shall be taken to mean a person who is less than completely or opaquely covered such as to expose to view that person's genitals and/or pubic region, all of buttocks area or the female breast area below a point immediately above the top part of the aureole. 
(14)  Commit, attempt, conspire, aid, abet or encourage any persons to commit any acts or things prohibited by this chapter, by the city code, by the provisions of any applicable Louisiana Revised Statutes or laws, or applicable laws of the United States or any other country. 
(15)  Permit any person to perform any services, on the licensed premises, covered under this chapter for which a license/permit is required without same being first issued and in a current valid status. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-08) 
Sec. 4-26. - Suspension or revocation; grounds enumerated. 
    The following shall be sufficient to cause suspension or revocation: 
(1)  If there is any misstatement or suppression of fact in the application for the permit. 
(2)  If the permit was granted to any person who is or has been engaged in the business of dealing in alcoholic beverages with a person whose application for a permit has been denied or whose permit has been revoked or suspended, in the relationship of spouse, agent, partner, employer, employee or interposed person. 
(3)  If any licensed dealer fails to pay any excise tax or local political subdivision sales and use tax, penalties, interest, tax deposits, attorney fees, court cost fees, occupational license tax or other tax, license or fee required by the parish or applicable municipality and due [from] him to the parish or applicable municipality, as the owner or operator of any regulated business within the parish or applicable municipality; 
(4)  Revocation, suspension or denial of a license/permit under this section may cause the revocation or suspension, as the case may be, of any other permit or license for alcoholic beverage held by the same permittee/licensee; 
(5)  Failure of the license/permit holder, or the designated manager in the absence of the holder, to immediately notify the police of any disturbance, fistic encounter or similar incident occurring on the licensed property or violation of any criminal statute or ordinance occurring on the licensed property of which the owner, manager or person in charge had knowledge or of which he should have known; 
(6)  Violation of, or failure to comply with, any of the provisions of this chapter by any person issued a license/permit under this chapter, or by such person's manager, agent, servant or employee; 
(7)  Failure of a licensee/permittee to cooperate fully with any law enforcement agency or its agents or any agent of the state Alcohol Beverage Control Board in conducting any official investigation which, in any way, involves the licensed premises, the license/permit holder, an agent, servant, representative or employee of, or any customer of, or person conducting business with the licensed business, except that no one may be compelled to incriminate themselves in violation of state or federal law; 
(8)  Sell, serve or dispense in any manner, any alcoholic beverages covered by this chapter to any person whose actions, mannerisms and general conduct would reasonably indicate that such person is intoxicated or under the influence of drugs. 
(9)  Sell, serve, or dispense in any manner, any of alcoholic beverages covered by this chapter to any person(s) unless such person submits a pictured driver's license or other pictured lawful identification that lists the age of the person submitting it as being of lawful age to purchase such alcoholic beverages and there is no reason to doubt the authenticity or correctness of the identification. 
(10)  Allow or permit any person(s) to frequent or visit the licensed premises where the principal commodity sold is alcoholic beverages unless such person submits a pictured driver's license or other lawful pictured identification that establishes the person as twenty-one (21) years of age or older and there is no reason to doubt the authenticity or correctness of the identification. For the purpose of this section a pictured lawful identification shall be the same as required in section 4-25. 
(11)  If the permit was issued to an interposed person contrary to R.S. 26:81. 
(12)  If the permittee has been found guilty by a court of competent jurisdiction of either any of the following offenses: 
a.  Violation of the Sunday closing laws where applicable. 
b.  Violation of any municipal or parish or other ordinance providing for Sunday closing hours. 
c.  Violation of any municipal or parish ordinance relating to alcoholic beverages enacted pursuant to law if the ordinance provides for revocation of the permit for its violation. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-08) 
Secs. 4-27, 4-28. - Reserved. 
Sec. 4-29. - Suspension, revocation of permits, closure. 
(a)  Any person, firm, corporation or association of persons who, as a business, dispenses in any manner any alcoholic beverages described in section 4-1 of this chapter without the proper license/permit shall have the premises of such business place closed and sealed from entry and any alcoholic beverages therein covered by this chapter shall be seized by the applicable law enforcement agency. 
(b)  The tax administrator may suspend or revoke permits for causes set forth in sections 4-25 and 4-26 in a manner consistent with that prescribed in R.S. 26:290, et seq. 
(c)  Except as otherwise provided, when a license/permit of a business covered under this chapter is revoked, no license/permit shall be issued covering the same premises until one (1) year after the date of revocation, and when a license/permit is denied for a premises such license/permit request may be denied for the same premises for a two-year period. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-08) 
Sec. 4-30. - Appeals. 
    Appeals of decisions of the tax administrator or the city pertaining to fines, revocation, suspension or denial of any license or permit shall be followed in accordance with procedures of this chapter as established for new licenses in that any appeal from the tax administrator or the city decision must be filed with the Ninth Judicial District Court within ten (10) days from receipt of notice of the decision, and such appeal may suspend the decision until the matter is decided by the court, or the decision will be final. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-08) 
Sec. 4-31. - Notice to state. 
    Written notice of a decision by the applicable governing authority to warn, fine, deny, suspend or revoke any license or permit shall be sent immediately to such state officer, departments or agencies as may have jurisdiction over, or interest in such license/permit, with a request that the state take like action. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-08) 
Sec. 4-32. - Law enforcement. 
    The chief of police shall notify the tax administrator of any and all arrests or charges at any business establishment licensed under this chapter, which involve the holder of the license for that establishment, or any agent, servant or employee of the same, and which arrests and charges relate to violations of this chapter; and the licensee, the agent, servant or employee of the same, as the case may be, may be charged if probable cause exist by citation or arrested and the Rapides Parish Tax Administrator shall be notified of all convictions resulting there from. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-08) 
Sec. 4-33. - Sales to minors. 
(a)  The sale to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years of any of the beverages permitted under this chapter is hereby prohibited. 
(b)  Any person, firm, corporation or association of persons applying for a license to sell, dispense or deliver alcoholic beverages, or applying to renew an existing license to sell, dispense or deliver alcoholic beverages, shall be required to sign a statement acknowledging that such applicant is fully cognizant of the laws pertaining to the sale, dispensing or delivering of alcoholic beverages to minors and to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years. Such signed statement shall be executed prior to the issuance or re-issuance of any license. 
(c)  Penalties shall be imposed, including fines or suspensions, on dealers who or whose employees sell alcoholic beverages to minors. Said penalty shall be within the following guidelines, except as may be further provided in this chapter: 
(1)  1st offense-Fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or a three-day suspension. 
(2)  2nd offense-Fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or a ten-day suspension. 
(3)  3rd offense-A mandatory suspension of thirty (30) days. 
(4)  4th offense-A mandatory suspension of six (6) months. 
Second and subsequent offenses shall be penalties for all violations within a two-year period. 
(d)  Notwithstanding any other provision to the contrary, in addition to any other penalty imposed by law, any dealer who or whose employees are convicted of selling alcoholic beverages to minors three (3) times in one (1) year shall be penalized by mandatory suspension of their alcoholic beverage license for a period of thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-08) 
Sec. 4-34. - Nudity is prohibited in sexually oriented businesses where alcohol is consumed. 
    It shall be unlawful for any sexually oriented business or any house of public entertainment as provided in R.S. 33:1236(6), which permits the consumption of alcoholic beverages at their establishment or place of business to permit or allow any nude or partially nude person, dancer, host, hostess, waiter or waitress on the premises whether in the capacity of an employee, entertainer, guest, invitee, patron or otherwise. 
    For the purpose of this article, the word nude shall be taken to mean a person who is less than completely or opaquely covered such as to expose to view that person's genitals and/or pubic region, all of buttocks area or the female breast area below a point immediately above the top part of the aureole. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-08) 
Sec. 4-35 - Requirement to display sign; fetal alcohol syndrome. 
(a)  Each person holding a Class A license under the provisions of section 4-14 shall post and display in a conspicuous place on each licensed premises a sign which shall clearly read as follows, to wit: "WARNING: Drinking alcoholic beverages during pregnancy may cause severe physical or mental birth defects." 
(b)  Signs required to be posted or displayed herein shall not be less than eight (8) inches by ten (10) inches, with letters not less than three-eighths ( 3/8 ) of an inch in height. Said signs must be substantially similar in design and color as the sample available for inspection at the office of the clerk of the council. 
(c)  Any licensee or permittee who shall violate the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) upon the first conviction and not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) upon the second and subsequent convictions. In the case of a corporation, the officer or agent in charge shall be subject to prosecution for any violation by such corporation, and upon conviction may be punished as provided above. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 2, 2-26-08) 
Sec. 4-36. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING, ZONING AND OPERATION REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 4-37. - Building requirements. 
(a)  Failure to acquire and maintain a valid health permit for any premises licensed under this chapter or violation of or noncompliance with any applicable fire prevention, uniform building codes, plumbing shall be cause for denial, revocation or suspension of any permit or license. Reinstatement of any such license, application or permit shall not be considered by the city until same receives notification from the proper authority that such violation or noncompliance has been corrected. In the case of new construction of a proposed licensed location, a certificate of occupancy shall be required before final issuance of a license or permit. 
(b)  In the event that premises licensed hereunder are destroyed by fire or any natural disaster or act of God, the licensee shall be permitted a reasonable time within which to reconstruct the licensed premises, but in no event longer than twenty-four (24) months, unless further extended by the city. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 3, 2-26-08) 
Sec. 4-38. - Security devices and standards for Class B retail dealers; camera requirements for certain permit holders for robbery deterrence. 
(a)  Every Class B retail dealer's premises shall be equipped with the following security devices and standards and the devices and standards shall be maintained in proper working order at all times, subject to inspection for compliance by the Alexandria Police Department: 
(1)  A security camera system capable of recording and retrieving an image to assist offender identification and apprehension which shall record during business operating hours the interior business area open to the general public and the entrance and exit of the dealer's premises ; provided, the video tape or image record, disk image or other recorded medium shall be retained by the retail dealer for a period of at least thirty (30) days from the date of recording which recorded medium shall be preserved by the retail dealer and available for inspection for compliance. 
(2)  A drop safe or cash management system for restricted access to cash receipts and which limits the cash on-hand after 11:00 p.m. and before 5:00 a.m. 
(3)  A lighted parking lot illuminated at an intensity of at least two (2) foot-candles per square foot at eighteen (18) inches above the surface. 
(4)  Height markers at the entrance of the dealer's premises which display height measures. 
(5)  A silent alarm to a private security agency. 
(6)  Bait money consisting of recorded serial number currencies or red dye marked money. 
(b)  If any of the following crimes (as identified and defined by the Louisiana Revised Statutes) including murder, robbery, rape, sexual battery, kidnapping or false imprisonment, or a Schedule II drug distribution or possession, occurs or has occurred at a Class B retail dealer's premises and arises out of the operation of the dealer's premises the permit holder shall implement at least one (1) of the following security measures: 
(1)  Provide at least two (2) employees on the premises at all times between 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m.; 
(2)  Provide a security guard on the premises at all times after 11:00 p.m. and before 5:00 a.m.; 
(3)  Lock the premises throughout the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. and only transact business through an indirect pass through trough, trapdoor or window; or 
(4)  Close the premises at all times after 11:00 p.m. and before 5:00 a.m. 
(c)  A violation of subsection (b) above or an intentional failure of the operation of a security camera system capable of recording and retrieving an image to reproduce images shall be grounds for revocation of the permit holder's alcohol beverage license permit and any other occupational license granted to the dealer for the premises. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 3, 2-26-08) 
Sec. 4-39. - Zoning. 
(a)  All zoning requirements as required by the zoning ordinance of the city must be met prior to the time an application for an alcoholic beverage license is filed with the tax administrator or the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or have in possession for sale or offer for sale any alcoholic beverage except in the commercial districts, and the industrial districts known as zoning districts "CBD", "C-2", "I-1" and "I-2" respectively, as defined and outlined in chapter 28 except by a special exception provided by ordinance of the city council. Such amendment shall be limited to the present tenant/owner and present use of structure. These special exceptions shall expire immediately upon change of tenant/owner or use. 
(c)  Where any zone "CBD", "C-2", "I-1" or "I-2" border upon a district designated in chapter 28 as "SF-1", "SF-2" or "SF-3", no sale of such beverage shall be allowed within three hundred (300) feet of any residence unless a special exception has been recommended by the Alcohol Beverage and Drug Abuse Control Commission and approved by ordinance of the City Council permitting the sale of alcoholic beverages within three hundred (300) feet of any residence, provided that this restriction shall not apply to Class B or C permits. 
(d)  No person operating a business which is presently classified as a nonconforming commercial use, as defined in the zoning ordinance of the city may apply for or be issued a Class A license or permit without first obtaining a petition of fifty-one (51) percent of the property owners within a three-hundred-foot radius of such business. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 3, 2-26-08) 
ARTICLE IV. - PUBLIC NUISANCE, LICENSE/PERMIT SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION 

Sec. 4-40. - Public nuisances in the City of Alexandria; factors to be considered; procedure to abate; penalty and revocation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any licensee/permittee's establishment, place of business, and/or premises to become a public nuisance and against the public good and welfare of the community. In addition to other penalties provided in this chapter, any combination of the following activities that total to twelve (12) points within any twelve (12) consecutive month period shall be considered a public nuisance. Incidences or complaints may be considered by the mayor on recommendation of the chief of police. The following points shall be assigned to each specified activity: 
(1)  High violent crime activity: Arrests wherein any person sustained a physical injury on the premises of the establishment; or wherein any person sustained a physical injury from activities arising out of the premises of the establishment. Four (4) points. 
(2)  Drug-related activity: Arrests for any violation of any provision of the Louisiana Uniform Controlled Dangerous Substance Act, R.S. 40:961 et seq., on the premises of the establishment; or for activities arising out of the premises of the establishment. Four (4) points. 
(3)  Prostitution-related activity: Arrests for prostitution or solicitation for prostitution or any related provisions of the Louisiana Criminal Code, R.S. 14:82 et seq., or any corresponding city or parish ordinance on the premises of the establishment; or for activities arising out of the premises of the establishment. Four (4) points. 
(4)  Sale of alcohol beverages to minors. Three (3) points. 
(5)  Sale of tobacco or tobacco products to minors. Three (3) points. 
(6)  Sale, exhibition or distribution of materials harmful to minors. Three (3) points. 
(7)  Disturbance-related activity: 
a.  Arrests and/or citations arising out of disturbances from the premises of the establishment. Two (2) points. 
b.  Arrests and/or citations arising out of disturbances from the premises of the establishment to residents of normal sensitivities living in any neighborhood adjacent to the premises of the establishment. Three (3) points. 
c.  In evaluating the points assessed against a licensee/permittee for a violation of subsections 4-40(a)(7)a. or b., the mayor may, in his sole discretion, reduce points by up to one-half (1/2) of the prescribed points if the licensee/permittee demonstrates, to the satisfaction of the mayor, that the licensee/permittee maintained security at the premises by a commissioned law enforcement officer at the time of the incident giving rise to the assignment of points. 
(b)  Whenever any evidence is presented to the mayor indicating that a permitted establishment shall have become a public nuisance, the mayor shall investigate the police records of the appropriate law enforcement agency or agencies. If this investigation shows that the permitted business has more likely than not become a public nuisance after considering the foregoing factors, the mayor shall initiate a hearing and shall make a recommendation of revocation to the alcohol beverage and drug abuse control commission. 
(c)  The mayor shall, in accordance with this chapter, and after a hearing before the alcohol beverage and drug abuse control commission and upon a finding of revocation, authorize the tax administrator to revoke the permit issued to any permitted establishment that has become a public nuisance. Any permit that has been revoked in accordance with this chapter shall not be re-issued or renewed for a period of twenty-four (24) months. 
(d)  Before any permit is revoked pursuant to this section, the licensee/permittee shall be entitled to a hearing before the alcohol beverage control commission. A permit may be revoked pending any appeal to any court of competent jurisdiction, unless in the ruling of the alcohol beverage control commission a stay of revocation is entered and a cash bond in favor of the city in an amount set by the alcohol beverage control commission is posted with the mayor. 
(e)  Upon surrender of a permit covering an establishment, place of business or premises that has accumulated a total of six (6) points within a twelve-month period, no permit covering that same establishment, place of business or premises shall be issued for a period for six (6) months from the date of surrender. 
(f)  The procedures for revocation set out in this section are in addition to other sanctions and powers of the mayor and the alcohol beverage control commission set out in this chapter, and do not supersede or replace other enforcement or penalty provisions of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, § 4, 2-26-08) 
Sec. 4-41. - Operating without license, closure. 
    Any person, firm, corporation or association of persons who, as a business, dispenses in any manner any alcoholic beverages described in section 4-1 of this chapter without the proper license/permit shall have the premises of such business place closed and sealed from entry and any alcoholic beverages therein covered by this chapter shall be seized by the city. 
(Ord. No. 184-1990, 7-31-90) 
Sec. 4-41.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 37-2009, § I, adopted February 24, 2009, repealed section 4-41.1 in its entirety, which pertained to public nuisances in the city; factors to be considered; procedure to abate; penalty and revocation, and derived from Ord. No. 224-2006, § I, adopted July 5, 2006. 
Cross reference- Public nuisances in the City of Alexandria, factors to be considered; procedure to abate; penalty and revocation, § 4-40. 
Sec. 4-42. - License/permit revocation or suspension. 
    In addition to any other causes enumerated in this chapter, the alcoholic beverage control commission may levy fines, suspend or revoke any license/permit for any of the following causes: 
(1)  For being convicted by a court for violation of any ordinance, statute or law or other provision contained in section 4-40(1) of this chapter; 
(2)  For any misstatement or suppression of fact in the information required to be given by the applicant under this chapter in applying for a license/permit; 
(3)  If the license/permit was granted to any person who is, or has been, engaged in the business of dealing in alcoholic beverages with a person whose application for a license/permit has been denied, revoked or suspended, in the relationship of spouse, agent, partner, employer, employee or interposed person; 
(4)  If any licensed dealer fails to pay any excise tax or local political subdivision sales and use tax, penalties, interest, tax deposits, attorney fees, court cost fees, occupational license tax or other tax, license or fee required by the city and due [from] him to the City of Alexandria, as the owner or operator of any regulated business within the city; 
(5)  Revocation, suspension or denial of a license/permit under this section may cause the revocation or suspension, as the case may be, of any other permit or license for alcoholic beverage held by the same permittee/licensee; 
(6)  Failure of the license/permit holder, or the designated manager in the absence of the holder, to immediately notify the police of any disturbance, fistic encounter or similar incident occurring on the licensed property or violation of any criminal statute or ordinance occurring on the licensed property of which the owner, manager or person in charge had knowledge or of which he should have known; 
(7)  Violation of, or failure to comply with, any of the provisions of this chapter by any person issued a license/permit under this chapter, or by such person's manager, agent, servant or employee; 
(8)  Failure of a licensee/permittee to cooperate fully with any law enforcement agency or its agents or any agent of the state A.B.C. board in conducting any official investigation which, in any way, involves the licensed premises, the license/permit holder, an agent, servant, representative or employee of, or any customer of, or person conducting business with the licensed business, except that no one may be compelled to incriminate themselves in violation of state or federal law; 
(9)  Sell, serve or dispense in any manner, any alcoholic beverages covered by this chapter to any person whose actions, mannerisms and general conduct would reasonably indicate that such person is intoxicated or under the influence of drugs. 
(10)  Sell, serve, or dispense in any manner, any of alcoholic beverages covered by this chapter to any person(s) unless such person submits a pictured driver's license or other pictured lawful identification that lists the age of the person submitting it as being of lawful age to purchase such alcoholic beverages and there is no reason to doubt the authenticity or correctness of the identification. 
For the purpose of this section, a pictured lawful identification shall be any pictured identification which [it] shall be illegal to alter or obtain by fraud, or any pictured identification issued by any government agency, either local, state, federal or international, such as a driver's license, state I.D. card, alien registration card, passport, military I.D. card, or federal I.D. card, and [such identification] shall list the age of the person submitting it as being of lawful age to purchase alcoholic beverages. 
This section shall not apply to Class R permit holders or to persons who are obviously of legal age to purchase such alcoholic beverages, but this shall in no way exempt license holders from responsibility of checking for identification when they are not positive or actually know for a fact that the person is of legal age to purchase such alcoholic beverages. 
(11)  Allow or permit any person(s) to frequent or visit the licensed premises where the principal commodity sold is alcoholic beverages unless such person submits a pictured driver's license or other lawful pictured identification that establishes the person as eighteen (18) years of age or older and there is no reason to doubt the authenticity or correctness of the identification. For the purpose of this section a pictured lawful identification shall be the same as required in subsection (10) above, except that it shall list the age of the person submitting it as being eighteen (18) years of age or older. This section shall not apply to Class R permit holders or to persons who are obviously of legal age to purchase such alcoholic beverages, but this shall in no way exempt license holders from responsibility of checking for identification when they are not positive or actually know for a fact that the person is of legal age to purchase such alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. 184-1990, 7-31-90; Ord. No. 209-1994, § 2, 9-27-94) 
Sec. 4-43. - Appeals. 
    Appeals of decisions of the alcoholic beverage control commission pertaining to fines, revocation, suspension or denial of any license or permit shall be followed in accordance with procedures of this chapter as established for new licenses in that any appeal to the commission's decision must be filed with the 9th Judicial District Court within ten (10) days from receipt of notice of the commission's decision, and such appeal may suspend the commission's decision until the matter is decided by the court, or the decision of the commission will be final. 
(Ord. No. 184-1990, 7-31-90; Ord. No. 209-1994, § 2, 9-27-94) 
Sec. 4-44. - Discretion of commission. 
    If the commission finds that a violation is of a minor nature; that there are extenuating circumstances, or that there are reasonable grounds to expect that the licensee/permittee will not again violate any of the provisions of this chapter, it may, by majority vote and after hearing all evidence, elect to warn any licensee/permittee, levy fines, or suspend the license or permit. If the violation is flagrant or serious, or if the licensee/permittee has had his license/permit suspended, the commission may revoke the license/permit and shall immediately notify applicable state and local authorities of its action. 
(Ord. No. 184-1990, 7-31-90; Ord. No. 209-1994, § 2, 9-27-94) 
Sec. 4-45. - Notice to state. 
    Written notice of a decision by the commission to warn, fine, deny, suspend or revoke any license or permit shall be sent immediately to such state officer, departments or agencies as may have jurisdiction over, or interest in such license/permit, with a request that the state take like action. 
(Ord. No. 184-1990, 7-31-90; Ord. No. 209-1994, § 2, 9-27-94) 
Sec. 4-46. - Law enforcement. 
    The chief of the police department of the City of Alexandria is hereby required to promptly notify the mayor of any and all arrests or charges at any business establishment licensed under this chapter, which involve the holder of the license for that establishment, or any agent, servant or employee of the same, and which arrests and charges relate to violations of this chapter; and the chief of police is hereby directed to charge the licensee, the agent, servant or employee of the same, as the case may be, with such violation before the proper court, who in turn will notify the mayor of all convictions resulting therefrom. 
(Ord. No. 184-1990, 7-31-90) 
Sec. 4-47. - Premises, revocation, duration. 
    When a license/permit of a business covered under this chapter is revoked, no license/permit shall be issued covering the same premises until one (1) year after the date of revocation, and when a license/permit is denied for a premises such license/permit request may be denied for the same premises for a two-year period. 
(Ord. No. 184-1990, 7-31-90) 
Sec. 4-48. - Revocation show cause hearing. 
    City officials, and law enforcement authorities have the right to have a licensee/permittee cited by the council to show cause why a license/permit should not be revoked. 
(Ord. No. 184-1990, 7-31-90) 
Sec. 4-49. - Revocation costs. 
    In hearings of the council which finally result in withholding the issuance of a license/permit or in suspending or revoking same, the council shall assess any costs of the hearing to the applicant, licensee/permittee as the case may be. The costs are recoverable by the city in any appellate proceeding instituted by the applicant, licensee/permittee or in any other judicial proceeding. 
(Ord. No. 184-1990, 7-31-90) 
Sec. 4-50. - Suspension. 
    Should any license/permit of a business be suspended by the council, it shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to sell any of the beverages described in section 4-1, on the premises during the suspension. 
(Ord. No. 184-1990, 7-31-90) 
Sec. 4-51. - Notice of suspension or revocation. 
    Upon suspension or revocation of a business licensed under this chapter, the council clerk shall immediately notify the chief of the police department of the council's action, and the council clerk shall immediately cause to be published one (1) time in the Alexandria Daily Town Talk, notice of such suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. No. 184-1990, 7-31-90) 
Secs. 4-52-4-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RESERVED[2] 

Footnotes:
