Editor's note- Ord. No. 49-2008, § 5, adopted February 26, 2008, repealed §§ 4-60-4-62, which pertained to penalties associated with violations of the alcoholic beverage license regulations. 

Secs. 4-60-4-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - GALLONAGE TAX 

Sec. 4-70. - Levy on beer, porter, ale, fruit juices and wine of designated alcoholic content. 
    In addition to all excise, license or other taxes presently imposed, or permitted to be imposed, there is hereby levied a tax on all beer, porter, ale, fruit juices, or wine containing more than one-half of one percent (0.005) and not more than six (6) percent of alcohol by volume of one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50) per standard barrel of thirty-one (31) gallons, or at a like rate on any other quantity, or for fractional parts of such barrel sold for consumption within the territorial limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 184-1990, 7-31-90) 
Sec. 4-71. - Collection by wholesalers from vendees; monthly remittance to state collector of revenue. 
    The tax herein levied shall be collected by all wholesale dealers from their vendees purchasing for consumption in the city, on each sale and shall be remitted by the wholesale dealers to the collector of revenue of the state for each month, on or before the 20th day of each succeeding month, respectively, all in accordance with rules and regulations promulgated by the collector of revenue and as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 184-1990, 7-31-90) 
Sec. 4-72. - Liability and penalty on failure of wholesaler to collect. 
    Failure of any wholesale dealer to collect and remit the tax levied, when due, or failure to pay the tax, when due, shall, ipso facto, render each of them liable for the amount of taxes found to be due, together with a penalty of twenty (20) percent of the amount of tax due, plus an additional amount of ten (10) percent of the tax and penalty, as attorney's fees if referred to an attorney for collection. 
(Ord. No. 184-1990, 7-31-90) 
Chapter 5 - ANIMALS, FOWL, BEES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Noisy animals, § 13-31(b)(4); drivers or riders of animals subject to traffic regulations, § 25-17. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 5-1. - Livestock at large-Prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner, or representative of the owner, of any horse, mule, cow, hog, goat or other livestock, to permit same to roam at large within the city. 
(Code 1956, § 5-3) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate animals at large, R.S. 33:401, A(8); authority to prohibit livestock running at large, R.S. 3:2531. 
Sec. 5-2. - Same-Impounding; redemption; fees; sale; disposition of moneys. 
    Any policeman or impounding officer of the city is hereby authorized to impound any animal found roaming at large, contrary to the provisions of section 5-1. A penalty of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be collected for each animal impounded and seven dollars ($7.00) per diem for each animal so impounded, to cover the cost of its maintenance before the owner shall be permitted to reclaim the animal. In the event an animal is uncalled for and unclaimed by its owner or the owner's representative, within three (3) days the animal shall be advertised for sale three (3) times in a local newspaper, and shall be sold at the public pound by the impounding officer or a police officer to the last and highest bidder for cash. The funds realized from the sale of such animal shall be used, first, to pay all cost of maintaining, impounding and advertising for sale, and the balance shall be deposited with the city treasurer who shall dispose of same as provided in section 10-8. 
(Code 1956, § 5-4; Ord. No. 33-1992, § 1, 2-4-92) 
Sec. 5-3. - Fowl to be enclosed; prohibited at large; sanitary conditions required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner, or any representative of the owner, to permit, or suffer, any chickens, or other poultry of any kind, to go upon the streets, sidewalks, public ways or upon the property or premises of any other person. 
(b)  All yards and enclosures where chickens or other poultry are kept shall be maintained in a sanitary condition in compliance with the state sanitary code and the regulations of the health unit. 
(Code 1956, § 5-5) 
Sec. 5-4. - Livestock prohibited within designated zoning districts. 
    Keeping or maintaining of livestock within the "A" Residential districts of the city as defined and outlined in Chapter 28, is hereby prohibited as a menace to the public health, comfort and welfare and is declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Code 1956, § 5-2) 
Sec. 5-5. - Keeping hogs and hog pens declared nuisance. 
    The keeping or maintaining of hogs and hog pens within the city is hereby declared a nuisance and any person who shall keep a hog or maintain a hog pen within the city shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1956, § 5-6) 
Sec. 5-6. - Cruelty to animals/fowl. 
(a)  [Definitions.] The following definitions shall be used in this section to define terms and establish limitations for purposes of enforcement as provided by R.S. 14:102.1 through R.S. 14:102.4. 
(1)  Cruel means every act or failure to act whereby unjustifiable physical pain or suffering is caused or permitted. 
(2)  Abandons means to completely forsake and desert an animal previously under the custody or possession of a person without making reasonable arrangements for its proper care, sustenance, and shelter. 
(3)  Proper food means providing each animal with daily food of sufficient quality and quantity to prevent unnecessary or unjustifiable suffering by the animal. 
(4)  Proper water means providing each animal with daily water of sufficient quality and quantity to prevent unnecessary or unjustifiable suffering by the animal. 
(5)  Proper shelter means providing each animal with adequate shelter from the elements as required to prevent unnecessary or unjustifiable suffering by the animal. Proper shelter includes shade in the summer. 
(6)  Proper veterinary care means providing each animal with veterinary care sufficient to prevent unnecessary or unjustifiable physical pain or suffering by the animal. 
(b)  [Unlawful acts.] 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally overdrive, overload, drive when overloaded or overwork a living animal. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to torture, torment, cruelly beat or unjustifiably injure, maim, mutilate or kill any living animal whether belonging to him/herself or another. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any person having charge, custody or possession of any animal to fail to provide proper food, drink, shelter and veterinary care. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful for any person to impound or confine a living animal without proper food, drink and shelter. 
(5)  It shall be unlawful for any person to carry or cause to be carried a living animal in or upon a vehicle in a cruel or inhumane manner. 
(6)  It shall be unlawful for any person to administer or expose domestic animals to poisonous or noxious drugs or substances with the intent of ingestion or damage to the animal. 
(7)  It shall be unlawful for any person to kill or injure any animal belonging to another person without legal privilege or consent of the owner. 
(8)  It shall be unlawful for any person to mistreat any living animal by act or omission causing physical pain, suffering or death. 
(c)  [Penalty.] Any person violating this section shall be liable to punishment as provided in section 1-8. 
(Ord. No. 93-1992, § 2, 4-14-92) 
Cross reference- Cruelty to animals, criminal code, § 15-109 et seq. 
State Law reference- Mistreatment, R.S. 14:102. 
Sec. 5-7. - Injuring-Alexandria Zoological Park animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or place any object into any exhibit at the Alexandria Zoological Park with the intent to maim, irritate or otherwise injure any animal being cared for there. 
(Code 1956, § 18-14.1) 
Sec. 5-8. - Bees or beehives; keeping or maintaining prohibited. 
    The keeping of bees or the operation or maintenance of beehives within the city is hereby prohibited. 
(Code 1956, § 5-1) 
Secs. 5-9-5-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate and tax dogs, R.S. 3:2731. 

Sec. 5-20. - Impounding officer and assistants; authority. 
    The mayor shall select an impounding officer and such assistants as are deemed necessary to enforce the provisions of this article and they are hereby authorized to impound any dog and/or animal roaming at large, or any dog and/or animal being kept in the city that has not been vaccinated or on which the registration fee has not been paid as herein provided. 
(1)  Issue citations for the enforcement of this article as well as take action necessary to enforce statues regarding animal cruelty. 
(2)  Obtain warrants for such violation and assist law enforcement personnel in making arrests for such violations. 
(3)  Submit affidavits to the courts regarding such violations. 
(Code 1956, § 5-11; Ord. No. 136-1996, § 2, 6-18-96; Ord. No. 203-2006, § II, 6-20-2006) 
Sec. 5-21. - Vaccination, registration, fee, required. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner or keeper of any dog, cat or other indoor mammal over the age of four (4) months which is kept in the city to have the animal vaccinated against rabies annually. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any animal over the age of four (4) months in the city unless the animal has been vaccinated. 
    Every owner or keeper additionally shall register each animal over the age of four (4) weeks with the city of Alexandria Animal Control Officer who shall issue a metallic license tag bearing the license number, "City of Alexandria" and the calendar year for which the license is issued. The owner or keeper shall affix such license tag upon a collar worn at all times by the animal. At the option of, and at the sole expense of the owner or keeper, an identification chip may be implanted in the skin of the animal in lieu of the wearing of a collar tag. In addition to the license tag or chip, a license certificate shall be issued to the owner or keeper, showing the license number, the name and address of the owner, a physical description of the animal by sex and color, the breed if known and the expiration date of the license. Any animal kept in the city more than five (5) consecutive days shall be subject to the licensing requirements set forth herein. The license fees shall be charged in accordance with the maximum amounts permitted by Louisiana law. Any owner or keeper who fails to register an animal in accordance with this section shall be subject to punishment in accordance with section 1-8. 
    Notwithstanding the foregoing, a person who delivers an injured or ill animal to a licensed veterinarian for treatment may be permitted to register such animal upon presentation without penalty for failure to license. 
    The interval between revaccination shall conform to the standards set forth in the most recent Compendium of Animal Rabies Prevention and Control prepared by the National Association of State Public Health Veterinarians, Inc. 
(Code 1956, § 5-7; Ord. No. 33-1992, § 1, 2-4-92; Ord. No. 393-2006, § I, 11-21-06; Ord. No. 86-2017, § I, 6-27-2017) 
State Law reference- Vaccination requirements, R.S. 40:1277. 
Secs. 5-22, 5-23. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 33-1992, § 1, adopted Feb. 4, 1992, provided for the deletion of §§ 5-22, 5-23 which pertained to a dog registration fee and the issuance of a certificate of registration and vaccination. Prior to deletion such sections were derived from the 1956 Code, §§ 5-8 and 5-9. 
Sec. 5-24. - Dogs at large-Prohibited. 
    No person shall suffer or permit any dog owned by him or in his possession, or kept by him about his premises, to roam at large in the city at any time. 
    Dogs, when not caged, in fenced yard, indoors or tethered, are required to be under the control of the owner by leash, tether, or other means of control so as to not present a nuisance or danger to the public. 
    If chained or otherwise tethered, the minimum tether length shall be a fifteen-foot radius, providing a thirty-foot exercise diameter. Dog callers for tethered animals shall be of leather or nylon. 
    The owner, possessor or keeper of any dog, who suffers or permits it to roam at large in the city, shall be liable to punishment as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1956, § 5-10; Ord. No. 33-1992, § 1, 2-4-92; Ord. No. 93-1992, § 2, 4-14-92) 
Sec. 5-25. - Same-Disposition of impounded animals; fees. 
(a)  Any dog, cat or other household pet which has been impounded may be redeemed by paying the impounding officer a ten dollar ($10.00) initial impounding fee and a six dollar ($6.00) daily boarding fee; plus any other fees that may be due which shall be done before same is returned to the owner. 
(b)  Any dog, cat or other household pet which has been impounded for a second time within a twelve (12) month period may be redeemed by paying the impounding officer a twenty-five dollars ($25.00) initial impounding fee and a six dollar ($6.00) daily boarding fee; plus any other fees that may be due which shall be done before same is returned to the owner. 
(c)  Any dog, cat or other household pet which has been impounded for a third time within a twelve (12) month period may be redeemed by paying the impounding officer a fifty dollar ($50.00) initial impounding fee and a six dollar ($6.00) daily boarding fee; plus any other fees that may be due which shall be done before same is returned to the owner. 
(d)  Evidence of ownership shall be required in the form of registration, vaccination certificate or recent photo as a means to establish ownership. 
(e)  If any dog, cat or other household pet is not redeemed within three (3) days thereafter, the city may sell or destroy the animal and/or dispose of the animal by means allowed under Louisiana Law. 
(Code 1956, § 5-12; Ord. No. 4-1981, § 1, 1-6-81; Ord. No. 33-1992, § 1, 2-4-92; Ord. No. 159-1999, § 1, 7-13-99) 
Sec. 5-26. - Same-Destruction of dogs authorized at discretion of impounding officers or police department. 
    The impounding officer or any of his assistants or any members of the police department of the city are hereby authorized to snare, capture, leash or otherwise impound animals which are found roaming at large within the city. Whenever such action seems proper and advisable for purposes of public health and safety, same individuals are hereby authorized to exercise necessary means to control said animals and to protect the public including destruction of the animal. 
(Code 1956, § 5-13; Ord. No. 33-1992, § 1, 2-4-92) 
Sec. 5-27. - Sanitary conditions. 
    Owners shall maintain their animal yards in a sanitary condition sufficient to prevent odors or the breeding of flies and other pests. 
(Ord. No. 93-1992, § 2, 4-14-92) 
Sec. 5-28. - Enforcement by impounding officer and assistants; fines. 
    The impounding officer and such assistants as are deemed necessary to enforce the provisions of this Code and they are hereby authorized to inspect, investigate and issue citations to animal establishments including but not limited to pet stores, kennels, exhibits, circuses and pet shows. 
    Any persons and/or firms found in violation of the provisions of this Code shall for each violation be fined no less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or be imprisoned for not more than sixty (60) days or both. Each separate day on which any violation of the provisions of this Code is shown to have continued to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 203-2006, § III, 6-20-2006) 
Sec. 5-29. - Control of vicious dogs. 
    No owner shall keep or permit to be kept within the corporate limits of the City of Alexandria any fierce, dangerous, or vicious animal other than in accordance with the provision of this section. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section, the following words and terms shall have the following meanings, unless the context shall clearly indicate another or different meaning or intent. 
(1)  Vicious dog means: 
a.  Any dog that, when unprovoked, inflicts bites on or attacks a human being or another animal either on public or private property, or in a vicious, menacing or terrorizing manner, approaches or chases any person in an apparent attitude of attack; or 
b.  Any dog with a known propensity, tendency, or disposition to attack unprovoked, to cause injury or to otherwise endanger the safety of human beings or domestic animals; or 
c.  Any dog which attacks a human being or domestic animal without provocation; or 
d.  Any dog owned or harbored primarily or in part for the purpose of dog fighting or any dog trained for dog fighting. 
e.  Exceptions. A dog may be exempted from this definition if: 
1.  The dog is used by law enforcement for legitimate law enforcement purposes. 
2.  The behavior was directed to a person or another animal who, at the time of the subject behavior: 
i.  Appeared to be committing or attempting to commit a crime or tort upon the premises lawfully occupied by the dog's keeper; or 
ii.  Who was provoking, tormenting abusing or assaulting the dog; or 
iii.  The dog was responding to pain or injury, protecting itself or its offspring or protecting human life within the immediate vicinity of the dog. 
f.  Determination of a vicious dog. After notice of an incident or complaint received by the animal control director, an investigation shall be made and shall include a reasonable opportunity for the owner or keeper to be heard. Thereafter, the animal control director is authorized to make a determination of whether a dog is vicious based on the definition contained herein. The owner shall be notified in writing of the finding and the requisites of this chapter. The owner or keeper shall present sufficient proof of compliance with this chapter within ten (10) days. 
(2)  Enclosure means a fence or structure of a minimum of six (6) feet in height, five (5) feet in width and fifteen (15) feet in length, forming or causing an enclosure suitable to prevent the entry of young children, and suitable to confine a vicious dog in conjunction with other measures which may be taken by the owner or keeper of the animal, such as tethering. Vehicle tow chains are prohibited from use as tethers. Such enclosures shall be securely closed and locked at all times and shall have secure sides and a secure top attached to its sides. In addition to the size of the proper shelter, such shelter shall have three (3) solid sides, a solid roof, a floor raised three (3) inches from the ground and large enough for the animal to enter, turn around, and lie down. Such structures shall further have a secure bottom or floor attached to the sides, or alternatively have the sides embedded no less than twelve (12) inches into the ground. The enclosures shall include adequate shelter and protection from the wind, rain, sun and cold and shall provide adequate exercise space, adequate light and adequate ventilation. A doghouse alone is not adequate in the summer to provide shade. No such animal shall be debarked. 
(3)  Dog officer shall mean any person authorized by the City of Alexandria to enforce the provisions of this section and, without limitation, shall include all members of the Alexandria Police Department and all officers and employees of the Alexandria Animal Control. 
(4)  Impounded means taken into the custody of the City of Alexandria or the Alexandria Animal Control. 
(5)  Person shall mean any legal or natural person, and shall include but not be limited to corporations, firms, partnerships, and other like juridical entities. 
(b)  Requirements for registration and harboring. No vicious dog shall be licensed by the City of Alexandria or have an existing license renewed after the effective date of this section unless the owner or keeper of said vicious dog shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  The owner or keeper shall present to the police department proof that the owner or keeper has procured liability insurance in the amount of at least three hundred thousand dollars($300,000.00) covering any damage or injury which may be caused by said vicious dog during the period for which licensing is sought. Said policy of insurance shall contain a provision requiring that the City of Alexandria is named as an additional insured or such other provisions as will require that the insurer notify the City of Alexandria in writing no less than ten (10) days prior to any cancellation, termination, or expiration of coverage. 
(2)  The owner or keeper shall have the registration number assigned to the vicious dog through the implanting of an ID "chip" under the skin. Any fees for this method shall be borne by said owner or keeper. 
(3)  The owner or keeper of the vicious dog shall display in a prominent place on the premises on which the dog is kept a sign easily readable by members of the general public and fairly intelligible to young children standing without the boundaries of those premises warning that there is a vicious dog on the premises. A similar sign shall also be posted on the pen, kennel, or other structure or enclosure in which the dog is housed or confined. 
(4)  The owner or keeper shall pay an annual registration fee as provided in section 5-21. 
(c)  Impoundment. 
(1)  If the Alexandria Shelter Director cannot with due diligence locate the owner or keeper of a dog that has been seized pursuant to this section, the director shall cause the dog to be impounded for not less than three (3) business days. If after three (3) days, the owner fails to claim the dog, the director shall cause the dog to be humanely destroyed. A non-owner caretaker assumes the responsibility of the owner for this purpose. 
(2)  The director may determine that a dog is dangerous and order the owner to comply with the requirements for keeping dangerous dogs set forth in this section and if the dog is impounded, release the dog to its owner after the owner has paid all fees incurred for the impoundment. If all impoundment fees have not been paid within ten (10) business days after final determination that a dog is dangerous, the director may cause the dog to be humanely destroyed. 
(d)  Control of vicious dogs. All vicious dogs shall be confined in an enclosure which meets the requirements set forth in this section. It shall be unlawful for any owner or keeper to maintain a vicious dog upon any premises which does not have such a locked enclosure. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner or keeper to allow any vicious dog to be outside of the dwelling of the owner or keeper, or outside of the enclosure unless it is necessary for the owner or keeper to obtain veterinary care for the vicious dog, or to sell or give away the vicious dog, or to comply with the commands or directions of the dog officer with respect to the vicious dog, or for the dog to be exercised in accordance with the provisions of the section. Whenever a vicious dog is allowed outside of the owner's or keeper's dwelling or outside of its enclosure, the dog shall be securely muzzled by a muzzling device sufficient to prevent the dog from biting persons or other animals. Such muzzle shall be used only under the conditions delineated in the previous sentence and must not interfere with the dog's breathing or vision. Such muzzle shall be constructed of a material that allows adequate air flow. The dog shall be restrained with a chain having a minimum tensile strength of three hundred (300) pounds and not exceeding three (3) feet in length. Further, the dog shall be kept under the direct control and supervision of its owner or keeper at all times. The owner or keeper must be physically capable of restraining the animal. The requirements of this section for the maintenance of physical control over the dog shall not be satisfied by the mere chaining, roping, leasing, or similar restraining of the animal to inanimate objects such as stakes, trees, posts, buildings, or lines. No person under the age of eighteen (18) shall be in physical control of any vicious dog. 
    The owner or keeper of any dog which, subsequent to the issuance of a license by the City of Alexandria, is found to have exhibited any of the characteristics of viciousness set forth in this section shall: 
(1)  Within thirty (30) days of the finding of viciousness provide an enclosure (as defined herein) for the dog; 
(2)  Within fifteen (15) days of the finding of viciousness, the owner or keeper shall: 
a.  Submit to the police department and/or animal control proof of the liability insurance coverage required hereunder and proof of rabies vaccination; 
b.  Have an ID chip implanted under the dog's skin in accordance with the provisions of this section; 
c.  Display the warning sign or signs required under the provisions of this section; 
d.  Sign the sworn statement required hereunder; and 
e.  Submit to the police department and/or animal control the photographs of the animal as required hereunder. The picture shall be surrendered to the animal control officer before the dog is released. 
    Any dog alleged to have committed a vicious act shall be confined in accordance with law and restrained pending a final determination of the viciousness of the dog as based upon the alleged incident(s). A dog determined to be vicious shall be similarly confined and restrained pending its owner's or keeper's compliance with all provisions of this section. 
(e)  Reporting requirements. The owner or keeper of any dog, whether or not classified as vicious, shall report any attack by his dog upon any human being to the police department within twenty-four (24) hours of said occurrence. Such report shall contain, at minimum: 
(1)  The owner's name and address; 
(2)  The name and license number of the dog; 
(3)  The name and address, if known, of the person attacked; 
(4)  The extent of injuries, if known, inflicted on the person; 
(5)  A description of any property damage caused by the dog; 
(6)  The time and location of the attack; 
(7)  The date on which the dog was last vaccinated against rabies; 
(8)  The name and address of the veterinarian who administered the vaccination; 
(9)  The new address at which a vicious dog will be kept should its owner or keeper move within the corporate limits of the city or out of the corporate limits of Alexandria, or sell, give or transfer the dog to another residence of the City of Alexandria or to another residence outside of the corporate limits of the City of Alexandria; and 
(10)  Unless previously submitted, if the dog is loose or otherwise unconfined, the owner shall, within twenty-four (24) hours of said occurrence, submit to the police department and/or animal control two (2) color photographs of the dog clearly depicting its color, markings, and size. 
    The provisions of this section, other than the reporting requirements above, shall not apply to proprietors of animal hospitals located within the corporate limits of the City of Alexandria or to veterinarians maintaining professional offices or clinics within the corporate limits who keep or maintain dangerous or vicious animals on the professional premises in the usual and normal course of their business, or to zoological gardens, theatrical exhibits, or circuses, provided that such animal hospital, veterinarian, zoological garden, theatrical exhibit, or circus possesses all licenses required by the laws of the City of Alexandria and the State of Louisiana and complies with all other regulations concerning the keeping and maintenance of such animals. 
(f)  Penalties. Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this section shall, for each violation, be fined no less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or be imprisoned in the parish jail for not more than sixty (60) days, or both. Each separate day on which any violation of the provisions of this section is shown to have continued to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 203-2006, § III, 6-20-2006; Ord. No. 393-2006, § I, 11-21-06) 
ARTICLE III. - PET OVER-POPULATION CONTROL 

Sec. 5-30. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article the following words shall have the following meanings ascribed to them: 
(a)  Adopter means a person who is legally competent to enter into a contract and who is adopting or buying a dog or cat from a releasing agency. 
(b)  Adult animal means any dog or cat that has reached the age of one hundred eighty (180) days or six (6) months or more. 
(c)  Releasing agency means the Alexandria Animal Shelter. 
(d)  Sterilization means the surgical removal of reproductive organs of a dog or cat in order to render the animal unable to reproduce. 
(Ord. No. 33-1992, § 1, 2-4-92) 
Sec. 5-31. - Sterilization required. 
    All animals sold and or adopted from the Alexandria Animal Shelter shall be sterilized by a Louisiana licensed veterinarian except as otherwise provided by this article. Procedure shall consist of written agreement as provided in La. R.S. 3:2472, 1990. 
    Confirmation of sterilization of released, sold or adopted animals shall be made to the Alexandria Animal Shelter within the prescribed time or the animal may be seized from the owner at no cost to the city. 
(Ord. No. 33-1992, § 1, 2-4-92) 
Sec. 5-32. - Fees. 
(a)  Adoption fees for animals to be sterilized are set as follows: 
Adoption fee ..... $10.00 
Boarding fee, per diem ..... 6.00 
Rabies vaccination ..... 9.00 
Sterilization Fee: 
Male cat ..... 50.00 
Female cat ..... 55.00 
Male dog ..... 65.00 
Female dog ..... 75.00 
All fees shall be paid the animal shelter prior to release of any animal. 
(b)  Waiver of sterilization fee. The sterilization requirements may be waived by an adopter who executes a written agreement obligating the adopter to care for the adopted animal and all of its offspring. The waiver fee shall be set at one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) and paid to the shelter prior to release of the animal. 
(Ord. No. 33-1992, § 1, 2-4-92) 
Sec. 5-33. - Dog-breeding yards prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to house more than five (5) dogs or any number for sale as determined by animal control in the yard of a residential area of the City of Alexandria for the purpose of breeding said dogs for resale unless licensed to do so pursuant to section 10-20 of this Code. 
    Any persons and/or firms found in violation of the provisions of this Code shall for each violation be fined no less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or be imprisoned for not more than sixty (60) days or both. Each separate day on which any violation of the provisions of this Code is shown to have continued to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 203-2006, § IV, 6-20-2006) 
Chapter 7 - BUILDINGS, CONSTRUCTION, RELATED ACTIVITIES[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1. - Fire districts. 
    Pursuant to Chapter III of the building code providing for the establishment of two (2) fire districts or zones, there is hereby established Fire District No. 1 and Fire District No. 2 of the city, the boundaries of which shall be as follows: 
Fire District No. 1. Begin at the intersection of Elliott Street and Red River and run in a southerly direction to Sixth Street; thence in a westerly direction along Sixth Street to Beauregard Street; thence in a southerly direction along Beauregard Street to Tenth Street; thence in a westerly direction along Tenth Street to Washington Street; thence in a southerly direction along Washington Street to Sixteenth Street; thence in a westerly direction along Sixteenth Street extended to McGinnis Street; thence in a northerly direction along McGinnis Street extended to St. James Street; thence in a northerly direction along St. James Street to Fifth Street; thence in a westerly direction along Fifth Street to Winn Street; thence in a northerly direction along Winn Street to Red River; thence along Red River to Elliott Street, the point of beginning. 
Fire District No. 2. Begin at the intersection of Monroe and Sixteenth Streets and run in a westerly direction along Sixteenth Street to the intersection of its extension with McGinnis Street; thence in a southwesterly direction along Mason Street to Turner Street; thence in a southeasterly direction along Turner Street to a point two hundred (200) feet beyond Lee Street measured perpendicularly; thence in a northeasterly direction parallel to Lee Street to intersect with a line two hundred (200) feet south of Bolton Avenue and parallel thereto; thence in an easterly direction two hundred (200) feet south of Bolton Avenue and parallel thereto to Monroe Street; thence in a northerly direction along Monroe Street to the point of beginning. 
(Code 1956, § 7-1) 
Sec. 7-2. - Uniform Construction Code adopted. 
    Effective January 1, 2007, pursuant to R.S. 40:1730.21 et seq., the Louisiana State Uniform Construction Code is hereby adopted, for the purpose of regulating construction, alterations, repair, equipment, use and occupancy and maintenance of every building or structure or any appurtenance connected or attached to such buildings or structures, excluding farm structures and recreational camps. The Louisiana State Uniform Construction Code (LSUCC) is incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein and shall be enforced within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 438-2006, § I, 12-22-2006) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 438-2006, § I, adopted Dec. 22, 2006, amended § 7-2 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to the adoption of the International Building Code and derived from Code 1956, § 7-2, as subsequently amended. 
Sec. 7-3. - Same-Severability. 
    If any provision of LSUCC is held invalid, such invalidity shall not effect other provisions, items or applications of the LSUCC as adopted herein, which can be given effect without the invalid provisions, items or application, and to this end the provisions of this code are hereby declared severable. 
(Ord. No. 29-1978, § 1, 2-21-78; Ord. No. 175-2005, §§ I, II, 6-21-05; Ord. No. 438-2006, § I, 12-22-2006) 
Sec. 7-4. - Same-Penalty for violation. 
    Anyone who violates the provisions of the code as adopted and amended herein shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code of Ordinances. The conviction for such violation on any occasion shall not prevent prosecution for subsequent violations and each day that the code as adopted and amended herein is violated shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 29-1978, § 1, 12-21-78; Ord. No. 175-2005, §§ I, II, 6-21-05; Ord. No. 438-2006, § I, 12-22-2006) 
Sec. 7-5. - Same-Enforcement by injunction. 
    There is reserved to the city the right to proceed to enforce the provisions of the code as adopted and amended herein by injunction and the conviction for violating its terms shall not in any manner affect or interfere with the right of the city in a civil proceeding to enforce the building code and its regulations or enjoin the violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 29-1978, § 1, 2-21-78; Ord. No. 175-2005, §§ I, II, 6-21-05; Ord. No. 438-2006, § I, 12-22-2006) 
Sec. 7-6. - Same-Adopted by reference. 
    The following codes, including any amendments or revision adopted from time to time by the Louisiana State Uniform Construction Code Council as the Louisiana State Uniform Construction Code are adopted by reference: 
(1)  International Building Code, 2006 Edition, not including Chapter 1-Administration; Chapter 11-Accessibility; Chapter 27-Electrical; and, Chapter 29-Plumbing Systems. The applicable standards referenced in that code are included for regulations of construction within this city. 
(2)  International Existing Building Code, 2006 Edition, not including Chapter 1-Administration, and the standards referenced in that code for regulations of construction within this city. 
(3)  International Residential Code, 2006 Edition, not including Parts I-Administrative, V-Mechanical, VII-Plumbing and VIII-Electrical. The applicable standards referenced in that code are included for regulation of construction within this city. Appendix J. Existing Buildings and Structures, is also included for mandatory regulation. For the purposes of this part, IRC R301.2.1.1 (Design criteria) shall be amended as follows and shall only apply to the International Residential Code, 2006 edition: 
a.  Amendment of R301.2.1.1 (Design criteria). 
b.  Item 6, The American Concrete Institute, Guide to Concrete Masonry Residential Construction in High Winds Areas, shall be added. 
c.  Item 7, Institute for Business and Home Safety, Optional Code-Plus Fortified for Safer Living, shall be added. 
d.  Item 8, Federal Alliance for Safe Homes, Optional Code-Plus Blueprint for Safety, shall be added. 
(4)  International Mechanical Code, 2006 Edition, and the standards referenced in that code for regulation of construction within this city. 
(5)  The Louisiana State Plumbing Code ((Part XIV (Plumbing) of the State Sanitary Code)) as amended by the state health officer acting through the Office of Public Health of the Department of Health and Hospitals. Nothing in this part shall be construed so as to prevent the state health officer for enforcing Part XIV (Plumbing) of the state sanitary code, the enforcement of which is his statutory and regulatory responsibility. 
(6)  International Fuel Gas Code, 2006 Edition, and the standards referenced in that code for regulation of construction within this city. 
(7)  National Electrical Code, 2005 Edition. 
(8)  International Property Maintenance Code, 2006 Edition, and the standards referenced in that code for regulation of construction within this city. 
(9)  International Energy Conservation Code, 2006 Edition, and the standards referenced in that code for regulation of construction within this city. 
(Ord. No. 29-1978, § 1, 2-21-78; Ord. No. 196-1982, 11-23-82; Ord. No. 99-1983, 7-29-83; Ord. No. 121-1983, §§ 1, 2, 8-26-83; Ord. No. 19-1984, § 1, 1-31-84; Ord. No. 119-1986, § 1, 7-1-86; Ord. No. 131-1987, § 1, 6-16-87; Ord. No. 29-1988, § 2, 2-23-88; Ord. No. 142-1988, § 1, 7-12-88; Ord. No. 211-1988, § 1, 9-6-88; Ord. No. 12-1989, § 2, 1-10-89; Ord. No. 175-2005, §§ I, II, 6-21-05; Ord. No. 438-2006, § I, 12-22-2006) 
Sec. 7-7. - Same-Property rehabilitation or demolition. 
(a)  Appeals. Whenever a property owner, or his duly authorized agent or representative is notified that his property is in violation of the 2006 International Property Maintenance Code as adopted by the City of Alexandria, or any rule or regulation adopted pursuant thereto, he may appeal such determination to the herein board of adjustment and appeals, but such appeal shall be in accordance with the provisions of section 28-6.7. 
(b)  Special rehab permits. No regular building permit issued in accordance with sections 7-14 and 28-6.5 shall be issued by the building official or his representative for repairs or condemnation while any property is under active official review, as defined by the 2006 International Property Maintenance Code as adopted by the City of Alexandria. A special permit may be obtained after the property is under active official review for demolition. Said permit may be issued by the city within thirty (30) days after initial notification to the property owner that the property is under administrative review. 
(c)  Special time limitation. The special permits listed in subsection (b) shall be obtained within thirty (30) days after the date of the certified letter issued by building official or his designated representative notifying the property owner or his agent or representative of the deficiencies of the property. The expiration of said permits shall be ninety (90) days from the date of issuance for the special building permit, and thirty (30) days for special demolition permit. The building official or his designated representative may issue no more than two (2) thirty-day extensions for the special building permit and no more than one (1) thirty-day extension for the special demolition permit. Any further extensions of time must be obtained from the Alexandria City Council. All work must be completed within the time limits thus provided. 
(d)  Time limitations for demolition. In the case of regular demolition permits, work authorized by such demolition permit is to begin immediately, with expiration of said permit to be ninety (90) days after issuance. The building official may issue up to two (2) thirty-day extensions for each permit. 
(e)  Repeal. All subsections of Article IV-Housing Code in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 438-2006, § I, 12-22-2006) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 428-2006, § I, adopted Dec. 22, 2006, amended § 7-7 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to the International Building Code revised sections and derived from Ord. No. 175-2005, §§ I, II, adopted June 21, 2005. 
Sec. 7-8. - Repeal but savings clause. 
    All other ordinances or parts of ordinances related to building codes within the city in conflict herewith are hereby repealed, provided that for building permits issued and in force and in effect prior to January 1, 2007, the ordinances which were in effect prior to January 1, 2007, including codes and standards regulating construction, alterations, repair, equipment, use and occupancy and maintenance of every building or structure or any appurtenance connected or attached to such buildings or structures, shall control and remain effective for such construction, alterations, repair, equipment, use and occupancy and maintenance. 
(Ord. No. 438-2006, § I, 12-22-2006) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 438-2006, § I, adopted Dec. 22, 2006, amended § 7-8 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 175-2005, §§ I, II, adopted June 21, 2005. 
Sec. 7-9. - Various building fees. 
Various permit fees: 
Special rehab permit fee ..... $150.00 
Special demolition permit ..... 100.00 
Demolition permit ..... 50.00 
House moving permit ..... 50.00 
Swimming pool permit ..... 50.00

ARTICLE II. - ELECTRICAL CODE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 7-20. - Electrical inspector-Designated enforcing officer. 
    Administration and enforcement of this article shall be the responsibility of the electrical inspector. Where used in this article electrical inspector shall include the electrical inspector, and assistants to the electrical inspector. 
Sec. 7-21. - Same-Authority, power and duties. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the electrical inspector to inspect all new wiring and construction before the current is turned on; to keep a permanent written report of any variation from the requirements of this article, to require compliance with this article within a reasonable time; to make inspections of the electrical work in any building at the request of the occupant, owner or his authorized agent; to report and cause to be corrected any defects discovered in old work amounting to a serious increase in fire risk; to issue written approval of new work and old work inspected and found to comply with this article; to issue permits for new work; to issue limited permits for the temporary use of current pending final completion and approval of any work; to keep accurate records of all inspections so that the records of any building may be inspected by the owner or occupants thereof; to make such tests as he may deem necessary to ascertain the condition of such wiring or appliances; the electrical inspector shall have the right to remove or compel the removal of any obstructions such as lathe, plastering, fittings, flooring or fixtures which may hinder a full and complete inspection of such wires or apparatus. 
(b)  In the discharge of his official duties, the electrical inspector shall have the right during reasonable hours to enter any building for the purpose of making an inspection or test of the installation of electrical wiring devices or electrical material contained therein, and shall have the authority to cause the turning off of all electrical current, and to cut or disconnect, in case of emergency, any wire where electrical current is dangerous to life or property or may interfere with the work of the fire department of the city. 
(c)  The electrical inspector may at any time inaugurate inspections of all old and new electrical installations for any existing or proposed customer that will be connected or is connected to city electric utilities. If any defective or dangerous installations or defective material is discovered, a notice shall be served on the owner or occupant to have same rectified in accordance with the requirements of this article. On failure of the owner or occupant to comply with such notice within ten (10) days, the electrical inspector shall have the authority to cut off or disconnect the electrical service, which shall not be reconnected until the defects are rectified and a certificate of approval issued to the owner or occupant. 
(d)  When an assistant electrical inspector condemns all or part of any electrical installation, the owner, within five (5) days after receiving notice, may file a petition in writing for a review of such action with the electrical inspector, upon which petition the electrical inspector shall proceed to determine whether or not such electrical installation conforms with this article and he shall make a decision in accordance with his findings. The electrical inspector may request an inspection by the Property Insurance Association of Louisiana and use its report in rendering a decision for such cases. 
(e)  The electrical inspector is hereby authorized to require that all of the provisions, rules and regulations of this article, governing electrical wiring fixtures, installations, etc., are fully complied with and to inspect all electrical work done and performed in the city. 
(Code 1956, § 10-22; Ord. No. 43-2006, § II, 2-7-2006) 
State Law reference- As to such association, see R.S. 22:1405. 
Secs. 7-22-7-25. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSING OF ELECTRICIANS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 184-2013, § 1, adopted October 18, 2013, repealed §§ 7-27-7-39, which pertained to licensing of electricians and derived from the Code of 1956, §§ 10-14, 10-15, 10-17, 10-31, 10-45-10-50; Ord. No. 80-1986, adopted May 6, 1986 and Ord. No. 103-2013, adopted May 28, 2013. 

Sec. 7-26. - Board of electrical examiners-created; composition. 
(a)  There is hereby created a board of electrical examiners of the City of Alexandria, composed of five (5) members, of which the electrical inspector shall be a member and chairman. The remaining four (4) members of the board shall be the director of utilities, or his designee, two (2) qualified electrical contractors and a graduate electrical engineer who is a resident of the city. 
(b)  The members of the board, with the exception of the electrical inspector and the director or his designee, shall be appointed each year by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the city council, to serve for a term of one (1) year from the date of their respective appointments, or until their successors are appointed. 
(Code 1956, § 10-44; Ord. No. 77-2007, 3-13-2007) 
Secs. 7-27-7-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS; INSPECTIONS; APPROVAL 

Sec. 7-46. - Notice and permit required for electrical work. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make alterations or additions in the existing wiring, either inside or outside of any building or enclosure, or to wire same for the placing of any electric lights, motors, heating devices or any apparatus requiring use of electric current or to engage in the business of installing or repairing electric wiring conductors, dynamos, motors or fixtures; erecting, removing, inspecting or maintaining electric signs or other electrical apparatus or material, operating at a differential or potential of fifty (50) volts or more, without first notifying the electrical inspector and securing a permit for such work, and complying with the provisions of this article or other pertinent provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1956, § 10-16; Ord. No. 80-1986, § 1, 5-6-86) 
Cross reference- Permit for secondary metering equipment, § 7-72. 
Sec. 7-47. - Permit or inspection fees-Schedule. 
    The following inspection fees shall be charged for electrical work: 
(a)  Commercial: 
$2.50 per circuit for first 10 circuits. 
$1.00 per circuit for each additional circuit. 
(b)  Residential: 
$1.75 per circuit. 
$3.00 for final inspection. 
(c)  Fees for replacement of service entrance equipment: 
(1)  $4.00 per service up to and including 60 amperes. 
(2)  $5.00 per service up to and including 100 amperes. 
(3)  $6.00 per service up to and including 200 amperes. 
(4)  $7.00 per service up to and including 400 amperes. 
(5)  $9.00 per service up to and including 600 amperes. 
(6)  $18.00 per service over 600 amperes. 
(d)  Miscellaneous: 
(1)  Reserved. 
(2)  $6.00 minimum fee for electric window signs, outline lighting, etc. 
(3)  For all other electrical equipment or apparatus for which no inspection fee has been fixed by this section, a fee of $10.00 per hour will be charged. 
(4)  $15.00 for swimming pools. 
(5)  $3.00 for temporary power services. 
(6)  $6.00 for minimum inspection fee. 
(7)  $10.00 for reinspection fee. 
(Code 1956, § 10-21; Ord. No. 45-1988, § 1, 3-22-88; Ord. No. 224-1990, § 2, 9-25-90) 
Sec. 7-48. - Same-Date due and payable; failure to pay. 
    The permit inspection fees must be paid at the time the permit is issued; and additional fees at the time the amended permit is issued, or if no amended permit, at the time of final inspection. Contractors who fail to pay fees will not be issued permits until such fees are paid. 
(Code 1956, § 10-20) 
Sec. 7-49. - Inspections-Application; progress notices; time; tag of approval or disapproval; procedure when unapproved. 
(a)  Applications for inspections shall give the exact address, by street and number of the premises on which the work is to be done, the date inspection is desired, name of owner or occupant, kind of building, nature of use, name of electrical contractor, and the nature and the extent of such work and the class of wiring. 
(b)  Electrical contractors shall at all times keep the electrical inspector notified of the progress of the work and shall request inspections as the work progresses. 
(c)  Upon receipt of written application requesting inspection, the inspector shall inspect the work or cause the work to be inspected within twenty-four (24) hours after receiving application. Sundays and holidays are not included in this time. 
(d)  After inspecting the electrical wiring or construction covered by any application, the inspector shall leave a tag or report which shall state that the work has been inspected and approved, or that it is not approved and must be held open for correction; and if the wiring or construction is to be held open for inspection, no person shall lathe, ceil or in any manner conceal any wiring or construction until he is informed that such wiring or construction has been finally approved by the inspector. 
(Code 1956, § 10-18) 
Sec. 7-50. - Same-Work to be left uncovered; extensions to old systems; final inspections; issuance of certificate. 
(a)  Electrical contractors shall have all electrical work inspected before such work is covered or concealed. All cabinet and panel board covers or trims shall be left off for final inspection. Any fittings or cover that conceals any wiring or construction, which may hinder the proper inspection of electrical work, shall be removed by the electrical contractor at the request of the electrical inspector. 
(b)  Electrical contractors making extensions or additions to existing electrical system, shall before proceeding with such work ascertain from the electrical inspector whether any of the old work shall be changed or shall be brought up to the requirements of this article. 
(c)  Upon completion and receipt of final inspection papers covering electrical work, the electrical inspector shall make a final inspection, and if such work is found to comply with this article, a certificate of inspection shall be issued stating that the work has been done according to the provisions of this article and the rules governing the class of work to which it belongs. This certificate shall not relieve the electrical contractor of his responsibilities for any defective work that may have been concealed or escaped the notice of the electrical inspector. 
(Code 1956, § 10-19) 
Sec. 7-51. - Interference with wiring system by other than electricians; owner's permission required; exception. 
    It shall be unlawful except as herein provided, for any person erecting any scaffolding, putting up any sign, altering or changing any electrical wiring, repairing, painting or erecting any building or structure, or engaged in any other manner of work, to cut, break or in any manner interfere with the arrangements of any electric wires whatsoever, inside or outside of any building, unless and until the owner of such building or structure, or the contractor engaged in such work, shall notify the electrical inspector in writing of the necessity so to do, at least twenty-four (24) hours before such intended work is begun. It shall, thereupon, be the duty of the electrical inspector to inspect the place where such work is intended to be done, and if satisfied that it is necessary so to do, he shall at once direct the owners of such wires to remove the same, and upon their failure so to do within twenty-four (24) hours thereafter, such wires may be removed by the contractor under the supervision of the electrical inspector. 
(Code 1956, § 10-23) 
Secs. 7-52-7-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - INSTALLATION STANDARDS; APPLIANCES 

Sec. 7-56. - National Electrical Code-Adopted by reference. 
    As set forth by LA R.S. 40:1730.28, the latest edition of the National Electrical Code and each of its sections including any future amendments, as published by the National Fire Protection Association, is hereby adopted and shall constitute the electrical code of the city. 
(Code 1956, § 10-12; Ord. No. 202-1995, § 2, 9-12-95; Ord. No. 157-2009, § II, 6-16-2009) 
Sec. 7-57. - Same-Severability. 
    Each phrase, sentence, paragraph and section of the National Electrical Code herein adopted is hereby declared to be severable and independent, and should any such phrase, sentence, paragraph or section be declared invalid by any court of competent jurisdiction, such declaration shall not affect the operation of the remaining portions thereof. 
(Ord. No. 157-2009, § II, 6-16-2009) 
Sec. 7-58. - Same-Penalty for violation. 
    Anyone who violates the provisions of the National Electrical Code as adopted herein shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code of Ordinances. The conviction for such violation on any occasion shall not prevent prosecution for subsequent violations and each day that the National Electrical Code as adopted and amended herein is violated shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 157-2009, § II, 6-16-2009) 
Sec. 7-59. - Same-Enforcement by injunction. 
    There is reserved to the city the right to proceed to enforce the provisions of the National Electrical Code as adopted herein by injunction and the conviction for violating its terms shall not in any manner affect or interfere with the right of the city in a civil proceeding to enforce the electrical code and its regulations or enjoin the violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 29-1978, § 1, 2-21-78; Ord. No. 157-2009, § II, 6-16-2009) 
Secs. 7-60-7-62. - Reserved. 
Sec. 7-63. - Underground service conductors. 
(a)  All underground service conductors shall be installed in conformity with all applicable National Electrical Code rules and the additional rules as set forth in this section. 
(b)  Underground service conductors shall be run up a pole or poles designated by an authorized representative of the city light and power department to a height not less than six (6) inches above the top conductor of the secondary. 
(c)  Service raceways shall be separated from the face of the pole or poles by standoff brackets constructed of corrosion resistant material, and minimum clearance between the face of the pole and said raceways shall be at least ten (10) inches. 
(d)  Property owners shall have sole responsibility for the installation and maintenance of all underground service conductors. 
(Code 1956, § 10-27; Ord. No. 157-2009, § II, 6-16-2009) 
Secs. 7-64, 7-65. - Reserved. 
Sec. 7-66. - Materials, devices and equipment-Conformity to specified standards for use and sale. 
    All electrical material, devices and all appliances designed for attachment to or installation on any electric current or system shall be of such material, design and construction as to guard against fires or damage to persons and property. Conformity with the standards of the Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc., as indicated by lists of inspected electrical appliances, or with the regulations of the American Insurance Association shall be prima facie evidence that such electrical materials, devices and equipment comply with the requirements of this division. 
(Code 1956, § 10.28; Ord. No. 117-1991, § 2, 6-21-91; Ord. No. 157-2009, § II, 6-16-2009) 
Secs. 7-67, 7-68. - Reserved. 
Sec. 7-69. - Single phase motors. 
    No single phase motor larger than one (1) horsepower will be permitted to operate unless conditions warrant a single phase motor and same must be authorized by the electrical inspector. 
(Code 1956, § 10-38; Ord. No. 157-2009, § II, 6-16-2009) 
Sec. 7-70. - Reserved. 
Sec. 7-71. - Meters and service switches. 
(a)  Installations having two (2) or more meters shall have each meter loop tagged, giving the street or apartment number it serves. Buildings of any description served by more than one (1) meter shall have meters grouped in one common location unless otherwise designated by the electrical inspector. 
(b)  Meters shall be located six and one-half (61/2) feet aboveground on the outside of buildings and other structures, unless otherwise designated by the electrical inspector. 
(c)  The city shall have the right to lock or seal all switches and meters. Permission shall be obtained from the electrical inspection department before breaking said seal or removing meters. Employees of the city utilities division are exempt from this provision while engaged in the performance of their duties. 
(Code 1956, § 10-42; Ord. No. 157-2009, § II, 6-16-2009) 
Cross reference- Installation by city of metering equipment, § 26-79. 
Sec. 7-72. - Secondary metering equipment; permit required for type of meter used. 
    Where a connected load of two hundred (200) amperes or more is to be installed using secondary metering equipment, it shall be the duty of the electrical contractor or other person making such installation to obtain a permit from the electrical inspector covering the type of meter to be installed. 
(Code 1956, § 10-43; Ord. No. 157-2009, § II, 6-16-2009) 
Sec. 7-73. - Illuminated signs-Contractors prohibited from running primary wiring. 
    It shall be unlawful for persons operating under an electrically illuminated sign contractor's certificate to run primary wiring for signs. 
(Code 1956, § 10-30; Ord. No. 157-2009, § II, 6-16-2009) 
Sec. 7-74. - Same-Distance above sidewalk; extension over street. 
    For all electrically illuminated signs there must be at least ten (10) feet from the bottom of the sign to the sidewalk level. No sign shall extend over the street. 
(Code 1956, § 10-32; Ord. No. 157-2009, § II, 6-16-2009) 
Secs. 7-75-7-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GAS CODE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 7-80. - Gas inspector; gas serviceman and foreman-Power and authority. 
(a)  The city gas inspector (and assistants) or in their absence the gas superintendent or in his absence the assistant gas superintendent, are hereby authorized, empowered and directed to supervise all gas piping, appliances, fixtures and apparatus, whether now or hereafter existing, placed in or in any manner connected in any building or tent or residence property in the city and the installation, construction, reconstruction, adjustment and repair thereof and to see that all rules and regulations of the city with respect thereto are properly complied with, and to inspect and to reinspect all such gas piping, appliances, fixtures and apparatus and the installation, construction, adjustment or repair thereof whenever or as often as he shall deem is desirable or necessary, and to do so in order to prevent fires, accidents or injuries to persons or property. 
(b)  The city gas inspector (and assistants), or in their absence the gas superintendent or in his absence the assistant gas superintendent, are authorized, empowered and directed to cause all such gas piping, construction, reconstruction, adjustment and repair thereof to be such as not to cause fire or accidents or injury to life or property and all such gas piping, appliances, fixtures and apparatus now existing or hereafter existing as well as the installation, construction, reconstruction, adjustment and repair thereof, shall be subject to the foregoing inspection and supervision. 
(c)  In addition to the gas inspector (and assistants), or in their absence the gas superintendent or in his absence the assistant gas superintendent, a city gas department serviceman or city gas department foreman is authorized to conduct inspections limited to replaced gas service lines. 
(Code 1956, § 14-2; Ord. No. 147-1990, § 1, 6-19-90) 
Sec. 7-81. - Same-Subject to order and direction of the mayor, subject to confirmation of the city council; right of entry. 
    The city gas inspector (and assistants) shall be subject to the order and direction of the mayor, subject to confirmation of the city council and he is hereby vested with full authority to enter any building, premises or structure, subways or other places, either public or private, in the discharge of his duties and to pass upon and decide any questions arising under the provisions of this article of any ordinances hereafter passed or any rules or regulations already adopted or hereafter adopted by the council of the city relative to any gas piping, appliances, fixtures or apparatus or the installation, construction, reconstruction, adjustment or repair thereof, or relative to the materials used therein, whether the same shall be in the original construction and erection or in any alterations or repairs thereof. 
(Code 1956, § 14-3; Ord. No. 49-1979, § 1, 4-17-79; Ord. No. 147-1990, § 1, 6-19-90) 
Sec. 7-82. - Same-Authority to cut off gas. 
    In the case of gas leaks of any nature, upon order of the gas inspector the gas shall be cut off immediately from the premises, without notice, and likewise the gas inspector may in the interest of the public safety order the gas supplied to any customer cut off immediately without notice. 
(Code 1956, § 14-5.2) 
Sec. 7-83. - Natural gas supplier. 
    The city shall be the sole and exclusive provider of natural gas for all new utility customers located within the corporate limits of the city, where city gas utilities are available. No other entity may provide natural gas to new customers within the city limits without written approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 105-2006, § II, 3-21-2006) 
Secs. 7-84-7-89. - Reserved.
