    A code enforcement officer shall have the duty to enforce the following ordinances adopted by the Alexandria City Council: 
(1)  Chapter 7, Article IV, as amended; 
(2)  Chapter 13. 
(Ord. No. 148-1992, § 2, 6-9-92) 
Sec. 7-182. - Powers. 
    The code enforcement officer shall have the following powers: 
(1)  Inspect private property to determine violations of the various codes promulgated by the City of Alexandria; 
(2)  Cite the property owner and/or tenant for any violations, after inspection; 
(3)  Grant a time delay to the owner of the property to encourage voluntary compliance; 
(4)  Enforce compliance in the Alexandria City Court for any violation which is not cured by voluntary compliance. 
(Ord. No. 148-1992, § 2, 6-9-92) 
Secs. 7-183-7-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - ALARMS 

Sec. 7-191. - Purpose. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to encourage alarm users and alarm businesses to maintain the operational reliability and properly use alarm systems and to reduce or eliminate false alarm dispatch requests. 
(b)  This article governs systems intended to summon police response, provides for penalties for violations, establishes a system of administration, and sets conditions for suspension. 
(Ord. No. 137-1996, § 2, 6-18-96) 
Sec. 7-192. - Definitions. 
    In this article: 
    Alarm administrator means a person or persons designated by the governing authority to administer, control and review alarm applications, permits and alarm dispatch requests. 
    Alarm business means a business, by an individual, partnership, corporation or other entity of selling, leasing, maintaining, servicing, repairing, altering, replacing, moving, installing or monitoring an alarm system in an alarm site. 
    Alarm dispatch request means a notification to the police by the alarm business that an alarm, either manual or automatic, has been activated at a particular alarm site. 
    Alarm review board shall consist of (5) five members as follows: the alarm administrator, the chief or his designee, the city attorney or his designate and two (2) Alexandria-based alarm company members appointed by LBFAA (Louisiana Burglar & Fire Alarm Association), Region III. 
    Alarm site means a single premises or location served by an alarm system or systems. Each tenancy, if served by a separate alarm system in a multitenant building or complex shall be considered a separate alarm site. 
    Alarm system means a device or series of devices, including, but not limited to, systems interconnected with radio frequency signals, which are designed to discourage crime by emitting or transmitting a remote or local audible, visual or electronic signal indicating an alarm condition. "Alarm system" does not include: 
(1)  An alarm installed on a vehicle unless the vehicle is permanently located at a site; or 
(2)  An alarm designed to alert only the inhabitants of a premises that does not have a sounding device which can be heard on the exterior of the alarm site. 
    Alarm user means any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity which uses an alarm system at its alarm site. 
    Chief means the chief of police of the city or any authorized representative. 
    Conversion means the transaction or process by which one alarm business begins monitoring of an alarm system previously monitored by another alarm business. 
    False alarm dispatch means an alarm dispatch request to the police department, when the responding officer finds no evidence of a criminal offense or attempted criminal offense after having completed a timely investigation of the alarm site. An alarm dispatch request which is canceled by the alarm business or the alarm user prior to the time the responding officer reaches the alarm site shall not be considered a false alarm dispatch. 
    Holdup alarm means a silent alarm signal generated by the manual activation of a device intended to signal a robbery in progress. 
    Keypad means a device that allows control of an alarm system by the manual entering of a coded sequence of numbers or letters. 
    Monitoring means the process by which an alarm business receives signals from alarm systems and relays an alarm dispatch request to the city for the purpose of summoning police response to the alarm site. 
    One plus duress alarm means the manual activation of a silent alarm signal by entering at a keypad a code that adds one (1) to the last digit of the normal arm/disarm code (Normal code = 1234, one plus duress code = 1235). 
    Person means an individual, corporation, partnership, association, organization or similar entity. 
    Takeover means the transaction or process by which an alarm user takes over control of an existing alarm system which was previously controlled by another alarm user. 
    Verify means an attempt by the alarm business or its representative to contact the alarm site by telephone or other electronic means, whether or not actual contact with a person is made, before requesting a police dispatch, in an attempt to avoid an unnecessary alarm dispatch request. 
    Voice dialer (automatic dialing device) means a device which is interconnected to a telephone line and is programmed to select a predetermined telephone number and transmit, by voice message or code signal, an emergency message indicating a need for emergency response. 
(Ord. No. 137-1996, § 2, 6-18-96) 
Sec. 7-193. - Registration required; application; fee; transferability; false statements. 
(a)  No commercial alarm user shall operate, or cause to be operated, an alarm system at its alarm site unless such alarm site has been duly registered with the alarm administrator. A separate registration is required for each alarm site. 
(b)  Upon receipt of a completed application form, the alarm administrator shall issue a registration certificate to an applicant unless the applicant has: 
(1)  Failed to pay a fine assessed under section 7-202; or 
(2)  Had an alarm registration for the alarm site suspended and the violation causing the suspension has not been corrected. 
(c)  Each application must include the following information: the name, address, and telephone number of the person who will be responsible for the proper maintenance and operation of the alarm system and payment of fines assessed under this article. 
(d)  An alarm registration certificate cannot be transferred to another person. An alarm user shall inform the alarm administrator of any change that alters any information listed on the permit application within five (5) business days. 
(e)  Information contained in applications shall be held in confidence by all employees or representatives of the city with access to such information. 
(Ord. No. 137-1996, § 2, 6-18-96) 
Sec. 7-194. - Alarm systems in apartment complexes. 
    The owner or property manager of an apartment complex shall register any alarm system operated in a nonresidential area of the apartment complex, including, but not limited to, common tenant areas and office, storage and equipment areas. 
(Ord. No. 137-1996, § 2, 6-18-96) 
Sec. 7-195. - Registration duration and renewal. 
    A commercial registration certificate shall expire one (1) year from the date of issuance, and must be renewed annually by submitting an updated application to the alarm administrator. The alarm administrator shall notify each alarm user of the need to renew thirty (30) days prior to the expiration of their certificate. It is the responsibility of the alarm user to submit an application prior to the certificate expiration date. Failure to renew will be classified as use of a non-registered alarm system and citations and penalties shall be assessed without waiver. 
(Ord. No. 137-1996, § 2, 6-18-96) 
Sec. 7-196. - Proper alarm systems operation and maintenance. 
(a)  An alarm user shall: 
(1)  Maintain the premises and the alarm system in a manner that will minimize or eliminate false alarm dispatches; and 
(2)  Make every reasonable effort to respond or cause a representative to respond to the alarm system's location within one-half (1/2) hour when notified by the city to deactivate a malfunctioning alarm system, to provide access to the premises, or to provide security for the premises; and 
(3)  Not manually activate an alarm for any reason other than an occurrence of an event that the alarm system was intended to report. 
(4)  Not install or use a system with a voice dialer. The use of a voice dialer on an alarm system is prohibited. 
(b)  An alarm user shall adjust the mechanism or cause the mechanism to be adjusted so that an alarm signal audible on the exterior of an alarm site will sound no longer than ten (10) minutes after being activated. 
(Ord. No. 137-1996, § 2, 6-18-96) 
Sec. 7-197. - Monitoring procedures. 
(a)  An alarm business performing monitoring services shall: 
(1)  Report alarm signals by using telephone numbers designated by the alarm administrator; 
(2)  Attempt to verify every alarm signal, except a duress or hold up alarm activation before requesting a police response to an alarm signal. The above does not apply to a system certified by Underwriters Laboratories, Inc.; 
(3)  Communicate alarm dispatch requests to the city in a manner and form determined by the alarm administrator. 
(4)  Communicate verified cancellations of alarm dispatch requests to the city in a manner and form determined by the alarm administrator. 
(5)  Cease communication of a non-verified intrusion alarm signal on any alarm site that has its certificate suspended or that has received a notice of non-police response. 
(b)  The alarm administrator shall: 
(1)  Designate a manner, form and telephone numbers for the communication of alarm dispatch requests; 
(2)  Develop a procedure to accept verified cancellation of alarm dispatch requests. 
(3)  Notify alarm business of alarm sites that have had their certificate suspended or received a notice of non-police response. 
(Ord. No. 137-1996, § 2, 6-18-96) 
Sec. 7-198. - Duties of alarm business. 
(a)  Alarm businesses shall not program alarm systems so that they are capable of sending one plus duress alarms. Alarm businesses may continue to report one plus duress alarms received from alarm systems programmed with this feature prior to December 31, 1997. However, after January 1, 1998, when performing a takeover or conversion an alarm business must remove the one plus duress alarm capability from the alarm system being taken over or converted. 
(b)  Alarm businesses shall not install a device for activating a hold-up alarm which is a single action and/or non-recessed button. 
(Ord. No. 137-1996, § 2, 6-18-96) 
Sec. 7-199. - Alarm system operating instructions. 
    An alarm user shall maintain at each alarm site a set of written operating instructions for each alarm system. 
(Ord. No. 137-1996, § 2, 6-18-96) 
Sec. 7-200. - Alarm dispatch request records. 
(a)  The officer responding to an alarm dispatch request shall record such information as necessary to permit the alarm administrator to maintain records, including, but not limited to the following information: 
(1)  Identification of the alarm site; 
(2)  Arrival time at the alarm site and dispatch received time; 
(3)  Date, and time; 
(4)  Weather conditions; 
(5)  Area and/or sub-area of premises involved; 
(6)  Name of alarm user's representative on premises, if any; 
(7)  Identification of the responsible alarm business; and/or 
(8)  Unable to locate the address. 
(b)  The responding police officer shall indicate on the incident report whether the dispatch was caused by a criminal offense, an attempted criminal offense, or was a false alarm dispatch. 
(c)  In the case of an assumed false alarm dispatch, the responding police officer shall leave notice at the alarm site that the police department has responded to a false alarm dispatch. The notice shall include the following information: 
(1)  The date and time of police response to the false alarm dispatch; 
(2)  The name and badge number of the responding police officer; and 
(3)  A statement urging the alarm user to ensure that the alarm system is properly operated, inspected, and serviced in order to avoid fines. 
(d)  Alarm businesses which perform monitoring services must maintain for a period of at least one (1) year following request for police dispatch to an alarm site, records relating to the dispatch. Records must include the name, address and phone number of the alarm user, the alarm system zone(s) or point(s) activated, the time of request for police dispatch and evidence that an attempt to verify was made to the alarm site prior to the request for police dispatch. The alarm administrator may request copies of such records for individually named alarm users. 
(Ord. No. 137-1996, § 2, 6-18-96) 
Sec. 7-201. - System performance reviews. 
    If there is reason to believe that an alarm system is not being used or maintained in a manner that ensures proper operation and suppresses false alarms, the alarm administrator may require a conference with an alarm user and the alarm business responsible for the repair of the alarm system to review the circumstances of each false alarm. 
(Ord. No. 137-1996, § 2, 6-18-96) 
Sec. 7-202. - Fines. 
(a)  An alarm user or the master permit holder for an apartment complex shall be subject to fines, warnings and suspension or revocation of permit depending on the number of false alarm dispatches emitted from an alarm system within a twelve-month period based upon the following schedule: 
Number of False 
Alarm Dispatches Action Taken 1 On-site written notice and warning letter #1 2 On-site written notice and warning letter #2 3 On-site written notice and $25.00 fine 4-9 On-site written notice and $50.00 fine 10 On-site written notice and suspension or notice of non-police response by certified mail  
(b)  In addition, any person operating an alarm system which is nonregistered, suspended or a notice of non-police response letter has been issued will be subject to a citation and assessment of a one-hundred-dollar ($100.00) fine for each false alarm dispatch, in addition to any other fines. The alarm administrator may waive this additional fine for a nonregistered system if the alarm user applies for registration within ten (10) days after such violation. 
(c)  Senior citizens, sixty-five (65) years or older, or certifiably handicapped citizens, operating a residential alarm shall have a fine waived by the alarm administrator if evidence is found that the activation of the alarm was a result of confusion, panic, or other similar causes linked directly to the user's advanced age. However, in every case, the senior citizen that is an alarm user must cooperate with and agree to receive training on the proper use of the alarm system. Failure to do so will result in the assessment of fines as described above in subsection (a). 
(d)  Alarm dispatch requests, caused by actual criminal offense or with evidence of a criminal attempt, shall not be counted as a false alarm dispatch. 
(e)  The alarm administrator may reinstate a suspended certificate upon receipt of acceptable evidence that the cause has been addressed and appropriate corrective action has been taken as outlined in section 7-206. 
(Ord. No. 137-1996, § 2, 6-18-96) 
Sec. 7-203. - Appeal from fines. 
(a)  An alarm user may appeal assessment of a fine to the alarm review board by filing a written request to the alarm administrator for a hearing, setting forth the reasons for the appeal within ten (10) days after receipt of the fine. The filing of a request for an appeal hearing with the alarm review board stays the assessment of the fine until the alarm review board makes a final decision. 
(b)  The alarm review board shall conduct a formal hearing and consider the evidence by any interested person(s). The board shall make its decision on the basis of the preponderance of evidence presented at the hearing including, but not limited to, evidence that a false alarm dispatch was caused by a defective part that has been repaired or replaced or that an alarm dispatch request was caused by a criminal offense. The board must render a decision within thirty (30) days after the request for an appeal hearing is filed. The board shall affirm, reverse or modify the assessment of the fine. The decision of the board is final as to administrative remedies with the city. 
(Ord. No. 137-1996, § 2, 6-18-96) 
Sec. 7-204. - Suspension or loss of alarm registration certificate. 
(a)  In addition to suspension pursuant to section 7-202, the alarm administrator may suspend an alarm registration certificate if it is determined that: 
(1)  There is a false statement of a material matter in the application for registration; 
(2)  The permit holder has failed to make timely payment of a fine assessed under section 7-202(a); timely payment for purposes of this section shall mean forty-five (45) days from levy; 
(b)  Unless there is separate indication that there is a crime in progress, the chief may refuse police response to an alarm dispatch request at an alarm site for which the alarm registration certificate is suspended or received a notice of non-police response. 
(c)  If the alarm certificate is reinstated pursuant to section 7-206, the alarm administrator may re-suspend the alarm certificate if it is determined that two (2) subsequent false alarm dispatches occur within sixty (60) days after the reinstatement date. 
(Ord. No. 137-1996, § 2, 6-18-96) 
Sec. 7-205. - Appeal from denial, suspension or revocation of a registration certificate. 
(a)  If the alarm administrator denies the issuance or renewal of a permit, or suspends a certificate, he or she shall send written notice of the action and a statement of the right to an appeal, by certified mail, return receipt requested, to both the applicant or alarm user and the alarm business. The applicant or alarm user may appeal the decision of the alarm administrator to the chief by filing a written request for a review setting forth the reasons for the appeal within twenty (20) days after receipt of the notice from the alarm administrator. An alarm business may submit the request for review on behalf of the alarm user. Filing of a request for appeal shall stay the action by the alarm administrator suspending a certificate until the chief has completed his/her review. If a request for appeal is not made within the twenty-day period, the action of the administrator is final. 
(b)  Alarm users shall be entitled to a hearing before the alarm review board if requested within twenty (20) days of receipt of notice of a sustained denial of a certificate by the chief. An alarm business may submit a request for hearing on behalf of an alarm user. 
(c)  The alarm review board shall conduct a formal hearing and consider the evidence by any interested person(s). The board shall make its decision on the basis of a preponderance of the evidence presented at the hearing including, but not limited to, certification that alarm users have been retrained, that a defective part has been repaired or replaced, or that the cause of the false alarm has been otherwise determined and corrected. The board must render a written decision within thirty (30) days after the request for an appeal hearing is filed. The board shall affirm, reverse, or modify the action of the chief. The decision of the board is final as to administrative remedies with the city. 
(Ord. No. 137-1996, § 2, 6-18-96) 
Sec. 7-206. - Reinstatement of certificate. 
    A person whose alarm certificate has been suspended may be issued a new certificate if the person: 
(1)  Submits an updated application; and 
(2)  Pays or otherwise resolves all citations and fines; and 
(3)  Submits a certification from an alarm business, that complies with the requirements of this article, stating that the alarm system has been inspected and repaired (if necessary) by the alarm business. 
(Ord. No. 137-1996, § 2, 6-18-96) 
ARTICLE XI. - PHOTOVOLTAIC SYSTEMS 

Sec. 7-207. - Plan review. 
    A building permit is required for installing photovoltaic ("PV") equipment. To obtain a PV permit the following is required: 
(1)  Provide two (2) complete sets demonstrating all requirements. 
(2)  Submit structural engineer's analysis indicating roof is capable of supporting the load of equipment and the mounting/racking system will withstand a ninety (90) miles per hour wind load. Include manufacturer's calculation for manufactured system. 
(3)  The location of the PV panel system shall be indicated on the plans, including site plan, roof plan, and elevation and mounting details for panel installation. (Roof or ground mounted PV systems.) 
(4)  Submit an electrical plan (riser diagram) showing how the PV system is wired and connected to the building electrical system. Include wire size and type, grounding, over current protection rating and disconnects. 
(5)  Submit a plumbing plan for PV hot water system including pipe size and type, location of exchange tank, existing/backup water heater, and pump. Indicate if heat exchanger coil is in direct contact with potable water. 
(6)  Include adequate fire department access, pathways, and ventilation opportunities. 
(7)  PV permits require a LA licensed electrical and PV contractor. 
(8)  Cut sheet and listing for inverter (DC to AC conversion). 
(9)  Engineer or manufacturer's certification of compliance with IEEE Standard 1547. 
(10)  Note on plans that PV equipment shall be installed in accordance with NFPA 70-690 and posted with applicable warnings, signage and plaques per NFPA 70-705-10, 690-17 and 690-64(b)(5). 
(Ord. No. 132-2012, § II, 6-26-2012) 
Sec. 7-208. - Marking. 
    PV systems shall be marked. Marking is required to provide emergency responders and service personnel with appropriate warning and guidance with respect to working around and isolating the PV electric system. Firefighting procedures require actions that could injure personnel should they come in contact with PV photovoltaic power systems or cut into their circuitry. 
(Ord. No. 132-2012, § II, 6-26-2012) 
Sec. 7-209. - Main service disconnect marking. 
    For residential applications, the marking may be placed within the main service disconnect. If the main service disconnect is operable with the service panel closed, the marking should be placed on the outside cover. 
    For commercial applications, the marking should be placed adjacent to the main service disconnect in a location clearly visible from the location where the lever is operated. 
(Ord. No. 132-2012, § II, 6-26-2012) 
Sec. 7-210. - Marking content and format. 
    Marking content: CAUTION: SOLAR ELECTRIC SYSTEM CONNECTED. 
(1)  Red background; 
(2)  White lettering 
(3)  Minimum 3/8 ? letter height' 
(4)  All capital letters; 
(5)  Arial or similar font, non-bold; 
(6)  Reflective, weather resistant material suitable for the environment (durable adhesive materials may meet this requirement). It is recommended that Underwriters Laboratories Marking and Labeling System 969 (UL969) be used as a standard to determine weather rating; UL listing of markings is not required. 
(Ord. No. 132-2012, § II, 6-26-2012) 
Sec. 7-211. - Marking for conduit, raceways, enclosures, cable assemblies, disconnects and junction boxes. 
    Marking is required on all PV system conduit, raceways, enclosures, cable assemblies, disconnects, and junction boxes. Marking should be placed every ten (10) feet, at turns and above and/or below penetration points. DC combiner and junction boxes shall also be marked. 
(Ord. No. 132-2012, § II, 6-26-2012) 
Sec. 7-212. - Inverters. 
    The inverter is a device used to convert DC electricity from the PV system to AC electricity for use in the building's electrical system or the grid. No markings are required for the inverter. 
(Ord. No. 132-2012, § II, 6-26-2012) 
Sec. 7-213. - Access, pathways and smoke ventilation. 
(a)  Access and spacing requirements should be observed in order to: 
(1)  Ensure access to the roof. 
(2)  Provide pathways to specific areas of the roof. 
(3)  Provide for smoke ventilation opportunities area. 
(4)  Provide emergency egress from the roof. 
(b)  The certified building official may create exceptions to this requirement where access, pathway or ventilation requirements are reduced due to: 
(1)  Proximity and type of adjacent exposures. 
(2)  Alternative access opportunities (as from adjoining roof). 
(3)  Ground level access to the roof area in question. 
(4)  Adequate ventilation opportunities beneath PV array (as with significantly elevated or widely-spaced arrays). 
(5)  Adequate ventilation opportunities afforded by module set back from other rooftop equipment (example: shading or structural constraints may leave significant areas open for ventilation near HVAC equipment). 
(6)  Automatic ventilation device. 
(7)  New technology, methods, or other innovation that ensure adequate fire department access, pathways and ventilation opportunities. Roof access points should be defined as areas where ladders are not placed over opening (i.e., windows or doors) and are located at strong points of building construction and in location where they will not conflict with overhead obstruction (i.e. tree limbs, wires, or signs). 
(Ord. No. 132-2012, § II, 6-26-2012) 
Sec. 7-214. - Access and pathways. 
(a)  Residential buildings with hip roof layouts: Modules should be located in a manner that provides one (1) three-foot wide clear access pathway from the eave to the ridge on each roof slope where modules are located. The access pathway should be located at a structurally strong location on the building (such as a bearing wall). 
(b)  Residential buildings with a single ridge: Modules should be located in a manner that provides two (2) three-foot wide access pathways from the eave to the ridge on each roof slope where modules are located. 
(c)  Hips and valleys: Modules should be located no closer than three (3) feet to hip or a valley if modules are to be placed on both sides of a hip or valley. If the modules are to be located on only one (1) side of a hip or valley that is of equal length then the modules may be placed directly adjacent to the hip or valley. 
(Ord. No. 132-2012, § II, 6-26-2012) 
Sec. 7-215. - Smoke ventilation. 
    For roof mounted systems, the PV modules should be located no higher than three (3) feet below the ridge. 
(Ord. No. 132-2012, § II, 6-26-2012) 
Sec. 7-216. - Commercial buildings and residential housing comprised of three (3) or more units. 
    Exception: If local fire department determines that roof configuration is similar to residential (such as in the case of townhouses, condominiums, or single-family attached buildings), the local fire department may make a determination to apply the residential access, emergency egress, and ventilation requirements. 
(Ord. No. 132-2012, § II, 6-26-2012) 
Sec. 7-217. - Access. 
    There should be a minimum six-foot wide clear perimeter around the edges of the roof. 
    Exception: If either axis of the building is two hundred fifty (250) feet or less, there should be a minimum four-foot wide clear perimeter around the edges of the roof. 
(Ord. No. 132-2012, § II, 6-26-2012) 
Sec. 7-218. - Pathways. 
    Pathways should be established in the design of the PV installation. Pathways should meet the flowing requirements: 
(1)  Should be over structural members. 
(2)  Centerline axis pathways should be provided in both axis [axes] of the roof. Centerline axis pathways should run on structural members or over the next closest structural member nearest to the center lines of the roof. 
(3)  Should be a straight line not less than four (4) feet clear to skylights and/or ventilation hatches. 
(4)  Should be a straight line not less than four (4) feet clear to standpipes. 
(5)  Should provide not less than four (4) feet around roof access hatch with at least one (1) not less than four-foot clear pathway to parapet or roof edge. 
(Ord. No. 132-2012, § II, 6-26-2012) 
Sec. 7-219. - Smoke ventilation. 
(a)  Array should be no greater than one hundred fifty (150) by one hundred fifty (150) feet in distance in either axis. 
(b)  Ventilation option between array sections should be either: 
(1)  A pathway eight (8) feet or greater in width. 
(2)  Four (4) feet or greater in width pathway and bordering on existing roof skylights or ventilation hatches. 
(3)  Four (4) feet or greater in width pathway and bordering four (4) feet by eight (8) feet venting cutouts every twenty (20) feet on alternating sides of the pathway. 
(Ord. No. 132-2012, § II, 6-26-2012) 
Sec. 7-220. - Location of conductors. 
    All photovoltaic source and output circuits operating at maximum system voltages greater than thirty (30) volts shall be installed in a raceway when in readily accessible locations. 
    Conduit runs between sub-array and to DC combiner boxes should use design guidelines that minimize total amount of conduit on the roof by taking the shortest path from the array to the DC combiner box. The DC combiner boxes are to be located such that conduit runs are minimized in the pathways between arrays. 
(Ord. No. 132-2012, § II, 6-26-2012) 
Sec. 7-221. - Installation requirements for PV system. 
(a)  The PV panels shall be bonded together with a copper grounding conductor. All of the PV conductors shall be routed together. The ground conductor bonds to the disconnect and then goes to an eight-foot copper clad ground rod. The ground rod shall be at least six (6) feet distance from the main service grounding rod and shall be bonded with #6 copper to the main service grounding conductor. All grounds for systems such as PV, cable, phone, and security, shall be bonded to the main service ground of the structure. An intersystem bonding termination (IBT) device shall be installed at the existing service ground to accommodate all system ground bonds. 
(b)  The disconnect for the PV system should be within sight of the main service meter and located as close as possible. 
(c)  All conductors coming from the PV system on the roof shall be in an approved sunlight resistant raceway where exposed. 
(d)  All conduits containing PV DC conductors shall be labeled to identify a PV system raceway. Disconnects shall have labels that are clearly visible and indicate they are for a second source power supply. 
(e)  Disconnects shall have the proper ground bar, bonding screw and lug kit to ensure only one (1) conductor per lug. 
(f)  The conductors from the disconnect to the main service panel shall be protected and terminate on the proper common-trip two-pole circuit breaker. Single-pole breakers shall not be used on two hundred forty (240) volt system. The two-pole circuit breaker shall be clearly marked in the main service panel to identify a PV system power source. 
(g)  No PV system components shall be installed where it violates any working space clearance codes, utility guidelines or all equipment that must be serviced. 
(h)  All conductors shall be copper and listed for ninety (90) degree Celsius and wet location. 
(i)  DC systems where the inverter is located away from the DC modules shall have an approved disconnect on the DC side as well as the AC side of the inverter. 
(j)  Any conductors that carry DC voltage shall be installed in a metal raceway or enclosure. 
(Ord. No. 132-2012, § II, 6-26-2012) 
Sec. 7-222. - Nonhabitable buildings. 
    This guideline does not apply to nonhabitable structures. Examples of nonhabitable structures include, but are not limited to, parking shade structures, PV trellises, etc. 
(Ord. No. 132-2012, § II, 6-26-2012) 
Sec. 7-223. - Ground mounted photovoltaic arrays. 
    Ground mounted PV systems shall must comply with the following: 
(1)  Meet the requirements of section 7-207 through section 7-222 as applicable. 
(2)  Meet all existing building construction setback requirements. For the purpose of determining conformance to this requirement, all measurements shall be taken from the outer most edge of the array as configured in its permanent orientation to the nearest property line, setback line, or other applicable reference line. 
(3)  Ground mounted PV systems shall not be located on any portion of any residential or commercial lot between the curb line of any bordering street and a projection of the rear of the permanent structure to either side lot line. It is the intent of this requirement that all ground mounted PV systems be located at the rear of any lot. 
(Ord. No. 132-2012, § II, 6-26-2012) 
Sec. 7-224. - PV permit fees. 
    The fees for PV permits shall be computed in the same manner as all other building permits described in this section. 
(Ord. No. 132-2012, § II, 6-26-2012) 
Chapter 8 - CIVIL DEFENSE AND EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Emergency interim successors, R.S. 33:1401 et seq. 

Sec. 8-1. - Local organization created. 
    There is hereby created a local organization for civil defense and emergency preparedness, pursuant to the provisions of R.S. 29:608 and 29:709, A. 
(Code 1956, § 9-1) 
Sec. 8-2. - Director-Appointment; execution of rules and regulations of state agency. 
    The local organization for civil defense and emergency preparedness shall have a director who shall be appointed by the governing body on the recommendation of the mayor, and commissioned as required by statute, and who shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration and operation of such local organization, subject to the direction and control of the governing body under the general direction and control of the governor and the state civil defense and emergency preparedness agency. 
    The director shall execute and enforce such orders, rules and regulations as may be made by the governor under the state civil defense and emergency preparedness agency. 
(Code 1956, § 9-2) 
State Law reference- Commissioning of director, R.S. 29:709, I. 
Sec. 8-3. - Same-Authority to accept federal and state aid. 
    When the federal or state government or any agency or officer thereof shall offer this political subdivision service, equipment, supplies, materials or funds by way of gift, grant or loan for purposes of civil defense and emergency preparedness, the director, with the consent of this governing body, may accept such offer and is authorized to receive such aid and assistance. 
(Code 1956, § 9-3) 
Sec. 8-4. - Same-Preparation and execution of plan for city. 
    The director is authorized and directed to prepare a detailed plan for civil defense and emergency preparedness operations in the city and to recruit and train personnel in accordance with the plan to the end that when disaster strikes, each member of this local organization will know his part and his duty. 
(Code 1956, § 9-4) 
Sec. 8-5. - Same-Authority to use city equipment, etc.; cooperation of city departments and agencies. 
    The director is hereby authorized to utilize the services, equipment, supplies and facilities of existing departments, offices and agencies of the city to the maximum extent practicable and the officers and personnel of all such departments and agencies are directed to cooperate and extend such services and facilities to the mayor and the director upon request. 
(Code 1956, § 9-5) 
Sec. 8-6. - Expense money. 
    There shall be appropriated such sums as the governing body may determine to be necessary for the payment of the expenses of the local organization for civil defense and emergency preparedness. 
(Code 1956, § 9-6) 
Sec. 8-7. - Public shelter managers. 
(a)  Duties. In case of emergency, public shelter managers duly appointed by the director, shall open public shelters, take charge of all stocks of food and water and other supplies stored in said shelter, admit the public according to the city's shelter use plan, and take whatever control measures are necessary for the protection and safety of the occupants. 
(b)  Use of restraint against uncooperative persons; penalty. Shelter managers are authorized to use reasonable restraint against those who refuse to cooperate with the routine of shelter living under emergency conditions. Refusal to carry out the orders of the shelter manager and his appointed staff shall be deemed a misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1956, § 9-7) 
Chapter 9 - DISPOSITION OF ADJUDICATED PROPERTY 

Sec. 9-1. - Adjudicated property-Sale of. 
    The mayor is authorized to execute non-warranty deeds for the sale of property which have been adjudicated to the City of Alexandria when the following conditions have been met: 
(1)  A letter of explanation has been delivered to the prospective purchaser; 
(2)  More than three (3) years has elapsed from the date of recordation of the tax sale deed which adjudicated the property to the City of Alexandria; 
(3)  A written request has been delivered to the property section of the office of the city attorney which contained all of the following information: 
a.  The legal description of the property 
b.  The municipal address of the property 
c.  The name of the owner in whose name the property was sold (adjudicated) and the year of the tax sale(s) 
(4)  A local services agreement with the various taxing authorities within the City of Alexandria has been executed by all of the various taxing authorities. 
(5)  A seventy-five-dollar certified check money order for each piece of property has been delivered to the City of Alexandria. 
(6)  The utility department has determined that the adjudicated property is not needed for public purposes. 
(7)  A sign has been posted on the property indicating that it is surplus and for sell. 
(8)  An appraisal has been obtained and the adjudicated property after the prospective purchaser has deposited with the City of Alexandria by certified funds or money order the cost of the appraisal. 
(9)  The prospective purchaser has been advised of the appraised value, the amount of taxes and public liens on the adjudicated property. 
(10)  An ordinance was introduced to sell the adjudicated property pursuant to R.S. 33:4712. 
(11)  No opposition or higher offer has been received and the city council has passed the ordinance. 
(12)  Within thirty (30) days after the adoption of the ordinance the prospective purchaser has certified in writing that he or his agent has examined the mortgage records, conveyance records and civil suit records of Rapides Parish, Louisiana and has attached to the certification a written list of all names and last known addresses of all owners, mortgagees, and any other person who may have a vested or contingent interest in the adjudicated property. 
(13)  That the prospective purchaser has made a written request to the property section of the office of the city attorney to notify each person as shown on the certification along with the sum of five dollars ($5.00) per notice by mail requested and/or the sum of thirty dollars ($30.00) per notice by publication. 
(14)  Proof of notice to all owners, mortgagees or other person noted on the certification has been filed in the conveyance records of Rapides Parish and a certified copy of the proof of notice has been delivered to the property section of the office of the city attorney. 
(15)  The prospective purchaser has certified in writing to the property section of the office of the city attorney that sixty (60) days as required by R.S. 33:4720.17 has elapsed since notice was made or attempted and the property has not been redeemed. 
(16)  The prospective purchaser has delivered to the City of Alexandria in certified funds the sales price. 
(Ord. No. 17-2004, §§ I, II, 12-9-2004) 
Chapter 10 - FINANCE; TAXATION; PROPERTY[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Charges for use of city facilities, § 26-1; municipal bus rates, § 26-2; charges for extension of water mains, § 24-40 et seq.; city utility fees and charges, Ch. 26. 
State Law reference- Ad valorem tax levy authority, Const. 1974, Art. 6, § 27. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Fiscal year established. 
    The fiscal year for the city is hereby established as May first through April thirtieth. 
(Code 1956, § 2-4) 
Charter reference- Authority to establish, § 5-01. 
Sec. 10-2. - City contracts-Buildings or improvements, provisions for liquidated damages required. 
    In all contracts entered into by the city for the construction of any buildings or other public improvements, wherein it is required that such improvements be completed within a certain specified time, a provision shall be inserted in the contract providing for the payment of liquidated damages in case of the failure of the contractor to complete such building or other public improvements within the time specified by the contract. 
(Code 1956, § 2-7) 
Sec. 10-3. - Same-Purchase or installation of equipment, provision for liquidated damages required. 
    In all contracts entered into by the city for the purchase or installation of any boilers, machinery or other equipment, carrying an efficiency guarantee, a provision shall be inserted in the contract of purchase or installation providing for the payment of liquidated damages should the boilers, machinery or other equipment fail to meet the required guarantee, and the amount of such liquidated damages shall be fixed in such contract of purchase or installation, as well as the method and manner of payment thereof. 
(Code 1956, § 2-8) 
Sec. 10-4. - Same-Bond required of contractor. 
    In all cases where a contract is entered into by and between the city and any contractor or other person for the purchase of any equipment, or for the construction of any public improvements, totaling more than thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00), a bond shall be required for the faithful performance of such contract in the amount of one hundred (100) percent of the contract price unless modified by the city council. Such bond shall be signed by a surety company or insurance company currently on the U.S. Department of the Treasury Financial Management Service list of approved bonding companies, which is published annually in the Federal Register. For any public works project, no surety or insurance company shall write a bond which is in excess of the amount indicated as approved by the U.S. Department of the Treasury Financial Management Service list. In addition, any surety bond written for a public works project shall be written by a surety or insurance company that is currently licensed to do business in the State of Louisiana. 
(Code 1956, § 2-9; Ord. No. 96-1988, § 1, 5-17-88) 
Sec. 10-4.1. - Same-Waiver of bond requirement, when. 
    On public contracts of thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00) or less, a performance bond as required by this section may be waived by the city for a contractor or subcontractor who: 
(1)  Meets the definition or requirements of a "responsible bidder" as set forth in L.S.A. R.S. 38:2216(C-2); 
(2)  Has been operating as the same business for a continuous period of at least three (3) years; 
(3)  Reserved. 
(4)  Provides an irrevocable letter of credit from a commercial bank having offices in the City of Alexandria in an amount not less than the amount of the contract, for the faithful performance of his duties. 
(Ord. No. 96-1988, § 1, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 69-1997, § 1, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 10-5. - Stolen, seized or relinquished property; disposition. 
(a)  The provisions of this section are to apply to all stolen property recovered by the police department and all property lawfully seized or voluntarily relinquished to the Alexandria Police Department. 
(b)  All property described in the subsection (a) of this section shall be disposed of as follows: 
(1)  Contraband shall be delivered to the Ninth Judicial Court, to be disposed of in accordance with the provisions of L.S.A. R.S. 15:41. 
(2)  Noncontraband shall not be disposed of prior to the lapse of six (6) months. If the property has not been claimed by the owner within that time, the police department shall dispose of the property in any manner that the department deems proper; provided, however, that any appropriately usable property shall be given to nonprofit youth facilities. However, no property shall be disposed of until the department has advertised twice within thirty (30) days in the official journal of the City of Alexandria, that the police department has within its possession the property to be disposed of. The advertisement shall describe the property and shall call upon the owner to present himself, prove ownership and pay the accrued storage charges, as well as cost of advertisement. 
(c)  A separate advertisement of each article shall not be required but one general advertisement shall be sufficient to authorize the police department to dispose of the property, it being sufficient that such advertisement give notice of the kind of property being disposed of. 
(d)  In the event that any property is sold, the proceeds shall be immediately transferred to the general fund of the City of Alexandria. 
(e)  The above sections do not apply to abandoned vehicles, appliances, etc., in accordance with L.S.A. R.S. 33:4876 nor does it apply to property owned by the City of Alexandria. 
(Code 1956, § 2-15; Ord. No. 10-1988, § 1, 1-12-88) 
State Law reference- See R.S. 33:4876 as to abandoned vehicles, appliances, etc. 
Sec. 10-6. - City contracts-Utilities. 
    In all contracts entered into by the city for the maintenance and construction of electric transmission distribution facilities, the contractor must be licensed by the State of Louisiana for electrical work (statewide). 
(Ord. No. 188-2005, § II, 7-5-2005) 
Secs. 10-7, 10-8. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-1988, § 2, adopted Jan. 12, 1988, repealed §§ 10-7 and 10-8, which had pertained to notice, redemption, advertisement and proceeds disposition re lost, abandoned, etc., property in the possession of the city. Such sections were derived from the 1956 Code, §§ 2-16-2-18. 
Sec. 10-9. - Transfer by mayor of unencumbered appropriation balances among programs within division, department, office or agency. 
    The following procedure shall be utilized by the mayor in transferring part or all of any unencumbered appropriation balances among programs within a division, department, office or agency as provided in section 5-05(D) of the home rule charter: If the mayor at any time during the fiscal year, transfers part or all of any unencumbered appropriation balance among programs within a division, department, office or agency, or changes any line item reflected in the current budget adopted by the city council, he shall at the time of the transfer immediately notify the city council in writing what line items will be affected by any such change or transfer and the reason therefor. 
(Code 1956, § 2-22; Ord. No. 100-1979, § 1, 7-24-79) 
Sec. 10-10. - Tax on cigarette paper. 
(a)  Pursuant to R.S. 33:2740.25(D)(1) and (2), in addition to ad valorem taxes and any other licenses and excise or sales taxes imposed by the city, there is hereby levied a sales tax of one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50) per pack upon the sale at retail of cigarette papers in the City of Alexandria; said tax to be collected by any store within the city, where goods, wares, merchandise or commodities of any description whatsoever are sold or offered for sale at retail. This tax shall not be levied on cigarette papers packaged with tobacco. 
(b)  The proceeds from the tax levied in subsection (a) shall be dedicated in the following manner: 
(1)  Fifty cents ($0.50) of the tax collected on the sale of each pack of cigarette papers shall be dedicated to the sheriff of the parish to be used solely for the purpose of developing or continuing the Drug Abuse Resistance Education (D.A.R.E.) programs. 
(2)  The remaining one dollar ($1.00) collected on the sale of each pack of cigarette papers shall be used for cooperative endeavors to benefit the youth programs. 
(Ord. No. 378-2004, § 2, 11-9-2004) 
Sec. 10-11. - Fee for copies of public records. 
(a)  A charge of fifteen cents ($0.15) per standard or legal size page will be imposed for all copying of public records done for and/or at the request of all persons other than employees of the city acting in their official capacities. Provided, that the fees imposed under this subsection shall not apply to the copying of records in the course of discovery during litigation by or against the city, except where the volume of such copying is excessive, in which case the fee imposed shall be such as will reimburse the city for its actual expenses incurred in providing such services. 
(b)  For all copying of records or documents other than of standard or legal size, the fee imposed shall be such as will reimburse the city for its actual expenses incurred in providing such services for the individuals described in this section. 
(Ord. No. 14-2006, § II, 1-10-2006) 
Secs. 10-12-10-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OCCUPATIONAL LICENSES, TAXES AND PERMITS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverage license, § 4-30 et seq.; electricians' licenses, § 7-29 et seq.; gas fitters' licenses, § 7-94; plumbers' licenses, § 7-143(104.3); begging permit, § 17-5; junk dealer, pawnbroker and peddler regulations, Ch. 17; transfer truck license, § 25-14; taxicab permit, § 27-23 et seq.; fortunetelling prohibited, § 15-33. 

Sec. 10-20. - Annual license tax levied. 
    There is hereby levied an occupational license tax for the year beginning January 1, 1988, and for each subsequent year, upon each person pursuing and conducting any business, trade, calling, profession, or vocation, within the corporate limits of the city, subject to license under the Louisiana Constitution and laws of this state. 
(Code 1956, § 16-5; Ord. No. 223-1981, § 1, 12-8-81; Ord. No. 134-1987, § 1, 6-18-87) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 134-1987, §§ 1-3, 5, adopted June 18, 1987, enacted provisions concerning occupational license taxes, but did not specify manner of codification; hence, such provisions have been codified as superseding former §§ 10-20-10-23(a), (b), 10-24 and designated as §§ 10-20-10-23. At the city's instruction, former § 10-23(c)-(e) has been retained. Such provisions, pertaining to delinquency penalties, have been designated by the editor as § 10-22.1. Ord. No. 294-1987, § 2, adopted Dec. 29, 1987, amended Ord. No. 134-1987, with provisions concerning an occupational license tax exemption; such provisions have been designated as § 10-24.

Sec. 10-21. - Adoption of state laws by reference. 
    The amount of license tax levied in each case is hereby fixed, determined, ordained to be the same as that fixed, levied, and collectable by the governing authority under, and shall be granted in accordance with the provisions of Louisiana Revised Statutes, Title 47, Sections 341 through 363, inclusive, as amended, and all other applicable laws, all of which for all purposes of this section are made a part hereof by reference as if written herein in extenso. 
(Code 1956, § 16-2; Ord. No. 223-1981, § 1, 12-8-81; Ord. No. 134-1987, § 2, 6-18-87) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 10-20. 
Sec. 10-22. - Audit. 
    In the event the tax collector is furnished the sworn affidavit of the taxpayer's certified public accountant, reflecting the amount of gross revenues of said taxpayer statement, when filed, shall be sufficient to satisfy all documents necessary for audit purposes. In the absence of said affidavit, the tax collector, for the city shall limit audit requests to the following documents: 
    IRS Form #1040 Schedule C, for individual taxpayers; 
    IRS Form #1065, for Partnerships; 
    IRS Form #1120, for Corporations. 
(Code 1956, § 16-3; Ord. No. 223-1981, § 1, 12-8-81; Ord. No. 134-1987, § 5, 6-18-87) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 10-20. 
Sec. 10-22.1. - Penalties for delinquency. 
(a)  All licenses unpaid prior to March 1 of each calendar year for which they are due or, in the case of a new business, unpaid on the date such business is commenced shall be deemed delinquent and subject to the payment of delinquent interest and penalty. 
(b)  All delinquent licenses shall bear a penalty of five (5) percent for each thirty (30) days or a fraction thereof and shall not exceed twenty-five (25) percent of the tax. Interest will be assessed at one (1) percent per month from the due date until paid. In the event the collection of the license fees are referred to an attorney for collection, there shall be an additional assessment of ten (10) percent of the total license tax, penalty and interest due. 
(c)  All delinquent licenses and interest and penalties shall be secured by a first lien and privilege in favor of the City of Alexandria, Louisiana, upon the property, movable and immovable, irrespective of ownership, used in carrying on the business, trade, profession, vocation or calling taxed under this Code of Ordinances; and also on the property, movable and immovable, of the delinquent owning the license, and shall be collected in the manner prescribed by state law. 
(Code 1956, § 16-4; Ord. No. 223-1981, § 1, 12-8-81; Ord. No. 207-1997, § 2, 11-4-97) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 10-20. 
Sec. 10-23. - Peddlers-License fee. 
    All peddlers, defined by Louisiana Revised Statutes, Title 47, Section 342, shall obtain a license costing two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Code 1956, § 16-3; Ord. No. 223-1981, § 1, 12-8-81; Ord. No. 134-1987, § 3, 6-18-87; Ord. No. 284-2003, § II, 9-2-2003) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 10-20. 
Cross reference- Peddlers, solicitors, etc., generally, § 17-1 et seq. 
Sec. 10-24. - Same-License exemption. 
    The occupational license required by section 10-23, to be effective on January 1, 1988, shall not apply to peddlers, hawkers, itinerate vendors, and any person who displays samples, models, goods, wares, or merchandise on a temporary basis, not to exceed three (3) days, for the purpose of securing orders for the retail sale of such goods, wares, or the like kind or quality, either for immediate or future delivery in any publicly owned building including, but not limited to, the Rapides Parish Coliseum and Exhibition Hall; the Alexandria Convention Hall; Farmers Market; Harold Miles Park; or the Beagle Club; nor any hotel or motel when the purpose is for a convention or exhibition. 
(Code 1956, § 16-4; Ord. No. 223-1981, § 1, 12-8-81; Ord. No. 294-1987, § 2, 12-29-87; Ord. No. 191-1991, § 1, 9-24-91) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 10-20. 
Cross reference- Peddlers, solicitors, etc., generally, § 17-1 et seq. 
Sec. 10-25. - Insurance business. 
(a)  There is hereby imposed an annual license tax on every insurer engaged in the city in the business of issuing any form of insurance policy or contract, which may now or hereafter be subject to the payment of any license tax for state purposes, as follows: 
(1)  On any insurer engaged in the business of issuing life or accident or health insurance policies or other forms of contracts or obligations covering such risks, or issuing endowment or annuity policies, or contracts, or other similar forms of contract obligations in consideration of the payment of a premium or other consideration for the issuance of such policies, contracts or obligations, whether such insurer is operating in this city through an agent or other representative or otherwise, ten dollars ($10.00) on gross annual premiums up to two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) and the additional license thereafter shall be seventy dollars ($70.00) on each ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), or fraction thereof, of gross annual premiums in excess of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00); provided, the maximum license on such businesses, payable to the city by any one insurer, shall not exceed twenty-one thousand dollars ($21,000.00). 
(2)  On any insurer, engaged in the business of issuing policies, contracts or other forms of obligations covering the risk of fire, marine, transportation, surety, fidelity, indemnity, guaranty, workmen's compensation, employers' liability, property damage, livestock, vehicle, automatic sprinkler, burglary, or insurance business of any other kind whatsoever in this city, whether such insurer is operating in this city through agents or other representatives or otherwise, the following: 
1st Class: When the gross receipts are not more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) the license shall be forty dollars ($40.00). 
2nd Class: When the gross receipts are more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), and not more than four thousand dollars ($4,000.00), the license shall be sixty dollars ($60.00). 
3rd Class: When the gross receipts are more than four thousand dollars ($4,000.00) and not more than six thousand dollars ($6,000.00), the license shall be eighty dollars ($80.00). 
4th Class: When the gross receipts exceed six thousand dollars ($6,000.00), the additional license thereafter shall be seventy dollars ($70.00) for each ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or fraction thereof, in excess of six thousand dollars ($6,000.00). 
(b)  (1) 
The maximum license tax on such businesses, payable to the city by any insurer, shall be nine thousand dollars ($9,000.00). Provided, that plate glass and steam boiler inspection insurers shall pay only one-third ( 1/3 ) of the above rates provided in subsection (2); and provided further, that the amount of license payable to the city as fixed in this section, shall be one-third ( 1/3 ) of the amount so fixed if the payer shall file a sworn statement with the annual report, showing that at least one-sixth ( 1/6 ) of the total admitted assets of the payer, less assets in an amount equal to the reserves on its policies issued in foreign countries in which it is authorized to do business and which countries require an investment therein as a condition of doing business, is invested and maintained, either in bonds of the state, or in bonds of municipal, school, road or levee district, or other political subdivisions of this state, or in mortgages on property located in this state, or in real property in this state which shall be requisite for the convenient accommodation of the transaction of its own business, or in policy loans, or other loans to residents of this state, or to corporations organized under the laws of this state and domiciled in this state, or in stock of homestead building or loan associations organized under the laws of this state, to the extent such stock is guaranteed or insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation or other federal or state agency. 
(2)  And provided that the total of the city and the parish licenses, if both are levied on any of the businesses defined in this section, shall not together exceed the limitations provided for herein. 
(c)  (1) 
In case of any failure to make a report or to make payment of license tax before June first of any year in which it is due, a penalty of five (5) percent per month shall be added to the amount of tax due and payable to the city along with the tax due. The amount of the penalty assessed shall not be greater than twenty-five (25) percent of the total amount of the tax due. 
(2)  When a payment is more than six (6) months delinquent, the city may send a written recommendation to the commissioner of insurance requesting the commissioner to revoke the authority of the delinquent taxpayer and all of the taxpayer's agents to do business in this state. Upon receiving such a recommendation and finding that the local tax assessment is correct and the insurer was duly notified of the assessment after the payment thereof is delinquent, the commissioner, after due notice to all affected parties and hearing, may revoke the authority of the taxpayer and all the taxpayer's agents to do business in this state. 
(Ord. No. 208-1997, § 2, 11-4-97) 
State Law reference- Authority, R.S. 22:1076. 
Sec. 10-26. - Coin-operated machines-Permit and payment of license required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate in the city any mechanical amusement device of any kind or character or any machine operated with coins unless a permit to do so has first been obtained and the license fee has been paid. 
(Code 1956, § 16-7) 
State Law reference- License tax on coin-vending machines, R.S. 47:353; license tax on coin amusement machines, R.S. 47:375. 
Sec. 10-27. - Same-Permit to be affixed in conspicuous place. 
    It shall be the duty of the person engaged in the business of operating devices or machines of the nature above described to affix on each machine the permit or license granted for the operation thereof and to have same displayed on the machine at all times and fastened or affixed thereto in a conspicuous place where it can be readily seen by anyone making an inspection. 
(Code 1956, § 16-8) 
Sec. 10-28. - Same-Allowing operation without permit affixed, license paid. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner, proprietor or operator of any establishment where such machines are located to permit them to be operated unless and until the license has been paid and the necessary permit obtained and affixed to the machine as above provided. 
(Code 1956, § 16-9) 
Sec. 10-29. - Same-Illegal operation; responsibility. 
    Each day's operation of any such machine or device without the license having been paid and a permit having been obtained, shall constitute a separate offense and both the owner or operator or other person dealing in or having control of such machines, as well as the owner, proprietor or operator of the establishment in which the machines are located shall be equally liable for the violation of sections 10-26 through 10-28. 
(Code 1956, § 16-10) 
Sec. 10-30. - Consumer credit sales, consumer leases or consumer loans. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in making consumer credit sales, consumer leases, or consumer loans within the city, or for persons having an office or place of business in the city, to take assignments of and undertake direct collection of payments from or enforce rights against debtors arising from these sales, leases or loans, without first paying to the city license fees in the amount of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) as provided for in R.S. 9:3564(D), as amended, in addition to a city occupational license, which license shall expire on December thirty-first of the year in which same is issued. 
(Code 1956, § 16-11) 
Sec. 10-31. - Chain store tax-Levied. 
    In addition to ad valorem taxes and any other licenses and excise taxes imposed by the city, there is hereby levied an annual chain store tax for each year upon each person engaged in the business of operating or maintaining, as part of a group or chain, any store within the city, where goods, wares, merchandise or commodities of any description whatsoever are sold or offered for sale at retail under the same general management, supervision, ownership and control, and who are commonly recognized as a member of a chain and as a branch store. 
(Code 1956, § 16-12) 
Sec. 10-32. - Same-Imposition as provided by state law. 
    The annual chain store tax levied herein shall be imposed on those stores operating within the city and shall be based upon the number of stores or merchandise establishments included under the same general management, supervision, ownership and control, whether within the city or not and whether within this state or not; the maximum license for each store or establishment to be in the amounts set forth in R.S. 47:10. 
(Code 1956, § 16-12.1) 
Sec. 10-33. - Same-Report required. 
    Every person engaged in a business affected hereby shall on or before the first day of February of each year render to the city a report containing a true and complete statement showing the number of stores or establishments operated or maintained in the city, the name, location and street address of each store, the total number of such stores whether or not in this state, as of the report date, and such other information as may be required by the city. Whenever a new store is opened which was not included in the aforementioned report, a supplemental report setting forth the required information shall be filed prior to the expiration of thirty (30) days after the date of opening. 
(Code 1956, § 16-12.2) 
Sec. 10-34. - Same-Due date, interest and penalties. 
    Payment of licenses authorized herein shall accompany the report required by section 10-33 and shall become delinquent if not paid when due. Interest and penalties shall be assessed and collected together with all taxes due in the same manner as are other taxes due the city. A separate license shall be issued for each store for which the tax has been paid as herein provided, and it shall be the duty of the licensee to post the license in a conspicuous place in each store. 
(Code 1956, § 16-12.3) 
ARTICLE III. - SMALL AND EMERGING BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 312-2007, § 1, adopted Nov. 6, 2007, amended the title of Art. III to read herein as set out. 

Sec. 10-35. - Legislative findings of fact. 
    The City Council of the City of Alexandria finds: 
(1)  That in prior and recent years, small businesses, including but not limited to minorities and women, were effectively denied the opportunity for full and equal participation in city purchases of goods and commodities; 
(2)  That the opportunity for full and equal participation by such entities is essential in order to promote, obtain, and maintain economic equality for such persons and improve the functioning of our local economy, capitalizing on diversity and creating broader sustainability by expanding industry and business in central Louisiana; 
(3)  That such conditions can be improved by providing the equal opportunity for the development of the business concerns owned by small business persons, minority persons, and women; 
(4)  That such development can be materially advanced through the procurement by the city of articles, equipment, supplies, and materials from such concerns; 
(5)  That such procurements also benefit the city by encouraging the expansion of business, thereby creating jobs and promoting economic opportunities for the citizenry which may not have existed prior to such diverse procurements and service requirements; 
(6)  That if gross statistical disparities exist in Alexandria, this constitutes a legislative finding that specific disparity studies are needed and shall be authorized forthwith to determine proof of a pattern or practice of institutional or actual discrimination in order to substantiate and/or develop a community-based picture; 
(7)  That the city should determine when and under what circumstances special qualifications are required to fill particular needs for full and equal participation in city purchases of goods and commodities and for promotion of job inclusion; 
(8)  That the city finds programming to increase job diversity must follow constitutional circumscriptions and should compare jobs regarding which individuals possess the necessary qualifications in the Alexandria economy to the general population of Alexandria, the State of Louisiana and nationwide; 
(9)  That racial and gender disparity should whenever practicable be based upon comparisons, when considering entry-level positions (positions requiring minimal training), of the racial and gender composition of the relevant population to the general population; 
(10)  That racial and gender disparity should whenever practicable be based upon different comparisons when considering positions requiring special qualifications. These comparisons should address the relevant statistical pool for purposes of demonstrating exclusion of ready, willing, and able minorities or women (the number of minorities or women qualified to undertake the particular task) to the general population of similarly-situated ready, willing, and able persons of the specific population who are not minority or women; 
(11)  That the city shall determine the number of qualified minority businesses and potential job holders within the limited jurisdiction using reliable, generally-accepted disparity and identification testing prior to the city requiring race-conscious goals, but that "aspirational" goals (including race-conscious as a non-predominant factor) and race-neutral means shall be developed with this ordinance. It shall be the policy of the city to ensure, in addition to addressing specifically minorities and women (or disadvantaged or challenged business, opportunity is made available to small business concerns, generally, in the letting of contracts and purchases. At no time until the completion of a disparity study shall any city department or representative exclude any responsive bidder from participation in, deny any person the benefits of, or otherwise discriminate against anyone in connection with, the awarding and performance of any contract or purchase on the basis of race, color, sex, or national origin; 
(12)  That the city shall provide programs and services designed to assist businesses within its jurisdiction or substantially connected to such jurisdiction as defined by this ordinance. The city shall promote programs and services to assist small and disadvantaged business concerns in the development and growth of their businesses, including through incubators or other business growth mechanisms, both private and quasi-public, as the case may be. City departments shall take measures to evaluate and ensure optimum contracting and purchasing opportunities are made available; 
(13)  That the city shall determine in its disparity and identification testing the barriers which may have an adverse impact upon small disadvantaged businesses and their ability to participate in all city-let contracts and purchases. Contractors shall be required to participate in this endeavor and at no time shall they discriminate on the basis of race, color, national origin, or sex in the award and performance of any city-let contract or purchase; and 
(14)  That the city shall implement a plan that will specify these intents through the office of the mayor, workforce development and small business retention (or the mayoral designee for such programming), to specify goals as required by any responsible federal agency for federally funded contracts/purchases and compliance requirements, any state equivalent thereto, together with the city's goals for all city-let contracts/purchases. This plan shall be applicable to the city and its contractors with reference to their subcontracting and supply needs. The city and its contractors and subcontractors will make a good faith effort to meet stated goals. 
(Ord. No. 98-1988, § 1, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 312-2007, § 1, 11-6-07) 
Sec. 10-36. - Title. 
    The provisions within these ordinances shall constitute and be known as the "Small and Emerging Business Development Program" for the City of Alexandria. This program shall encompass several components, including: 
(1)  The "Alexandria Fairness, Equality, Accessibility and Teamwork" Program ("A.F.E.A.T"); 
(2)  The "Alexandria Bonding Assistance" Program ("A.B.A."); and 
(3)  The "Alexandria Financial Intermediary Initiative Program" ("A.F.I.I.") 
(Ord. No. 98-1988, § 1, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 312-2007, § 1, 11-6-07) 
Sec. 10-36.1. - Purpose. 
    The purposes are: 
(1)  To promote the competitive viability of small business, minority, and women business enterprise by providing contract, technical, educational, and management assistance; 
(2)  To promote business ownership by small business persons, minority persons, and women; and 
(3)  To provide for the procurement by the city of articles, equipment, supplies, and materials from business concerns owned by small business persons, minority persons, and women. 
(Ord. No. 98-1988, § 1, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 312-2007, § 1, 11-6-07) 
Sec. 10-37. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context otherwise requires, the following words shall have the following meanings: 
    Business means any person, partnership, firm, company, corporation, or joint-venture, which provides articles, equipment, supplies, and materials to the City of Alexandria. 
    City means the City of Alexandria, Louisiana, and all of its departments, agencies, boards and commissions. 
    Debar means to preclude a business entity from providing goods or services to the city or otherwise engaging in business with the city. 
    Disparity study means a study completed by a professional service provider the purpose of which is to determine whether there is a disparity between the number of qualified small, minority, and women-owned businesses ready, willing, and able to perform a particular service and the number of contractors/vendors actually engaged to perform such services. To determine whether such contracting disparities exist, the city would solicit proposals and qualifications from qualified service providers. A disparity study can, and should, be useful in providing the City of Alexandria with evidence, in accord with the current changes in law and particularly the precedent of the United States Supreme Court in City of Richmond v. J.A. Croson (1989) and Adarand v. Pena (1995), to modify such policies and goals of the City of Alexandria since those landmark decisions and any future ones, to determine whether or not, and to what extent, remedial programs for racial or gender discrimination are appropriate. A disparity study will determine if the City of Alexandria has up-to-date facts for existing and future efforts to increase the use of minority- and women-owned businesses. 
    Dominant in its field of operation means those businesses exercising a controlling or major influence in a business activity in which a number of businesses are engaged. In determining if a business is dominant, the following criteria, among others, shall be considered: number of employees; volume of business; financial resources; competitive status or position; ownership or control of materials, processes, patents, license agreements, and facilities; sales territory; and nature of business activity. 
    Dominant in its field of operation, affiliate or subsidiary of a business means those affiliates or subsidiaries of businesses of which at least twenty (20) percent is owned by a business dominant in that field of operation, or by partners, officers, directors, majority shareholders, or their equivalent of a business dominant in that field of operation. 
    Financial intermediary means a financial intermediary is an institution, firm, or individual who performs some form of intermediation between two (2) or more parties in a financial context, meaning specifically, but not limited to, facilitation of the channeling of funds between lenders and borrowers through indirect means. A lender may lend funds to an intermediary, typically a banking institution, under certain limitations so that the institution, firm, or individual as the case may be can allocate the funds to borrowers under strict guidance and rules. 
    Good faith effort means an honest and genuine attempt to comply with the terms, goals and objectives of this program as provided for in this article and as specifically provided for in each contract for the purchase of goods by the City of Alexandria. 
    Goods and services means personal property of every description and all work, except work performed by full-time employees of the city, performed for the city, excluding construction and work performed by professionals. 
    Joint-venture means an association of two (2) or more persons, companies, corporations, partnerships or any combination thereof, to carry out a single business enterprise for profit, for which purpose they combine their property, money, skills and knowledge. 
    Minority means any individual who is a citizen (or lawfully admitted permanent resident) of the United States and an individual in one (1) or more of the following groups: (1) Black American, (2) Hispanic American, (3) Native American, (4) Asian-Pacific American, and (5) Subcontinent Asian American. 
    Minority, business enterprise or minority owned business means the business shall be at least fifty-one (51) percent owned and controlled in both form and substance by one (1) or more minorities. Only businesses who are independently owned/operated, not dominant in their field of operation, meet the Small Business Administration's definition of a small business concern as determine by the U.S. Small Business Administration's Small Business Size Standards and which are registered by the city will be allowed to participate in and benefit from this program. 
    North American Industry Classification System Codes (NAICS) 2007 means [a system] used by business and government to classify and measure economic activity. NAICS was developed jointly by the U.S., Canada, and Mexico to provide new comparability in statistics about business activity across North America. 
    Person means any person, partnership, firm, corporation, association, limited liability company, joint-venture, or other Louisiana recognized juridical entities. 
    Preference means a technique which gives an advantage in consideration of bids and proposals to those submitted by minority business enterprise or women business enterprise, to the extent allowed by law as such controlling law may be amended or changed as legislated or interpreted by controlling precedent of a final authority. 
    Professional service providers means those persons who provide technical or professional services within the municipal jurisdiction whose services are exempt from the Louisiana Public Works Act or bid laws, such as but not limited to, engineers, accountants, architects, attorneys, security providers, and medical practitioners. 
    Reservation means a technique which limits consideration of bids and proposals to those regulations and requirements as may from time to time be instituted by this article and state law. 
    Significant local presence means a presence such that a substantial amount of business is done within the metropolitan statistical area ("MSA") of Alexandria by: (i) location of a satellite office within the MSA or fifty-mile radius, employing three (3) or more full-time employees in twenty (20) or more calendar weeks per year; or (ii) maintaining a principal business establishment ("PBE") within the MSA or fifty-mile radius; or (iii) real and substantial commitment, represented by cooperative endeavor with the City of Alexandria, to locate a PBE or satellite within the MSA. This presence is also satisfied by having successfully bid on and completed substantial projects in the past, without the aid of the small and emerging business program. 
    Socially or economically disadvantaged person means a person who has been deprived of the opportunity to develop and maintain a competitive position in the economy because of social or economic disadvantage. This disadvantage may arise from cultural, social or economic circumstances or background or physical location.
