    U.S. Small Business Administration's Small Business Size Standards means a table that lists small business size standards matched to industries described in the North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) as modified by the office of management and budget in 2007. The size standards are mostly expressed in either millions of dollars or number of employees. A size standard is the largest that a for-profit concern can be and still qualify as a small business. 
    Women business enterprise or women owned business means a small business that is at least fifty-one (51) percent owned by a woman or women who also control and operate it. "Control" in this context means exercising the power to make policy decisions. "Operate" in this context means being actively involved in the day-to-day management. In determining whether a business is fifty-one (51) percent owned by a woman or women, the percent ownership of the woman or women shall not be diminished because she is part of a community property regime. 
(Ord. No. 98-1988, § 1, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 312-2007, § 1, 11-6-07) 
Sec. 10-38. - Small business development program. 
    There is hereby established a small business development program for the city. This program and its components shall be administered by the director of finance who shall report directly to the mayor or his designee. The program shall have the following three (3) components: 
(1)  Alexandria Bonding Assistance Program. The city establishes a small business bonding assistance program to be administered through the office of the mayor, or his designee, which may with further actions of the city council authorize the mayor to enter into joint service agreements or cooperative efforts with the state or other government agencies and political subdivisions, including but not limited to, the Governor's Office of Economic Development, or any other agency of the state, the parish governing body, other parish offices or agencies, the school board, the state of Louisiana, any special governing districts, or private individuals or firms. 
(2)  Alexandria Financial Intermediary Initiative. The city shall be authorized to promote, facilitate, and aid creation of an intermediary relationship with appropriate and qualified firms or individuals, including mentor and protege programs; to cooperate with state and other agencies, to enter joint service agreements or cooperative efforts with the State of Louisiana, including the Governor's Office of Economic Development, other government agencies and political subdivisions, including but not limited to, the parish governing body, other parish offices or agencies, the school board, any special governing districts, or private individuals or firms all to accomplish incentives and coordination for the benefit of small and emerging businesses and any person or corporation assisting the purposes of this act. 
(3)  Reservations and aspirational goals for the Alexandria Fairness, Equality, Accessibility and Teamwork Program. The city may, after appropriate supportive findings, reserve for small business enterprises, to the extend allowed by law or this article, the dollar value of anticipated city procurement of all goods and services in accordance with the reservation and goal schedule which shall be certified each fiscal year by the director of finance. Appropriate supportive findings shall follow disparity studies, which shall from time to time be used as a prerequisite to validate programmatic modifications. 
    The programming may involve the city's construction of web-based interactivity and informational meetings with local contractors to provide educational, promotional and training opportunities to interested parties willing to participate in the program and its components. 
(Ord. No. 98-1988, § 1, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 312-2007, § 1, 11-6-07) 
Sec. 10-38.1. - Small business development program, bonding assistance (Reserved). 
Sec. 10-38.2. - Small business development program, financial intermediary (Reserved). 
Sec. 10-38.3. - Alexandria Fairness, Equality, Accessibility and Teamwork Program, reservations and preferences; procedures and coordination. 
(a)  Reservations and aspirational goals. In addition to the policy statement of 10-38(3) regarding reservation for small business, the procurement shall be designated or divided into contract award units of economically feasible production runs in order to facilitate orders or bids from small business firms and suppliers. Failure to reserve particular procurements shall not be deemed to prohibit or discourage small businesses from seeking the procurement award through the normal solicitation and bidding process. 
(b)  Preference, minority. To the extent allowed by R.S. 38:2233 and in no event less than ten (10) percent of the value of the procurements designated for the reservation award as set forth above shall be awarded, if possible, to minority business enterprise, or minority-owned businesses. In order to facilitate the award of said procurements through said businesses, if a procurement is designated for reservation as set forth herein, said procurement shall be awarded to a certified minority business enterprise, or minority owned business if said bid is not more than three (3) percent higher than the lowest responsible non-minority business enterprise or minority owned business bidder. The percentage of the value of the procurements designated shall be determined after annualizing the appropriate percentage to reconcile the results with empirical data as shown by disparity impact analysis. Annualization shall be determined at the outset of the program through the director of finance. It shall include a determination of the number of minority businesses ready to perform divided by the total number of business in that industry. 
(c)  Preference, women. To the extent allowed by R.S. 38:2233 and in no event less than ten (10) percent of the value of the procurements designated for reservation award as set forth above shall be awarded, if possible, to women owned business enterprises. In order to facilitate the award of said procurements through said businesses, if a procurement is designated for reservation as set forth herein said procurement shall be awarded to a certified women owned business enterprise, or women owned business if said bid is not more than three (3) percent higher than the lowest responsible non-women business enterprise or women owned business bidder. The percentage of the value of the procurements designated shall be determined after annualizing the appropriate percentage to reconcile the results with empirical data as shown by disparity impact analysis. Annualization shall be determined at the outset of the program through the director of finance. It shall include a determination of the number of minority or women-owned businesses ready to perform divided by the total number of businesses in that industry. 
(d)  Procedures to ensure equal opportunities to compete. To facilitate participation by small business, minority and women in business enterprise in the procurement of goods and services, the City of Alexandria shall: 
(1)  Establish and maintain a directory to facilitate the identification of small businesses, minority and women owned businesses according to their capabilities; 
(2)  Arrange solicitations within the reservation to better facilitate the participation of small business, minority and women business enterprise; 
(3)  Implement informational programs on opportunities and procedures; 
(4)  Hold pre-bid/pre-proposal conferences to explain the procedure and forms to be used to encourage small business, minority and women owned business enterprise; 
(5)  Provide information and communications on contracting procedures, specifications and requests for proposals to small businesses, minority and women owned businesses in a timely manner; 
(6)  Conduct a city-wide, with regional application, disparity study within six (6) months of time following passage of this ordinance, and then thereafter for updating as often as is needed, but in no event any more than every five (5) years, upon resolution or ordinance of the governing authority; 
(7)  Increase advertisement and publication methods for bids and procurement of goods and services. This includes but is not limited to: bulletin board posting in community centers, the City of Alexandria's Government Access Channel, the City of Alexandria's website and ethnic owned newspapers; 
(8)  Unbundle construction and large contracts to make them accessible to small business, minority and women owned business enterprises. 
(e)  Coordination of all city departments. All city departments shall appoint a representative to serve as a small business coordinator, which persons shall be supervised on this program by the workforce development and small business retention officer within the mayor's office, or other mayoral designee or assistant. Administration of the program shall be centralized to the director of finance office and will be assisted and monitored at the division director's level. 
    All department heads shall be responsible for assisting in developing, managing, and implementing the program as well as reporting to their division director on at least a monthly basis on the efforts at achieving the goals of this program. 
    All such reporting shall require monthly reports to the workforce development and small business retention officer within the mayor's office, or other mayoral designee or assistant, to include obstacles and impediments to implementation and facility as well as socio-cultural or other problems. 
    The division heads shall also separately report on a quarterly basis those professional service agreements awarded or in place, and shall endeavor to reflect changing demographics within the city. The division heads will individually recommend to the administration an achievable, realistic, and reflective goal for professional service agreements. 
    In order to demonstrate publicly the commitment of the administration, precise demographics and statistics shall be maintained by division heads regarding available professional service providers in each division. 
(Ord. No. 312-2007, § 1, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 10-39. - Small business, minority and women-Participation goals. 
    The yearly goal of the city is to provide opportunities for small business, minority and women to participate in a percent of the anticipated city procurement of all goods and services in accordance with the set-aside and goal schedule as prepared by the director of finance. The set-aside program is a yearly goals program and the city shall examine all procurements to determine the product and quantity to be set aside in order to meet the dollar goal set by the director of finance. 
(Ord. No. 98-1988, § 1, 5-17-88) 
Sec. 10-40. - Same-Business enterprise certification. 
(a)  Certification of eligibility of small business enterprises. Only businesses which are certified by the City of Alexandria as small businesses in accord with law and which are registered by the city will be allowed to participate in and benefit from this program. 
(b)  Certification of eligibility of minority/women business enterprises. Only businesses which are owned and controlled in both form and substance by one (1) or more minorities or women shall participate in and benefit from the preference program set forth herein. Each business, or individual, including the minority or women business partner in a joint venture, wishing to participate in the city's program, must be certified by a state-authorized certification process. 
(c)  Affidavit program. The mayor or his designee shall prepare a form of a certification affidavit requiring attestation by the applicant of certain information, including but not limited to attesting to (i) having read all requirements of the program; (ii) providing any additional information requested by the city to document program qualifications; (iii) providing immediate information about certain changes to the business structure or location, ownership, or control; (iv) the truth of all information in the application and that any misrepresentation may result in disqualification; and (v) the legal right of the city to request and obtain any and all tax returns for up to three (3) years. 
(d)  De-certification; appeal; challenge of certification. 
(1)  When the city has reasonable cause to believe that a business with a current certification is ineligible, the director of finance or the purchasing or fiscal agent shall inform the business in writing of its concerns about the eligibility of such business; give the business an opportunity to respond within a reasonable time to those concerns in writing or in person; and provide the business a written explanation of the reasons to de-certify the business. 
(2)  Any person aggrieved by the decision of the director of finance or fiscal or purchasing agent shall have the right to appeal to the mayor or his designee for this purpose within ten (10) days of being notified of the decision. 
(3)  Any person who has good cause to believe that a business with a current certification is a front (engaged in interposition for an entity or person otherwise ineligible) may challenge the certification by providing the director or the fiscal or purchasing agent with information or reasons supporting that belief. The director or the fiscal or purchasing agent shall initiate an investigation if warranted. 
(Ord. No. 98-1988, § 1, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 312-2007, § 1, 11-6-07) 
Sec. 10-41. - Penalties for noncompliance. 
    Upon the determination by the fiscal agent for the city so designated by the mayor, the director of finance, or purchasing agent, or, if appealed, by the mayor or his designee that any person has violated or has failed to comply with any of the provisions of this article, or has falsified any information submitted to the city pursuant to this article, the offending party may be subject to any and all of the following penalties: 
(1)  Debarment of all future bids on any public procurement with the city for a period of one (1) year; 
(2)  Termination of an existing procurement award with the city. 
(Ord. No. 98-1988, § 1, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 312-2007, § 1, 11-6-07) 
Sec. 10-42. - Appeals. 
    Upon the determination by the mayor or his designee that any person has violated or has failed to comply with any of the provisions of this article, the mayor shall notify such person by certified mail setting forth the reasons for said determination. Any person aggrieved by the decision of the mayor shall have the right to appeal to the city council within ten (10) days of the date of receipt of the notification of the decision. Such appeal shall be perfected by a letter addressed to the city council and delivered to the city clerk, stating that an appeal from the decision of the mayor or his designee is desired. The city council shall thereafter hold a hearing on the appeal. All parties shall have the opportunity to present any and all evidence concerning the alleged violation. After public hearing on the appeal, the council may by majority vote sustain, modify, or reverse the findings of the mayor. The aggrieved person shall be entitled to a written determination of the findings or the recommendations of the council before any of the penalties provided for in the previous section are imposed. The findings of the city council shall be final subject to any applicable legal process. 
(Ord. No. 98-1988, § 1, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 312-2007, § 1, 11-6-07) 
Sec. 10-43. - Effective date of provisions concerning set-asides. 
    With respect to those provisions of this article which relate to set-asides, the same shall become effective on May 1, 1989. 
(Ord. No. 98-1988, § 1, 5-17-88) 
Sec. 10-43.1. - Limitations. 
    Nothing herein shall be construed to require reservations for businesses outside of a fifty-mile radius or the MSA, which shall be the municipality's jurisdiction for purposes of this statutory scheme. Such businesses shall be given preference only if possessing a significant local presence. 
(Ord. No. 312-2007, § 1, 11-6-07) 
ARTICLE IV. - CHARITABLE RAFFLES, BINGO AND KENO LICENSING 

Sec. 10-44. - Application. 
(a)  No charitable raffles, bingo or keno, as defined in R.S. 4:701 through 4:739, shall be permitted within the corporate limits of the City of Alexandria, without first having obtained a license. 
(b)  Licenses shall be issued to bona fide veterans, charitable, educational, religious or fraternal organizations, civic and service clubs, domiciled in the city, only after complying with the following rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 144-2004, § II, 5-11-2004) 
Sec. 10-45. - Application for license; fee. 
(a)  Each applicant for such a license shall file with the Rapides Parish Sales Tax Collector a written application therefore in duplicate, containing the information set forth below. The application shall be accompanied by an application fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) which is not refundable. 
(1)  Name and address of the applicant, together with sufficient facts relating to its incorporation and organization to enable the Rapides Parish Sales Tax Collector to determine whether or not it is a bona fide organization or association, including but not limited to the group charter, letter of determination of exempt status from IRS and current membership roster. 
(2)  The names and addresses of its officers. 
(3)  The specific kind of game or games of chance intended to be held, operated and conducted by the applicant. 
(4)  The place or places where, the date or dates and the time or times when, such game or games of chance are intended to be conducted, by the applicant, under the license applied for. 
(5)  The items of expense intended to be incurred or paid in connection with the holding, operating and conducting of such game or games of chance and the names and addresses of the persons to whom, and the purpose for which, they are to be paid. 
(6)  The specific purpose to which the entire net proceeds of such game or games of chance are to be devoted and in what manner. 
(7)  That no commission, salary, compensation, reward, rent, or recompense will be paid to any person for holding, operating or conducting or assisting in the holding, operation or conduct of, such games of chance. 
(8)  A description of all prizes to be offered and given in all such games of chance to be held, operated and conducted under such license. 
(9)  Such other information as shall be prescribed by these rules and regulations and the rules and regulations set forth in R.S. 4:701 through 4:739 and any subsequent amendments. 
(b)  In each application there shall be designated an active member or members of the organization under whom the game or games of chance described in the application are to be held, operated and conducted and to the application shall be appended a statement executed by the applicant and by the member or members, so designated, that he or they will be responsible for the holding, operation and conduct of such game or games of chance in accordance with the terms of the license and the provisions of these rules and regulations governing the holding, operation and conduct of such game or games of chance. 
(Ord. No. 144-2004, § II, 5-11-2004) 
Sec. 10-46. - Investigation of qualifications of applicant; issuance of license. 
(a)  The chief of police of the Alexandria City Police Department and the Rapides Parish Sales Tax shall make an investigation of the qualifications of each applicant and the merits of the application, with due expedition after the filing of the application, and the Rapides Parish Sales Tax Collector shall thereafter determine if the applicant is duly qualified to hold, operate and conduct games of chance under the rules and regulations governing the holding, operation and conduct thereof in the city. 
(b)  The chief and the collector in their investigation shall determine if the member or members of the organization designated in the application to hold, operate or conduct the game or games of chance which the license is applied for are bona fide active members of the organization and persons of good moral character and have never been convicted of a felony and that the games are to be held, operated and conducted in accordance with the provisions of R.S. 4:701 et seq.; and in accordance with the rules and regulations governing the holding, operation and conduct thereof, and that the proceeds thereof are to be disposed of as provided by the aforesaid R.S. 4:701 et seq. Following investigation of the qualifications of the applicant, the sheriff shall make a report of his findings and recommendations to the Rapides Parish Sales Tax Collector who shall be charged with the responsibility of timely authorizing the issuance of a license hereunder. 
(c)  If the applicant complies with all rules and regulations set out in R.S. 4:701 et seq., and if the Rapides Parish Sales Tax Collector is satisfied that no commission, salary, compensation, reward, rent (excluding publicly owned facilities), or recompense whatever will be paid or given to any holding, operation or conduct of any such game of chance, and upon payment of a five dollar ($5.00) fee, it shall issue a license to the applicant for the holding, operation and conduct of the specific kind, or one of the specific kinds, of game of chance applied for accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 144-2004, § II, 5-11-2004) 
Sec. 10-47. - Duration of license. 
    The license for the holding, operation or conduct of any game of chance shall be issued for one calendar year, beginning January 1, and ending December 31. 
(Ord. No. 144-2004, § II, 5-11-2004) 
Sec. 10-48. - Hearing; amendment to license. 
(a)  No application for the issuance of a license shall be refused by the Rapides Parish Sales Tax Collector until after a hearing is held before the city council on due notice to the applicant, at which time the applicant shall be entitled to be heard upon the qualifications of the applicant and the merits of the application. 
(b)  Any license issued under these rules and regulations shall be amended, upon application to the city, if the subject matter of the proposed amendment could lawfully and properly have been included in the original license. 
(Ord. No. 144-2004, § II, 5-11-2004) 
Sec. 10-49. - Form of license. 
    The provisions of R.S. 4:701 et seq., are incorporated herein and made a part hereof by reference and shall be applicable to the form of each license. 
(Ord. No. 144-2004, § II, 5-11-2004) 
Sec. 10-50. - Control and supervision over games. 
    The provision of R.S. 4:701 et seq., are incorporated herein and made a part hereof by reference and shall be applicable to the control and supervision over games. 
(Ord. No. 144-2004, § II, 5-11-2004) 
Sec. 10-51. - Number of games. 
    The number of games of chance per month shall be that set by the provisions of R.S. 4:701 et seq., and its amendments, which is incorporated herein by reference and made a part hereof. 
(Ord. No. 144-2004, § II, 5-11-2004) 
Sec. 10-52. - Persons entitled to hold games; equipment; expenses; commissions or salaries. 
    The provisions of R.S. 4:701 et seq., are incorporated herein and made a part hereof by reference and shall be applicable to persons entitled to hold games, equipment, expenses, commissions or salaries. 
(Ord. No. 144-2004, § II, 5-11-2004) 
Sec. 10-53. - Statement of receipts; expenditures; books and records. 
    The provisions of R.S. 4:701 et seq., are incorporated herein and made a part hereof by reference and shall be applicable to statements of receipts; expenditures; books and records. 
(Ord. No. 144-2004, § II, 5-11-2004) 
Sec. 10-54. - Examination of books and records and personnel. 
    The provisions of R.S. 4:701 et seq., are incorporated herein and made a part hereof by reference and shall be applicable to examination of books and records and personnel. 
(Ord. No. 144-2004, § II, 5-11-2004) 
Sec. 10-55. - Immunity. 
    The provisions of R.S. 4:701 et seq., are incorporated herein and made a part hereof by reference and shall be applicable to immunity. 
(Ord. No. 144-2004, § II, 5-11-2004) 
Sec. 10-56. - Violations. 
    The provisions of R.S. 4:701 et seq., are incorporated herein and made a part hereof by reference and shall be applicable to violations. 
(Ord. No. 144-2004, § II, 5-11-2004) 
Sec. 10-57. - Exemptions. 
    A bona fide senior citizen recreation club, upon application to the Rapides Parish Sales Tax Collector, shall be exempt from licensing and reporting procedures enumerated in sections 10-44 through section 10-45 above. A senior citizen recreation club, for the purpose of these rules and regulations, shall be defined as an organization, which is sanctioned by the local council on aging, composed as a group of persons sixty (60) years of age or older, whose only function is to provide amusement and diversion for its members. 
(Ord. No. 144-2004, § II, 5-11-2004) 
Chapter 11 - FIRE PREVENTION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Fire department, § 4-07. 
Cross reference- Damaging fire alarm boxes, § 15-11; false fire alarms, § 15-12; fire lanes, § 25-106 et seq.; driving over fire hose, § 25-58; operation of vehicle on approach of authorized emergency vehicle, § 25-57; parking near emergency vehicle, § 25-57; authority of firemen as to traffic, § 25-6; tampering with fire hydrant, § 26-26. 
State Law reference- Fire prevention or protection, R.S. 40:1491 et seq. 

Sec. 11-1. - Bureau of fire prevention established. 
    A bureau of fire prevention in the fire department of the city is hereby established which shall be operated under the supervision of the chief of the fire department. He shall designate an officer of the fire department as chief of the bureau of fire prevention and may detail such other members of the fire department as inspectors as shall from time to time be necessary, all subject to the approval of the mayor. 
(Code 1956, § 11-2) 
Sec. 11-2. - Appeal from decision on provisions of code. 
    Whenever the chief of the fire department shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a license or permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the fire prevention code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the decision of the chief of the fire department to the city council, within thirty (30) days from the date of the decision of the appeal. 
(Code 1956, § 11-6) 
Sec. 11-3. - Procedure when permits required for new materials not listed in code. 
    The mayor, the chief of the fire department and the chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall act as a committee to determine and specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or occupancies, which shall require permits, in addition to those now enumerated in the fire prevention code. The chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall post such list in a conspicuous place in this office, and distribute copies thereof to interested persons. 
(Code 1956, § 11-7) 
Sec. 11-4. - Fire prevention code-Adopted by reference. 
    There is hereby adopted for the purposes of prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion, the most current edition of that certain code known as the National Fire Protection Association's Fire Prevention Code and all referenced codes, except such portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified or amended by this chapter, and the same is hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the date on which this section takes effect the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the limits of the city. 
(Code 1956, § 11-1; Ord. No. 46-1977, § 1, 9-20-77; Ord. No. 54-1992, § 1, 3-3-92; Ord. No. 221-2000, §§ I, II, 10-17-2000) 
Charter reference- Authority to adopt by reference, § 2-16. 
Sec. 11-5. - Same-Modification of provisions. 
    The chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall have power to modify any of the provisions of the fire prevention code upon application in writing by the owner or lessee, or his duly authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code, provided that the spirit of the code shall be observed, public safety secured, and substantial justice done. The particulars of such modifications when granted or allowed and the decision of the chief of the bureau of fire prevention thereof shall be entered upon the records of the department and a signed copy shall be furnished the applicant. 
(Code 1956, § 11-5) 
Sec. 11-6. - Same-Penalty for violation of provisions. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the code hereby adopted or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any certificate or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or who shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified on appeal, within the time fixed herein, shall severally for each such violation and noncompliance respectively, be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-8. The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue; and all such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time; and when not otherwise specified, each ten (10) days that prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  The application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
(Code 1956, § 11-8) 
Sec. 11-7. - Districts in which storage of flammable liquids in outside aboveground tanks is prohibited. 
    The limits referred to in the fire prevention code herein adopted in which storage of flammable liquids in outside aboveground tanks is prohibited are those established in section 7-1, creating Fire District No. 1 and Fire District No. 2, and fixing the boundaries of said districts. 
(Code 1956, § 11-3) 
Sec. 11-8. - Districts in which flammable liquid plants and storage of liquefied petroleum gas are prohibited. 
    The limits referred to in the fire prevention code herein adopted in which new bulk plants for flammable liquids are prohibited, and the limits referred to in which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted, are established as all zoning districts, established in section 28-3.1, except E. 
(Code 1956, § 11-4) 
Sec. 11-9. - Fireworks, firecrackers, toy pistols; discharging within city. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge a toy pistol where percussion or powder is used, within the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to explode a firecracker or fireworks of any kind within the city; provided, however, this subsection shall not apply to pyrotechnic displays, referred to in the fire prevention code herein adopted, authorized in writing by the mayor. 
(Code 1956, § 18-24) 
Cross reference- Article 13 of the fire prevention code restricts the manufacture, sale, discharge or possession of fireworks within the municipality. 
State Law reference- Discharging or selling fireworks and toy pistols restricted, R.S. 14:311, 14:318, 14:319, 51:650 et seq. 
Chapter 13 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Water and sewers, § 26-20 et seq.; garbage, trash, etc., disposal, § 26-90 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Definitions. 
    The following terms, as used in this chapter, and elsewhere in this Code, shall have the respective meanings given herein: 
    Authorized private receptacle: A litter storage and collection receptacle. 
    Garbage: Putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
    Litter: "Garbage," "refuse" and "rubbish" as defined herein, and all other waste materials which, if thrown or deposited as herein prohibited, tends to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare. 
    Newspaper: Any newspaper of general circulation, and, in addition thereto, shall mean and include any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not less than four (4) issues per year. 
    Park: A park, reservation, playground, beach, recreation center or any other public area in the city, owned or used by the city and devoted to active or passive recreation. 
    Private premises: Any dwelling, house, building or other structure designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule, or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building or other structure. 
    Public place: Any street, sidewalk, boulevard, alley or other public way and any public park, square, space, ground or building. 
    Refuse: All putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes (except body wastes) including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles, discarded or abandoned major appliances such as refrigerators, freezers, ranges or machinery or other metal or other discarded items, and solid and industrial wastes. 
    Rubbish: Nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, metal cans, yard clippings, leaves, tree limbs or branches, grass cuttings or sweepings, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials. 
(Code 1956, § 15-6.1) 
Sec. 13-2. - State Sanitary Code adopted by reference. 
    The Sanitary Code of the State of Louisiana, 1963 Edition, as amended and revised, prepared and promulgated by the Louisiana State Board of Health, insofar as the provisions thereof are applicable to cities in the class of this city, is hereby adopted by reference. Three (3) copies are on file in the office of the city clerk and are adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein. Any person violating the provisions thereof shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
    Said sanitary code shall be cumulative of, and in addition to, the provisions of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1956, § 15-1) 
Charter reference- Authority to adopt by reference, § 2-16. 
State Law reference- Authority to set of standards, R.S. 40:925. 
Sec. 13-3. - Unsanitary premises generally. 
(a)  The owner or tenant of any property or premises in the city, who shall permit the accumulation of garbage, litter, rubbish, refuse, junk, filthy or offensive matter thereon, shall be deemed guilty of maintaining a nuisance. 
(b)  When such a condition exists in the city, the owner, and/or tenant shall be notified by certified mail advising him of the condition of the premises and giving him ten (10) days within which to remove the accumulation of garbage, litter, rubbish, refuse, junk, filthy or offensive matter. 
(c)  If the owner, or tenant fails to comply with the notice within ten (10) days, the city through the office of the city attorney shall be authorized to file a civil action in the Alexandria City Court ordering the owner, and/or tenant to appear and show cause, if any he can, why he should not be ordered to remove the accumulation of garbage, litter, rubbish, refuse, junk, filthy or offensive matter from the premises. 
(d)  In the event the court orders the owner, and/or tenant to remove the garbage, litter, rubbish, refuse, junk, filthy or offensive matter from the premises and the owner and/or tenant fails to comply with the orders of the court, upon application of the city, the court shall find the owner and/or tenant in contempt of court and in addition to any other penalties prescribed by the court shall grant to the city a judgement sufficient to defray the actual costs to the city for the removal of the accumulated garbage, litter, rubbish, refuse, junk, filthy or offensive matter. 
(e)  In the event the owner and/or tenant cannot be contacted via certified mail, the city shall remove or cause to be removed, the garbage, litter, rubbish, refuse, junk, filthy or offensive matter from the premises and the city shall charge to the owner and/or tenant the cost, charges, or expenses incurred in the removal which shall not be less than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(f)  All sums collected hereinabove shall be deposited into a special account maintained by the city for the purpose of removing garbage, litter, rubbish, refuse, junk, filthy or offensive matter with the city. 
(Code 1956, § 15-2; Ord. No. 116-1987, § 1, 6-2-1987; Ord. No. 200-2006, § II, 6-20-2006) 
Sec. 13-4. - Weeds and obnoxious growth abatement. 
(a)  The owner and/or tenant of any lot, place or area within the city shall maintain or caused to be maintained that lot, place, or area so that it remains free from any and all deleterious, unhealthful, and/or obnoxious growth of weeds, grass, or vegetation growing, lying, or being in or upon any adjacent sidewalk or upon any lot, place or area within the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any owner and/or tenant of any lot, place, or area within the city, to allow, or to permit any grass, weeds, and/or other obnoxious growth lying, or being in or upon any adjacent sidewalk or upon any lot, place, or area within the city to exceed ten (10) inches in height as measured from soil level. Such cutting and removal shall be done as often as necessary in order to ensure that such lots, places or areas do not constitute a hazard to the health of the citizens of the community. 
(c)  In the event any owner and/or tenant of any lot, place or area within the limits of the city fail to cut, destroy and remove such weeds, grass, or other unhealthy growth or obnoxious matter in the manner required by this article, the city shall cut, destroy, and/or remove the same and the city shall charge to the owner and/or tenant the costs, charges or expenses incurred in the cutting, destruction, or removal of such weeds, grass or other growth as set forth in the schedule of costs listed below. 
SCHEDULE OF COSTS FOR WEEDS AND OBNOXIOUS GROWTH ABATEMENT 
7,500 square feet or less (50 x 150) ..... $ 125.00 
7,501-11,500 square feet (76 x 150) ..... 150.00 
11,501-15,150 square feet (101 x 150) ..... 175.00 
15,151 square feet-one (1) acre (43,560 square feet) ..... 200.00 
Parcels over one (1) acre ..... 250.00 × the acreage 
    In cases where the city has to cut, destroy, and/or remove weeds, grass or other unhealthy growth or obnoxious matter from any lot, place, or area, and also remove litter from the same, the owner and/or tenant shall be charged for both the cutting of the lot, place, or area and the removal of the litter. 
    No such work shall be undertaken by the city until the owner of the lot, place or area where the weeds or growth are to be removed, as shown on the last assessment roll of the city, has an opportunity of doing the work himself within at least ten (10) days after notice has been given him by advertisement in the official journal of the city for two (2) consecutive days. The ten-day notice will be published during the month of March of each year. No other notice will be given. 
(Code 1956, § 15-3; Ord. No. 67-1986, § 1, 4-22-1986; Ord. No. 138-1986, § 2, 7-29-1986; Ord. No. 191-1986, § 2, 10-21-1986; Ord. No. 116-1987, § 2, 6-2-1987; Ord. No. 53-1996, § 2, 3-26-1996; Ord. No. 122-1996, § 2, 6-4-1996; Ord. No. 27-2006, § II, 1-24-2006; Ord. No. 200-2006, § II, 6-20-2006) 
State Law reference- Authority, R.S. 33:5062. 
Sec. 13-5. - Property owner's failure to comply with section 13-4; nuisance. 
    In any event any owner and/or tenant of any lot, place or area within the limits of the city fails to cut, destroy and remove such weeds, grass or other unhealthful growth or obnoxious matter in the manner required by section 13-4 hereof, the property owner and/or tenant shall be deemed guilty of maintaining a nuisance, and upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1956, § 15-4, 15-6.15; Ord. No. 78-1979, § 1, 6-12-1979; Ord. No. 10-1980, § 1, 1-8-1980; Ord. No. 74-1980, § 1, 5-13-1980; Ord. No. 179-1983, 10-25-1983; Ord. No. 67-1986, § 1, 4-22-1986; Ord. No. 200-2006, § II, 6-20-2006) 
Cross reference- Removal of vehicles, § 25-130 et seq. 
Sec. 13-6. - Statement of cost and/or expenses to owners. 
    The city shall furnish the owner as shown on the last assessment roll of the municipality, by regular mail a written statement showing the cost or expenses incurred for the work, and the place or property on which the work was done. If the statement is not paid within thirty (30) days thereafter, the amount thereof shall be included in, and form part of the taxes due by the owner of said property, and when collected shall be credited to the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 117-1986, § 1, 7-1-1986; Ord. No. 27-2006, § II, 1-24-2006; Ord. No. 200-2006, § II, 6-20-2006) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 67-1986, § 1, adopted Apr. 22, 1986, provided that former § 13-6 be deleted. Such provisions has pertained to mailing statements of weed abatement expenses to lot owners and including unpaid amounts as property taxes, derived from §§ 15-5, 15-6.15 of the 1956 Code. 
Sec. 13-7. - Litter in public places generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk, gutter, drain, or other public place within the city, except in public receptacles, in authorized private receptacles for collection, or in official city sanitary landfills. 
(Code 1956, §§ 15-6.2, 24-7) 
Cross reference- Attaching posters, etc., to public property, § 22-10. 
State Law reference- Discharge of refuse on highways, R.S. 48:385; discharging on public property, R.S. 32:289. 
Sec. 13-8. - Litter in parks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or deposit litter in any park within the city except in public receptacles and in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of the park or upon any street or other public place. Where public receptacles are not provided, all such litter shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(Code 1956, § 15-6.8) 
Sec. 13-9. - Litter in gutters or drains. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, or cause or allow to be placed, any litter in any gutter or drain in the city. 
(Code 1956, § 13-1) 
Sec. 13-10. - Litter in lakes, fountains, watercourses. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or deposit litter in any fountain, pond, lake, stream, bay or any other body of water in a park or elsewhere in the city. 
(Code 1956, § 15-6.9) 
Sec. 13-11. - Sweeping litter into gutters, etc.; keeping sidewalks clean-Generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the city the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. 
(b)  Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk in front of the property which they own or occupy free of litter. 
(Code 1956, §§ 15-6.4, 15-6.5) 
Sec. 13-12. - Littering of streets and adjacent lands prohibited. 
    No person, firm, or corporation shall intentionally dump, leave or deposit any glass or metallic objects, trash, refuse or garbage on any private property without permission of the owner of said property or on any street, park, or on any land adjacent thereto. Whoever violates provisions of this subsection shall be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) and/or be required to spend at least two (2) hours in one (1) calendar day picking up trash or refuse. The collection of such trash, glass, refuse or garbage shall occur within a reasonable area as designated by the judge. The work penalty shall not be subject to suspension, except in cases of hardship. 
(Code 1956, § 15-6.6; Ord. No. 42-1980, § 1, 3-4-1980) 
Cross reference- Spillage from vehicles, § 25-157. 
Sec. 13-13. - Dropping litter, etc., from aircraft. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in an aircraft to throw out, drop or deposit within the city any litter, handbill or any other object. 
(Code 1956, § 15-6.10) 
Sec. 13-13.1. - Spraying from aircraft. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any aircraft to spray within the boundaries of the City of Alexandria any herbicides, fertilizers, or pesticides without receiving a permit from the office of mayor or his designee. Said permit shall be issued by the office of the mayor upon presentation by the applicant of certificates from the county agent and sanitation officer of Rapides Parish that the proposed spray poses no hazard to human health and safety. 
(b)  The administration shall review the permit application process and present the council with a recommended fee which shall be adopted by the council by resolution basis and shall be adjusted by resolution from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 197-1982, §§ 1, 2, 11-23-1982) 
Sec. 13-14. - Litter on vacant lots. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or deposit litter on any open or vacant private property within the city whether or not owned by such person. 
(Code 1956, § 15-6.13) 
Cross reference- Deposit of refuse, § 26-91. 
Sec. 13-15. - Litter on occupied private property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or deposit litter on any occupied private property within the city, whether or not owned by such person, except that the owner or person in control of private property may maintain authorized private receptacles for collection in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk, or other public place or upon any private property. 
(Code 1956, § 15-6.11) 
Cross reference- Receptacle specifications, § 26-90. 
Sec. 13-16. - Owner to maintain premises free of litter. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or person in control of any private property not to maintain the premises free of litter at all times. 
(Code 1956, § 15-6.12) 
Sec. 13-17. - Placement of litter in receptacles so as to prevent scattering. 
    It shall be unlawful for persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles to do so in a manner so as to allow it to be carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. 
(Code 1956, § 15-6.3) 
Sec. 13-18. - Depositing litter on premises declared nuisance; penalty for same. 
    Any person depositing or throwing litter as hereinabove set out shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and of creating a nuisance and upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1956, § 15-6.14) 
Sec. 13-19. - Spitting or expectorating on sidewalks, other public places. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to spit, or expectorate, upon the sidewalks, or floors of any public buildings, or platforms, or approaches connected with such buildings, to which the general public has access within the city. 
(Code 1956, § 18-37) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, R.S. 40:1121. 
Sec. 13-20. - Urinating or defecating on public property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to urinate or defecate upon the public streets, squares or parks of the city, or in any other public place, or in any building other than in facilities provided specifically for such purpose. 
(Code 1956, § 18-36) 
Sec. 13-21. - Smoking and the use of smokeless tobacco products are prohibited in buildings, facilities and vehicles owned or leased by the city. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  Smoking means the carrying of a lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe, or any other form of tobacco or any other substance that may emit smoke or the inhaling of and exhaling of smoke by a person from any form of lighted tobacco or any other substance that may emit smoke. 
(2)  Smokeless tobacco product means any form of tobacco product or any other substance that does not emit smoke, such products include but are not limited to dip, snuff, chewing tobacco, etc. 
(3)  Facility means any property of the city other than a building or vehicle and includes but is not limited to property owned, occupied or operated by the city or an agency thereof, utilized by the general public for public use, recreation, sport or pleasure, other than the playing area of a city owned golf course, and includes public transportation facilities, parks, playgrounds, the Alexandria Zoological Park, ball fields, swimming pools, community centers, resource centers, and any other city property other than a street, sidewalk or parking area or a designated smoking area. 
(b)  Prohibited acts. Smoking and the use of smokeless tobacco products are prohibited by any person within buildings, facilities or vehicles owned, or leased, occupied or operated by the city or any agency thereof, including public transportation facilities or vehicles, except as provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 88-1003, §§ 1-3, 5-25-1993; Ord. No. 262-1998, § 2, 12-1-1998; Ord. No. 44-2006, § I, 2-7-2006; Ord. No. 344-2006, § II, 10-10-2006) 
Sec. 13-22. - Abandoned or junked motor vehicles declared a nuisance. 
    The accumulation and storage of abandoned, junked, inoperative, dismantled or wrecked vehicles within the city shall be deemed and is hereby declared a public nuisance. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or maintain such a public nuisance by abandoning, wrecking, dismantling, in part or in whole, rendering inoperable or discarding any motor vehicle within the city. Therefore, the presence of these types of vehicles, except as expressly hereinafter permitted, is declared to constitute a public nuisance which may be abated as such in accordance with the provisions of this part. 
(Ord. No. 121-1996, § 2, 6-4-1996; Ord. No. 58-2004, §§ I, II, 2-17-2004; Ord. No. 310-2006, § II. 9-12-2006; Ord. No. 22-2007, § II, 1-16-2007; Ord. No. 163-2007, § II, 6-5-2007) 
Sec. 13-22.1. - Definitions. 
    Abandoned motor vehicle means any motor vehicle that is inoperable and is left unattended on public property for more than three (3) days, or a motor vehicle that has remained illegally on public property for a period of more than three (3) days, or a motor vehicle that has remained on private property without the consent of the owner or person in control of the property for more than three (3) days, or a motor vehicle that has remained on the property of the vehicle owner for more than ten (10) days. 
    Antique vehicle means any motor vehicle twenty-five (25) years or older, which is operable and substantially in its original condition. These vehicles must be registered as antiques and display antique license plates. 
    Junked vehicle means any motor vehicle, the condition of which is one (1) or more of the following: 
(1)  Wrecked; 
(2)  Dismantled; 
(3)  Partially dismantled; 
(4)  Lawfully inoperable on public streets in the provisions of the various statutes and ordinances applicable in this jurisdiction, including but not limited to, La. R.S. 32:1301 et seq. 
    Motor vehicle means any vehicle which is self propelled and designed to travel along the ground, on the water, in the air, and shall include, but not be limited to, automobiles, buses, motor bikes, motorcycles, motor scooters, trucks, tractors, go-carts, golf carts, campers, trailers, airplanes, and boats. 
(Ord. No. 163-2007, § II, 6-5-2007) 
Sec. 13-22.2. - Exceptions. 
    This part shall not apply to: 
(1)  Any motor vehicle which is completely enclosed within a building in a manner that is not otherwise visible from the street or other public or private property; 
(2)  Any motor vehicle in an appropriate storage place or depository maintained at a location where such business is authorized under the comprehensive zoning ordinance and other regulatory ordinances of the city; 
(3)  Any motor vehicle in operable condition specifically adapted or constructed for racing or operation on privately owned dragged strips or raceways; 
(4)  Any antique vehicle retained by the owner for collection purposes, as defined herein, rather than for salvage or for transportation; 
(5)  Any motor vehicle stored as the property of a member of the armed forces of the United States who is on active duty assignment; 
(6)  Any motor vehicle within the custody and control of the city and used for training purposes; pr any vehicle seized pursuant to the Louisiana forfeiture statute or any vehicles designated as surplus. 
(Ord. No. 163-2007, § II, 6-5-2007) 
Sec. 13-22.3. - Administration and enforcement; right to enter onto private property. 
    Except as otherwise provided herein, the provisions of this part shall be administered and enforced by an authorized member of the city police department and/or a code enforcement officer. In the enforcement of this article, such persons charged with the administration and enforcement may enter upon private or public property to examine the vehicle or parts thereof, or to obtain information as to the identity of a vehicle and to remove or cause the removal of a vehicle or parts thereof declared to be a nuisance pursuant to this part. 
(Ord. No. 163-2007, § II, 6-5-2007) 
Sec. 13-22.4. - Right of third person to enter onto private property. 
    When the city has contracted with or granted a permit to any person or persons, such person or persons shall be authorized to enter upon private property or public property to remove or cause the removal of a vehicle or parts thereof declared to be a nuisance pursuant to this part. 
(Ord. No. 163-2007, § II, 6-5-2007) 
Sec. 13-22.5. - Notification of owners. 
(a)  Whenever any public nuisance exists on public property or on an occupied or unoccupied private premises within the city in violation of this section, the enforcement agency shall order the owner of the vehicle, or the occupant of the premises on which such public nuisance exist, to abate or remove said nuisance. Such order shall: 
(1)  Be in writing; 
(2)  Specify the public nuisance and its location; 
(3)  Specify the corrected measures required; 
(4)  Provide for compliance within fifteen (15) days from the service thereof; and 
(5)  Provide for an opportunity of a hearing by written request within seven (7) days of receipt of notice. 
(b)  The order shall be served upon the owner or occupant of the premises by serving him personally or by sending the order by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the address of the premises and the address shown by the department of motor vehicles. 
(c)  Within fifteen (15) days after service of notice, the owner or occupant of the premises or the owner of the vehicle shall abate the nuisance by: 
(1)  Removing the nuisance from the premises, or 
(2)  Commencing repairs to the vehicle sufficient to disqualify the vehicle as an abandoned or junked vehicle. 
(d)  If the owner or occupant of the premises or the owner of the vehicle fails to abate the nuisance within fifteen (15) days or fails to timely request a hearing within seven (7) days of receipt of notice, the enforcing agency may issue a misdemeanor summons to the owner or occupant of the premises and cause the vehicle to be removed from the premises in the same manner as provided by state law and/or local ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 163-2007, § II, 6-5-2007) 
Sec. 13-22.6. - Presumption of notice. 
    For purposes of this section, when the owner of the premises or the owner of the vehicle has been served notice by certified mail as set forth in this part and such certified mail is refused, the owner is deemed to have received notice in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, and the fifteen-day period commences to run on a day of such refusal. 
(Ord. No. 163-2007, § II, 6-5-2007) 
Sec. 13-22.7. - Request for hearing; waiver of rights. 
    If the owner of the premises or owner of the vehicle are not in agreement with the decision of the enforcing authority that the vehicle in question constitutes a nuisance, said premises owner or vehicle owner has the right to request a hearing within seven (7) days after service of the notice as herein provided. Failure to request said hearing within seven (7) days of notice shall be deemed as a waiver of the right to said hearing and the decision of the enforcing authority shall be deemed final and enforceable. The requests for a hearing must be in writing and post-marked within seven (7) days of notice via certified mail to the Office of the Alexandria City Attorney, 915 Third Street, Alexandria, LA 71301. 
(Ord. No. 163-2007, § II, 6-5-2007) 
Sec. 13-22.8. - Hearing panel; time. 
    Any hearing requested by a vehicle owner or the owner of a premises on which an abandoned and/or junked vehicle is located shall be convened before a panel of three (3) persons duly appointed by the mayor of Alexandria. The panel shall consist of one (1) code enforcement employee and two (2) citizens of Alexandria. Neither of the two (2) citizen appointees shall be city employees. Said hearing shall be scheduled and held at a time deemed appropriate by the city. The decision of the panel shall be rendered within seven (7) days of the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 163-2007, § II, 6-5-2007) 
Sec. 13-22.9. - Decision of the hearing panel. 
(a)  If the hearing panel affirms the decision of the enforcing agency that an abandoned and/or junked vehicle constitutes a public nuisance, then the owner of the vehicle or the owner of the premises on which the nuisance is located shall have seven (7) days in which to abate the nuisance. The failure or refusal of the owner to comply with the decision of the hearing panel shall subject the violator to a penalty of a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00); said penalty to be decided and imposed after a contradictory hearing, held after a rule to show cause, in Alexandria City Court. 
(b)  If the vehicle owner or premises owner or the city do not agree with the decision of the hearing panel, then either may file an appeal with the Alexandria City Court within seven (7) days after the decision of the hearing panel. Failure to do so within said seven-day period shall be deemed a waiver of such right, and the decision of the hearing panel shall be deemed final and enforceable. 
(Ord. No. 163-2007, § II, 6-5-2007) 
Sec. 13-22.10. - Seizure and disposition. 
(a)  If the nuisance has not been abated by the owner of the premises and/or owner of the vehicle within fifteen (15) days and no request for hearing has been timely made or the decision of the enforcing authority has been affirmed by the hearing panel and no appeal has been timely filed, the city, through its duly authorized representative, may seize or otherwise hold any abandoned motor vehicle or junked motor vehicle which is found to be in violation of this section. The owner thereof shall be entitled to regain possession of the vehicle upon the payment of such cost as may be incurred by the enforcing authority in connection with said seizure and storage. The cost so fixed shall cover all charges for the removal of the vehicle to a place of holding and/or storage as well as all other cost incurred during the period of holding/storage. 
(b)  If the cost of seizure, removal and/or storage is not paid within ten (10) days after said seizure, the enforcing agency has the authority to dispose of said vehicle by any of the following means to-wit: 
(1)  Cause said motor vehicle to be delivered to salvage or scrap facility and surrendered as scrap to any such facility willing to accept same. 
(2)  Any proceeds obtained as a result of the sale of the salvage or strap facility shall be first used to pay all cost incurred in the seizure, removal, storage and surrender. If, within one (1) year following the date of the sale, the owner or lien holder of the subject vehicle shall present sufficient proof to the city of its ownership and/or lien holder status, the owner or lien holder shall be entitled to the balance of the proceeds obtained from the sale of the vehicle after the payment of all costs and expenses hereinabove described. Any funds not claimed within one (1) year following the date of the sale shall be forfeited to the city. 
(Ord. No. 163-2007, § II, 6-5-2007) 
Sec. 13-22.11. - Judicial order of abatement. 
(a)  The city, as an alternate means of enforcement, may seek the abatement of any violation of this article through the judicial process. If within the specified delay, the notice to abate has not been complied with, and no request for hearing has been filed, the city may file a petition for abatement in a court of competent jurisdiction to have the offending violation declared a public nuisance and to order its abatement. This proceeding shall be summary in nature and shall be directed against the owner of the premises, the occupant of the premises, if any, and, in the proper case, against any registered owner of the offending motor vehicle. A hearing on the matter shall be provoked by a rule to show cause why the requested determination should not be made. Service of the rule to show cause shall be made in any manner provided by law. 
(b)  If evidence adduced at the hearing warrants the finding of a public nuisance, the court shall declare as such and order its abatement forthwith. The court shall also fix the reasonable cost of abatement, including, but not limited to, attorney fees incurred. The court shall also order imposition of a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(c)  Notices of the hearing shall constitute notice of any order rendered at such hearing or pursuant to such hearing and no further notice of the judicial order shall be required. 
(d)  The owner or occupant of the premises and/or the registered owner of the offending motor vehicle may appeal from the order of abatement by filing an appeal, to the court of appropriate jurisdiction, setting forth the reasons why the decision or order of the lower court is proper and the issue shall be tried by preference, if possible, in the appellate court. 
(e)  The decision of the lower court shall be final unless an appeal is filed within the time limits specified in the Louisiana Code of Civil Procedure. If no appeal is timely filed and no abatement has been completed, the city shall have the right to seize and dispose of the subject vehicle pursuant to the provisions of subsection 13-22.10(b). 
(Ord. No. 163-2007, § II, 6-5-2007) 
Sec. 13-23. - City of Alexandria smoke-free air ordinance of 2011. 
    The ordinance from which this section is derived shall be known as the City of Alexandria smoke-free air ordinance of 2011 and shall make all enclosed public places and workplaces, and certain outdoor areas, in the City of Alexandria smoke-free. 
(1)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Bar means an establishment that sells and/or serves alcoholic beverages of any alcoholic content for consumption on the premises by guests and in which the serving of food is only incidental to the consumption of those beverages, including but not limited to taverns, nightclubs, cocktail lounges, bars located within restaurants, bars located within hotels and motels, and cabarets. 
Business means a sole proprietorship, partnership, joint venture, corporation, or other business entity, either for-profit or not-for-profit, including retail establishments where goods or services are sold; professional corporations and other entities where legal, medical, dental, engineering, architectural, or other professional services are delivered. 
Employee means a person who is employed by an employer in consideration for direct or indirect monetary wages or profit, and a person who volunteers his or her services for an employer or non-profit entity. 
Employer means a person, business, partnership, association, corporation, including a municipal corporation, trust, or non-profit entity that employs the services of one or more individual persons. 
Enclosed area means all space between a floor and a ceiling that is bounded on at least two sides by walls, doorways, or windows, whether open or closed. A wall includes any retractable divider, garage door, or other physical barrier, whether temporary or permanent and whether or not containing openings of any kind. 
Gaming facilities means any establishment where gaming, gambling activities, or charitable gaming occurs, including but not limited to bingo halls, racetracks, establishments with video poker, land-based casinos, and riverboat casinos. "Gaming," "gambling activities," and "charitable gaming" means any game of chance which is played with cards, dice, or any electronic, electrical, or mechanical device or machine for money or property or anything of value. 
Health care facility means an office or institution providing care or treatment of diseases, whether physical, mental, or emotional, or other medical, physiological, or psychological conditions, including but not limited to, hospitals, rehabilitation hospitals or other clinics, including weight control clinics, nursing homes, long-term care facilities, homes for the aging or chronically ill, laboratories, and offices of surgeons, chiropractors, physical therapists, physicians, psychiatrists, dentists, and all specialists within these professions. This definition shall include all waiting rooms, hallways, private rooms, semiprivate rooms, and wards within health care facilities. 
Place of employment means an area under the control of a public or private employer, including, but not limited to, work areas, private offices, employee lounges, restrooms, conference rooms, meeting rooms, classrooms, employee cafeterias, hallways, construction sites, temporary offices, and vehicles. A private residence is not a "place of employment" unless it is used as a child care, adult day care, nursing home, or health care facility. 
Playground means any park or recreational area designed in part to be used by children that has play or sports equipment installed or that has been designated or landscaped for play or sports activities, or any similar facility located on public or private school grounds or on City of Alexandria grounds. 
Public place means an area to which the public is invited or in which the public is permitted, including but not limited to, banks, bars, educational facilities, gaming facilities, health care facilities, hotels and motels, laundromats, public transportation vehicles and facilities, reception areas, restaurants, retail food production and marketing establishments, retail service establishments, retail stores, retail tobacco businesses, shopping malls, sports arenas, theaters, and waiting rooms. A private residence is not a "public place" unless it is used as a child care, adult day care, nursing home, or health care facility. 
Restaurant means an eating establishment, including but not limited to, coffee shops, cafeterias, sandwich stands, and private and public school cafeterias, which gives or offers for sale food to the public, guests, or employees, as well as kitchens and catering facilities in which food is prepared on the premises for serving elsewhere. The term "restaurant" shall include a bar area within the restaurant. 
Retail tobacco business is any establishment or business, including but not limited to cigar shops, that are utilized primarily for the sale of tobacco products and accessories and in which the sale of other items is incidental. 
Service line means an indoor or outdoor line in which one or more persons are waiting for or receiving service of any kind, whether or not the service involves the exchange of money, including but not limited to, ATM lines, concert lines, food vendor lines, movie ticket lines, and sporting event lines. 
Shopping mall means an enclosed public walkway or hall area that serves to connect retail or professional establishments. 
Smoking means inhaling, exhaling, burning, or carrying any lighted or heated cigar, cigarette, or pipe, or any other lighted or heated tobacco or plant product intended for inhalation, in any manner or in any form. "Smoking" also includes the use of any oral smoking device for the purpose of circumventing the prohibition of smoking in this section. 
Sports arena means a place where people assemble to engage in physical exercise, participate in athletic competition, or witness sports or other events, including sports pavilions, stadiums, gymnasiums, health spas, boxing arenas, swimming pools, roller and ice rinks, and bowling alleys. 
(2)  Prohibition of smoking in enclosed public places . Smoking shall be prohibited in all enclosed public places within the City of Alexandria including but not limited to, the following places: 
a.  Aquariums, galleries, libraries, and museums. 
b.  Areas available to the general public in businesses and non-profit entities patronized by the public, including but not limited to, banks, laundromats, professional offices, and retail service establishments. 
c.  Bars. 
d.  Bingo facilities. 
e.  Child care and adult day care facilities. 
f.  Convention facilities. 
g.  Educational facilities, both public and private. 
h.  Elevators. 
i.  Gaming facilities. 
j.  Health care facilities. 
k.  Hotels and motels, including all rooms rented to guests, restrooms, lobbies, reception areas, hallways, and other common-use areas; provided that a maximum of fifty (50) percent of the hotel rooms, at the discretion of the hotel owner or general manger, available for rent to guests in a hotel or motel may be designated as smoking rooms. 
l.  Lobbies, hallways, and other common areas in apartment buildings, condominiums, trailer parks, retirement facilities, and other multiple-unit residential facilities. 
m.  Nursing homes including but not limited to all private and semi-private rooms, restrooms, lobbies, reception areas, hallways, and other common-use areas. 
n.  Polling places. 
o.  Public transportation vehicles, including buses and taxicabs, under the authority of the City of Alexandria, and ticket, boarding, and waiting areas of public transportation facilities, including bus, train, and airport facilities. 
p.  Restaurants. 
q.  Restrooms, lobbies, reception areas, hallways, and other common-use areas. 
r.  Retail stores. 
s.  Retail tobacco businesses. 
t.  Rooms, chambers, places of meeting or public assembly, including school buildings, under the control of an agency, board, commission, committee or council of the City of Alexandria or a political subdivision of the state, to the extent the place is subject to the jurisdiction of the City of Alexandria. 
u.  Service lines. 
v.  Shopping malls. 
w.  Sports arenas, including enclosed places in outdoor arenas. 
x.  Theaters and other facilities primarily used for exhibiting motion pictures, stage dramas, lectures, musical recitals, or other similar performances. 
(3)  Prohibition of smoking in enclosed places of employment . 
a.  Smoking shall be prohibited in all enclosed areas of places of employment without exception. This includes, without limitation, common work areas, auditoriums, classrooms, conference and meeting rooms, private offices, elevators, hallways, medical facilities, cafeterias, employee lounges, stairs, restrooms, vehicles, and all other enclosed facilities. 
b.  This prohibition on smoking shall be communicated to all existing employees by the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived and to all prospective employees upon their application for employment. 
(4)  Prohibition of smoking in outdoor public places. Smoking shall be prohibited in the following outdoor places: 
a.  Within a reasonable distance of twenty-five (25) feet outside entrances and operable windows of enclosed areas where smoking is prohibited, so as to prevent tobacco smoke from entering those areas. 
b.  Within twenty-five (25) feet of all buildings owned, leased, or operated by the City of Alexandria and that is under the control of the City of Alexandria. 
c.  In, and within twenty-five (25) feet of, enclosed outdoor seating or serving areas of restaurants and bars. 
d.  In and at all outdoor arenas, stadiums, and amphitheaters, including but not limited to bleachers and grandstands for use by spectators at sporting and other public events. 
e.  In, and within twenty-five (25) feet of, all outdoor playgrounds. 
f.  In, and within twenty-five (25) feet of, all outdoor public transportation stations, platforms, and shelters under the authority of the City of Alexandria. 
g.  In outdoor common areas of apartment buildings, condominiums, trailer parks, retirement facilities, nursing homes, and other multiple-unit residential facilities, except in designated smoking areas, not to exceed twenty-five (25) percent of the total outdoor common area, which must be located at least twenty-five (25) feet outside entrances and operable windows of enclosed areas where smoking is prohibited. 
(5)  Prohibition of smoking in outdoor places of employment. 
a.  Smoking shall be prohibited in all outdoor places of employment where employees are required to be in the course of their employment. This includes, without limitation, work areas, construction sites, temporary offices such as trailers, restroom facilities, and vehicles. 
b.  This prohibition on smoking shall be communicated to all existing employees by the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived and to all prospective employees upon their application for employment. 
(6)  Declaration of establishment or outdoor area as nonsmoking. Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, an owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of an establishment, facility, or outdoor area may declare that entire establishment, facility, or outdoor area as a nonsmoking place. Smoking shall be prohibited in any place in which a sign conforming to these requirements is posted. 
(7)  Posting of signs and removal of ashtrays. The owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of a public place or place of employment where smoking is prohibited by this section shall: 
a.  Clearly and conspicuously post "no smoking" signs or the international "no smoking" symbol (consisting of a pictorial representation of a burning cigarette enclosed in a red circle with a red bar across it) in that place. 
b.  Clearly and conspicuously post at every entrance to that place a sign stating that smoking is prohibited. 
c.  Clearly and conspicuously post on every vehicle that constitutes a place of employment under this section at least one (1) sign, visible from the exterior of the vehicle, stating that smoking is prohibited. 
d.  Remove all ashtrays from any area where smoking is prohibited by this section, except for ashtrays displayed for sale and not for use on the premises. 
(8)  Where smoking not regulated . Notwithstanding any other provision of this section to the contrary, smoking shall not be prohibited in private residences, unless used as a childcare, adult day care, nursing home, or health care facility. 
(9)  Declaration of establishment or outdoor area as nonsmoking . Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, an owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of an establishment, facility, or outdoor area may declare that entire establishment, facility, or outdoor area as a nonsmoking place. Smoking shall be prohibited in any place in which a sign conforming to these requirements is posted. 
(10)  Non-retaliation; non-waiver of rights. 
a.  No person or employer shall discharge, refuse to hire, or in any manner retaliate against an employee, applicant for employment, customer, or resident of a multiple-unit residential facility because that employee, applicant, customer, or resident exercises any rights afforded by this section or reports or attempts to prosecute a violation of this section. Violation of this subsection shall be a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each violation. 
b.  An employee who works in a setting where an employer allows smoking does not waive or otherwise surrender any legal rights the employee may have against the employer or any other party. 
(11)  Enforcement . 
a.  This section may be enforced by any law enforcement officer by issuance of a citation and summons to appear before the Alexandria City Court. 
b.  Notice of the provisions of this section shall be given to all applicants for a business license in the City of Alexandria. 
c.  City of Alexandria Code Enforcement officials may enforce this section while an establishment is undergoing otherwise mandated inspections. 
d.  An owner, manager, operator, or employee of an area regulated by this section shall direct a person who is smoking in violation of this section to extinguish the product being smoked. If the person does not stop smoking, the owner, manager, operator, or employee shall refuse service and shall immediately ask the person to leave the premises. If the person in violation refuses to leave the premises, the owner, manager, operator, or employee shall contact a law enforcement agency. 
(12)  Violations and penalties . 
a.  A person who smokes in an area where smoking is prohibited by the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by: 
1.  A fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a first violation. 
2.  A fine not exceeding two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for a second violation within one (1) year. 
3.  A fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each additional violation within one (1) year. 
b.  Except as otherwise provided by this section, a person who owns, manages, operates, or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment and who fails to comply with the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by: 
1.  A fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a first violation. 
2.  A fine not exceeding two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for a second violation within one (1) year. 
3.  A fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each additional violation within one (1) year. 
c.  In addition to the fines established by this section, violation of this section by a person who owns, manages, operates, or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment may result in the suspension or revocation of any permit or license issued to the person for the premises on which the violation occurred. 
d.  Each day on which a violation of this section occurs shall be considered a separate and distinct violation. 
(13)  Public education .
