(Ord. No. 337-2006, § V, 10-10-2006) 
Sec. 16-96. - Additional duties. 
    The AREP commission additionally shall cooperate with the City of Alexandria to promote the athletic, recreational and cultural activities and facilities operated by the City of Alexandria. The directors and employees of the divisions of planning, finance, public works, and community services shall provide requested assistance to the commission. The city attorney and legal division staff shall provide legal services and representation to the commission. 
(Ord. No. 337-2006, § VI, 10-10-2006) 
Sec. 16-97. - Reports. 
    The AREP commission shall transmit to the mayor and the city council annually a status report of its activities. The report shall include: 
(1)  Recommendations regarding capital improvements; 
(2)  Program establishment or enhancement including detailed description; and 
(3)  Policy establishment or modifications. 
(Ord. No. 337-2006, § VII, 10-10-2006) 
Chapter 17 - PEDDLERS; SOLICITORS; JUNK AND SECONDHAND DEALERS; PAWNBROKERS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Occupational license tax, § 10-20 et seq.; certain peddlers exempt from license tax, § 10-24. 
State Law reference- Secondhand dealer regulations, R.S. 37:1861 et seq. 

Sec. 17-1. - Soliciting, peddling, hawking, etc., on private premises without invitation-Declared misdemeanor. 
    The practice of going in and upon private residences in the city by solicitors, peddlers, hawkers, itinerant merchants or transient vendors of merchandise not having been requested or invited so to do by the owner or occupant of such private residences for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise or disposing of or peddling or hawking the same, is declared to be a nuisance and punishable as such nuisance as a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1956, § 20-4) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate transient merchants, R.S. 37:1908. 
Sec. 17-2. - Same-Exceptions. 
    The provisions of section 17-1 shall not apply to the sale, or soliciting of orders for the sale, of milk, dairy products, vegetables, poultry, eggs and other farm and garden produce so far as the sale of the commodities named herein is now authorized by law. 
(Code 1956, § 20-5) 
Sec. 17-3. - Street canvassing-Prohibited. 
    It is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and it shall be unlawful for any person to canvass persons on the streets or sidewalks of the city for the purpose of selling books, wares, merchandise or articles of any description or to beg or solicit funds. Such practice is hereby declared to be a nuisance and obnoxious to the personal rights, convenience and privileges of the public and it is further declared as impeding orderly traffic on streets and sidewalks unless, and except, in cases where the organization involved shall have strictly complied with the requirements set forth hereinafter. 
(Code 1956, § 20-2; Ord. No. 184-1981, § 1, 10-27-81; Ord. No. 16-1997, § 2, 1-21-97) 
Sec. 17-4. - Same-Exception. 
    The provisions of the preceding section shall not apply to persons over eighteen (18) years of age soliciting funds in drives sponsored solely for charitable, civic, or service organizations provided: 
(1)  In street canvassing. 
a.  A permit has been issued by the Alexandria Police Department indicating the location of the proposed canvassing, the time the event will start, and the time it is scheduled to conclude. 
    Such permit may be denied by the police department if the date and times conflict with other events at the location sought to be permitted or, in the opinion of the police department, will cause undue traffic delays and/or jeopardize the safety of the canvassers and/or the motoring public. 
b.  Members or volunteers canvassing or soliciting on behalf of the organization shall: 
1.  Wear bright orange vests while in the travel portion of the street. 
2.  Wear a clearly visible badge or insignia of the organization for which the person is canvassing or soliciting. 
3.  Place orange traffic cones not more than fifteen (15) feet apart down the center line of the traffic lanes for a distance not less than one hundred fifty (150) feet. 
(2)  Street solicitation from the sidewalk. 
a.  A permit has been issued by the Alexandria Police Department indicating the location of the proposed canvassing, the time the event will start, and the time it is scheduled to conclude. 
    Such permit may be denied by the police department if the date and times conflict with other events at the location sought to be permitted or in the opinion of the police department will cause undue traffic delays and/or jeopardize the safety of the canvassers and/or the motoring public. 
b.  Members or volunteer solicitors or canvassers on behalf of the organization shall: 
1.  Wear a clearly visible badge or insignia of the organization represented. 
2.  Remain on the sidewalk while traffic is in motion. 
3.  Enter the street only when traffic is stopped. 
4.  Make no attempt to impede the flow of traffic at the permitted site. 
5.  Return to the sidewalk immediately upon collection of the funds being solicited. 
    The city police department may, at any time during the permitted solicitation, suspend or terminate the solicitation if conditions arise which, in the opinion of the department, jeopardize the safety of the solicitors/canvassers or the motoring public. 
(3)  Permit limitations: 
a.  Permits issued by the Alexandria Police Department shall be for a period not to exceed one (1) day for each permit. 
b.  No more than six (6) permits shall be issued to any one (1) organization in a calendar year. 
c.  No permit shall be issued until the organization involved, as a condition of the permit, provides the city with sufficient evidence of liability insurance protecting such organization with respect to such activities in an amount not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00), single limit. 
(4)  Whosoever solicits funds on the streets and sidewalks of the city without securing the permits provided for in subsections 17-4(1) and 17-4(2) above shall be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Code 1956, § 20-3; Ord. No. 184-1981, § 2, 10-27-81; Ord. No. 16-1997, § 2, 1-21-97; Ord. No. 203-1999, §§ I, II, 9-7-99) 
Sec. 17-5. - Begging or soliciting alms without permit prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person directly or indirectly, to solicit alms for any purpose whatsoever, or beg within the city for himself or any other person unless the person so begging or soliciting shall first receive a written permit from the mayor so to do. 
(Code 1956, § 18-6) 
Cross reference- Begging, § 15-17(3); begging by child, § 15-31(b)(1). 
Sec. 17-6. - Use of streets for business purposes prohibited; construction of provisions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use the streets or sidewalks of the city as places of trade or business or as stands from which to conduct any trade or business. 
(b)  This section shall not be construed as preventing the temporary stopping or parking of vehicles on the streets for the purpose of making sale or delivery of goods, wares, merchandise or produce on private premises to occupants of the buildings or dwellings thereon where such sale or delivery is not prohibited by other ordinances of the city; but shall be construed as prohibiting the stopping or parking of vehicles or other forms of conveyance on the streets for the purpose of selling or delivering therefrom to the general public any goods, wares, merchandise or produce or otherwise engaging in trade or business therefrom with the general public. 
(Code 1956, § 20-1) 
Cross reference- Private use of streets, § 22-6. 
Sec. 17-6.1. - Sales of seafood, meats, produce, housewares, indoor and outdoor craft items, electronic gear and equipment, tools or machinery and any goods and merchandise for sale to the public on private property regulated. 
    It shall be unlawful for any persons, firm or corporation, except that farmers or their employees may sell or peddle farm produce as provided by this chapter and in accordance with R.S. 33:4833, to peddle, sell, offer for sale, exhibit for sale or take orders for sale of fresh or frozen seafood, fresh or frozen meats, farm produce, electronic gear and equipment, tools or machinery from any truck, automobile, motor vehicle, mobile unit, cart, stand, table, temporary building, portable or movable container, whether closed or enclosed, or operated on a permanent, temporary or seasonal basis, upon any private property without: 
(1)  Obtaining all applicable licenses and permits required by the State of Louisiana and/or the City of Alexandria or Rapides Parish, and posting same in a conspicuous place, in full view of the public; 
(2)  Designating on the occupational license application the fixed location of the private property or properties upon which such sales are to be made and making sales only at such fixed locations; 
(3)  Maintaining a public record for proof of purchase for auditing purposes for the City of Alexandria and any other concerned governmental agency which has powers to collect sale and use taxes; 
(4)  For the sale of fresh or frozen seafood: 
a.  Receive approval from the Rapides Parish Health Unit; 
b.  Use a thermometer and maintain the temperature of seafood at forty-five (45) degrees or below; 
c.  If selling prefrozen shrimp, the vendor must display a placard stating such information; 
d.  To display on a placard information regarding the original acquisition date and place of the seafood. 
(5)  Every transient merchant and/or open-air merchant subject to the provisions of this section, before selling at retail, or offering for sale at retail, within the incorporated limits of the city, any goods, wares or merchandise, whether from stock or by same, shall make application with the Alexandria Tax Office for a permit to carry on such business within the city. Such application shall be in writing, duly sworn by the applicant in person, or by the applicant's duly authorized representative, and shall contain the following information: 
a.  The name of the person having the management or supervision of such business during the time it shall be carried on in the city; 
b.  The address of such person while engaged in such business in the city; 
c.  The capacity in which such person will act; that is whether proprietor or agent; 
d.  The name of the person for whose account the business shall be carried on, and if a corporation, under the laws of what state the same is incorporated; 
e.  The place where the owner of such business conducts or maintains an established place of business; 
f.  The place in the city where it is proposed to carry on such business, and the length of time during which it is expected or proposed that such business shall be conducted; 
g.  A statement of nature, character and quantity of the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold at retail or offered for sale at retail in the city; 
h.  A statement as to whether the goods are to be sold at retail from stock in possession or by same, and whether the same are to be sold at retail at auction or public outcry, or by personal solicitation, or otherwise; 
i.  A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done or to be done in order to attract customers; 
j.  Written evidence of permission from the owner of the property where the retail activities are proposed to be conducted. 
(6)  It shall be unlawful for any transient vendor, solicitor, canvasser or merchant to engage in business until he shall have first applied to and obtained a permit to engage in business, in accordance with the above provisions and has paid all taxes and fees required by law for the transaction of such business in the incorporated limits of the city; the tax office shall issue such permit in writing, and shall state the date the same was issued, the nature of business authorized to be carried on and the expiration date of such permit, the place where such business may be carried on under such permit, and the name of the person or persons authorized to carry on the same, which permit shall be signed by the city tax collector or his authorized representative. 
(7)  The permit so issued shall be posted conspicuously in the place of business named therein. In the event the person applying for such permit shall desire to do business in more than one (1) place, then separate permits shall be applied for and issued for each place of business, and shall be posted conspicuously in each place of business, and the fee herein provided for shall be paid for each permit. 
(8)  Violations of the provisions of this section may result in a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per occurrence, per location. 
(Ord. No. 118-1982, § 1, 7-20-82; Ord. No. 25-1998, §§ 2, 3, 2-10-98 
Sec. 17-7. - Junk, secondhand dealers, pawnbrokers and scrap metal dealers-Purchase records required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person purchasing junk, scrap metal or any article usually handled by junk dealers, secondhand dealers, pawn brokers or scrap metal dealers, either as a business or as an occasional purchaser of such articles, to fail to maintain a well bound book at such person's place of business wherein shall be entered daily every purchase and a description of the articles so acquired, the name of the person from whom same were obtained, and the price paid for each such article or metal. 
(Code 1956, § 19-5; Ord. No. 252-2008, § I, 7-29-08) 
State Law reference- Regulations, R.S. 51:571 et seq. 
Sec. 17-7.1. - Scrap metal dealers to keep daily report of scrap metal purchased; required information; retention requirement, penalties. 
(a)  (1)  Every person, including any individual, firm, corporation, entity or partnership, except municipalities, political subdivisions, and public utility companies, engaged in the business of purchasing and reselling any of the materials provided for in paragraph (2) of this subsection, located either at a permanently established place of business or in connection with a business of an itinerant nature, including junk shops, junk yards, junk stores, auto wreckers, scrap metal dealers or processors, salvage yards, collectors of or dealers in junk, shall within twenty four (24) hours of any transaction, electronically record and maintain data and be capable of readily providing reports, as specified in subsection (b) of this section, in the form prescribed by the Alexandria Police Department, which report shall contain the following information and every person required to submit such record electronically shall, at the end of each business day, provide an electronic upload to a pawn reporting system designated by the chief of police of all transactions that occurred during that business day: 
a.  The name and address of the residence or place of business of such person required to either keep the register and file reports, or electronically maintain the data and generate the requested reports. 
b.  The date and place of each such purchase or acquisition. The report shall show the hour of the day when the article was received on deposit, pledged, or purchased, and the number of the pawn ticket, amount loaned, amount purchased, and a complete description of each article left on deposit, pledged or purchased. Each pawn ticket issued shall be numbered consecutively, and if stubs are used in connection with the pawn ticket, each stub shall be numbered consecutively to conform to the ticket. If any article so left on deposit, pledged, or purchased has engraved thereon a number, word, or initial, or contains settings of any kind, the description of the article in the report shall contain the number, word, or initial and shall show the kind of settings and the number of each kind. 
c.  The name and address of the seller or person from whom such material was purchased, including the distinctive number of the seller or person's or persons' valid and current Louisiana driver's license, Louisiana identification card, driver's license from another state, state issued identification card, passport, military identification, or identification issued by a governmental agency or the United States Postal Service. If the seller or person cannot produce any of the above forms of identification at the time of purchase, the purchaser shall not purchase or acquire possession of the item or items. 
d.  A photocopy of a valid driver's license or a valid identification card issued by the seller's current state of residence. If the seller of the material does not have a current valid driver's license or state-issued identification card, the purchaser shall not complete the transaction. 
e.  The motor vehicle license number of the vehicle or conveyance on which such material was delivered. 
f.  A full description of all such material purchased, including the weight of the material and whether it consists of bars, kegs, cable, ingots, rods, tubing wire, wire scraps, clamps, connectors, or other appurtenances or some combination thereof. 
g.  A full description of railroad track materials in excess of five hundred (500) pounds purchased, including the weight and whether it consists of rail, switch components, spikes, angle bars, tie plates, or bolts of the type used to construct railroads or other appurtenances or some combination thereof. 
h.  A digitally captured photograph of the item purchased or acquired. When the item purchased or acquired is captured photographically, the time and date shall be digitally recorded on the photograph, and the identity of the person taking the photograph shall be recorded. Any such photographs shall be included with the completed form or report that is submitted. 
(2)  This section shall apply to the following materials or any other appurtenance utilized or that can be utilized by common carriers or by persons, firms, corporations, cooperatives, entities, or municipal corporations engaged in either the generation, transmission, or distribution of electric energy or in telephone, telegraph, or other communications: 
a.  Gold, silver, platinum, copper, copper wire, copper alloy, bronze, zinc, aluminum other than in the form of cans, or brass, whether in the form of bars, cable, ingots, rods, tubing, wire, wire scraps, clamps, or connectors and whether the mineral or alloy is in any form or content whatsoever. 
b.  Steel in the form of railroad tracks or in the form of rail, switch components, spikes, angle bars, tie plates, or bolts of the type used in constructing railroads, or any combination of such materials valued in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(3)  This section shall not apply to purchases of materials provided for in paragraph (2) of this subsection from any manufacturing, industrial, or other commercial vendor that generates, as a byproduct or recyclable waste, or sells such materials in the ordinary course of business. 
(b)  (1)  Each such person shall keep either one (1) copy of such completed form in a separate register or book and maintain the information in electronic format as provided in subsection (a) of this section which shall be retained for a period of two (2) years at the purchasers place of business and shall be made available for inspection by any peace officer or law enforcement official at any time during the two-year period. 
(2)  For a period of not less than ten (10) days from the date of purchase, such material purchased or acquired shall be held or captured photographically, including digital format, in the same form without change, in which it was acquired, and items listed in the reports required shall be kept separated so that it is readily identifiable from all other purchases. 
(c)  Failure to maintain the information, the register or produce a report requested by the Alexandria Police Department as required by this section shall be prima facie evidence that the person receiving such material described in this section and not registered or reported, received it knowing it to be stolen, in violation of R.S. 14:69. 
(d)  The dealer shall not purchase trade or accept any salvage metals in subsection a. of this section or salvage vehicles from a person who is not eighteen (18) years of age. The purchasing of food or beverage cans is exempt from this section. 
(e)  All daily records shall be filed electronically to a law enforcement web site designated as an agent of the police department for the sole purpose of collecting such records, or in such other forms as may be permitted by the chief of police. 
(f)  The dealer shall not purchase, trade or accept any salvage metals in subsection (a) of this section containing a name or indication the item is the property of the city or for any other item having any identifiable characteristic of ownership other than the seller of the item. 
(g)  Whoever violates this section shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for not more than six (6) months, or both and the enhancement of penalties and suspension and revocation of an occupational license as set out in section 17-14 shall also be applicable. 
(Ord. No. 252-2008, § II, 7-29-08) 
Sec. 17-8. - Same-Purchases to be kept separate from general stock for designated time; exceptions. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, any article purchased as described in section 17-7 shall be kept by the dealer acquiring same for a period of at least two (2) days separate from other articles of the same character, so that the same may be fully identified upon examination made by any officer of the city designated in section 17-9. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with this section. 
(Code 1956, § 19-6; Ord. No. 252-2008, § III, 7-29-08) 
Sec. 17-9. - Same-Inspection and retention of records and articles. 
    The book and any electronic records or electronic data containing the required entries, shall at all times, and the articles purchased, shall for a period of ten (10) days after their acquisition, as described in sections 17-7 and 17-8 be subject to inspection by any police officer of the city. 
(Code 1956, § 19-7; Ord. No. 252-2008, § IV, 7-29-08) 
Sec. 17-10. - Same-Enclosure of premises for storage and selling of wreckage. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, to store or offer for sale any iron or steel junk or wreckage of motor vehicles, or any wrecked or junked vehicle, on any open lot or parcel of ground that is not properly enclosed on all boundary lines with a proper, suitable and substantial fence not less than six (6) feet, nor more than ten (10) feet high, and properly screening said enclosed area from public view; and provided further, said fence shall be kept in a constant state of good repair, and further that no signs or other advertising matter shall be placed upon said fence. 
(Code 1956, § 18-4.2) 
Cross reference- Dismantling vehicles on streets, § 22-12. 
State Law reference- Authority and procedure in removal of abandoned vehicle from public or private property, R.S. 32:474 et seq. 
Sec. 17-11. - Pawnbrokers-Record of articles purchased or pledged. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, either for his own account or as an agent or employee, engaging in the pawn broking business, or business of loaning money upon the security of personal property physically delivered in pawn to secure such loan, or of purchasing secondhand jewelry or watches, to fail to keep at the places of business conducted by them a well bound book wherein shall be entered daily a description of the articles purchased or pledged, the name of the sellers or borrowers, and the amounts of the purchase price or amount loaned thereon as the case may be. 
(Code 1956, § 19-1) 
State Law reference- Pawnbroker regulations, R.S. 37:1751 et seq. 
Sec. 17-11.1. - Secondhand dealers; defined, records of transactions. 
(a)  Every person engaged in the business of buying, selling, trading in, or otherwise acquiring or disposing of used or secondhand property, including but not limited to jewelry, silverware, diamonds, precious metals, furniture, pictures, objects of art, clothing, mechanic's tools, carpenter's tools, automobile hubcaps, automotive batteries, automotive sound equipment such as radios, CB radios, stereos, speakers, cassettes, compact disc players, digital video discs players, and similar automotive audio supplies, compact discs (CD), digital video discs (DVD), electronic games and gaming systems, used building components and items defined as cemetery artifacts is a secondhand dealer. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, a "used building component" shall mean any object produced or shaped by human workmanship or tools that is an element of structural, architectural, archaeological, historical, ornamental, cultural, utilitarian, decorative, or sentimental significance or interest, which has been and may be used as an adjunct to, or component or ornament of any building or structure, regardless of monetary worth, age, size, shape, or condition, that is immovable property or fixture, including but not limited to bricks, siding, gutters, downspouts, lightning rods, chimney roofs, lights, chandeliers, stoves, tubs, sinks, faucets, faucet handles, toilets, bidets, showers, fans, furnaces, air conditioners, water heaters, sprinkling systems, shelving, countertops, cabinets, built-in speakers, shutters, trim, rafters, roof tiles, roofing, studs, foundation, barge boards, paneling, stairs, risers, banisters, wiring, plumbing, hinges, door latches, door knobs, medallions, mantles, flooring, carpet, tiles, molding, wainscoting, pavers, doors, windows, sills, transoms, joists, mailboxes, signage, fountains, decking, gates, fences, planters, landscaping, plantings or portions thereof, or component parts of immovable property of any nature or kind whatsoever. 
(c)  For purposes of this part "cemetery artifacts" means any object produced or shaped by human workmanship or tools, including ornaments of archaeological, historical, cultural, or sentimental significance or interest, which may be used to memorialize the dead and shall include but not be limited to all cemetery items, objects, and properties including but not limited to any type of religious or sentimental addition or adornment, inside or outside of a tomb, gravesite, plot, mausoleum, vault or interment location, whether placed privately or by assignment, regardless of monetary worth, age, size, shape, or condition including but not limited to statues, bricks, signage, plaques, tablets, urns, pots, planters, benches, chairs, crosses or other religious symbols, vases, gates, fences, or any portions thereof. 
(d)  The following are not secondhand dealers for purposes of this section: 
(1)  Dealers in coins and currency, dealers in antiques, gun and knife shows or other trade and hobby shows. 
(2)  Persons solely engaged in the business of buying, selling, trading in, or otherwise acquiring or disposing of motor vehicles and used parts of motor vehicles, and shall not apply to wreckers or dismantlers of motor vehicles who are licensed under the provisions of R.S. 32:771, et seq. 
(3)  Private residential sales commonly known as "garage sales" or "yard sales" as long as such sales take place at a residential address. 
(4)  Any bona fide charity possessing a valid exemption under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(e)  Pawnbrokers and secondhand dealers as defined herein shall file all daily records electronically to a law enforcement web site designated as an agent of the police department for the sole purpose of collecting such records or in such other form as may be permitted by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 252-2008, § V, 7-29-08) 
Sec. 17-12. - Same-Inspection of records and articles. 
    The book containing the information described in section 17-11, and the article purchased or pledged as the case may, shall at all times be subject to inspection upon demand by the chief of police of the city or any police officer designated by him. 
(Code 1956, § 19-2) 
Sec. 17-13. - Disposal or changing identity prohibited during ten-day period. 
    No secondhand dealer shall sell or dispose of or change or destroy the identity of any goods, articles, or things purchased by him before an interval of ten (10) calendar days from the date of purchase has elapsed. 
(Ord. No. 252-2008, § VI, 7-29-08) 
Sec. 17-14. - Violations; penalty. 
(a)  Any secondhand dealer who violates any provision of this chapter, shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty ($250.00) dollars, nor more than five hundred ($500.00) dollars or be imprisoned for not less than thirty (30) days nor more than sixty (60) days, or both. 
(b)  For the second offense, his occupational license shall be suspended for a thirty-day period. For a third offense, his license shall be revoked and he shall not thereafter be permitted to engage in the business of secondhand dealer in the city. 
(c)  Each transaction shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(d)  Any secondhand dealer convicted of selling stolen goods shall have his occupational retail license revoked. 
(e)  The occupational license tax collector is hereby vested with the authority, upon motion in a court of competent jurisdiction, to rule the non complying secondhand dealer to show cause in not less than two (2) nor more than ten (10) days, exclusive of holidays, as to why the non complying secondhand dealer's retail occupational license should not be suspended or revoked as prescribed under this part. This rule may be tried out of term and in chambers and shall be tried with preference and priority. If the rule is made absolute, the order rendered therein shall be considered a judgment in favor of the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 252-2008, § VII, 7-29-08)

ARTICLE II. - REGIONAL PLANNING COMMISSION 

Sec. 20-20. - Regional planning area and commission created; adoption of map. 
    The City Council of Alexandria, acting jointly with the Rapides Parish Police Jury and the Mayor and Board of Aldermen of the City of Pineville, and under the authority of Section 1321 et seq., of Title 33 of the Louisiana Revised Statutes of 1950, as amended, and under the authority of Section 131 et seq., of Title 33 of the Revised Statutes of 1950, as amended, does hereby join with said other governmental bodies in the creation of a regional planning area to encompass all that area within the existing city limits of Alexandria and Pineville and all of Wards 1, 8, 9 and 10 and that portion of Ward 2 lying north of Township Two North, Range One East and north of Township Two North, Range One West and west of Section 36, Township 3 North, Range One East, Rapides Parish, Louisiana, as shown on the official regional planning area map, which is hereby approved and declared to be a part of this article and shall bear the following words: "This is to certify that this is the Official Regional Planning Area Map adopted on December 18, 1968," and shall be attested by the chairman of said regional planning commission, said map to be filed with the clerk and recorder of Rapides Parish, and does further hereby create and establish a regional planning commission to act with respect to the area herein set forth, which commission is empowered to make studies and recommendations regarding, to correlate, and to establish and review plans, policies and programs for solving area-wide problems of the respective local governments in the area concerned. 
(Ord. No. 39-1968, § 1, 12-18-68) 
Sec. 20-21. - Name; membership. 
    The regional planning commission shall be known as the Rapides Area Planning Commission and shall consist of no less than fifteen (15) members. The mayor, or chief executive officer, of each of the governing bodies composing said planning commission shall be members of said commission. The mayor, or the chief executive officer, of each of said governing bodies composing the commission shall nominate, subject to the approval of the nominator's respective governing body, four (4) other persons to serve on the planning commission, two (2) of whom shall be members of the nominator's respective governing body. At all times the membership of the commission shall be composed of a majority of appointed or elected public officials holding office in the municipalities and/or parish represented in the urbanized area. The commission shall be an open-ended commission and with the unanimous consent of the cities of Pineville and Alexandria, and the police jury of Rapides Parish, additional municipalities may participate in the planning commission, and each new member of the commission is entitled to appoint the same number of members as each present member of the commission is entitled to appoint, provided that each new municipality contributes to the expense and maintenance of the planning commission on a pro rata basis. 
    The tenure of office of the appointed members of the commission shall be in accordance with the provisions of R.S. 33:132 and all appointees shall serve until their successors are duly appointed. 
(Ord. No. 39-1968, §§ 2, 9, 12-18-68; Ord. No. 23-1970, § 1, 9-15-70) 
Sec. 20-22. - Purposes and functions. 
    The purposes and functions of the planning commission shall be: 
(1)  To carry on a continuing comprehensive planning program which will supplement and coordinate, without duplication, programs of the member units. 
(2)  To study area governmental problems common to two (2) or more of the governing bodies which have formed the area and commission in question, as it deems appropriate, including but not limited to matters affecting health, safety, welfare, education, economic conditions and regional development. 
(3)  To promote cooperative arrangements and coordinate the action among its members. 
(4)  To make recommendations for review and action to the members and other public agencies that perform functions within the region. 
(5)  To serve as a clearinghouse, for the benefit of the member governments, of information concerning their common problems and concerning state and federal services available to assist in the solution of these problems. 
(6)  To formulate, develop and modify from time to time a comprehensive general plan for the development of the area with particular emphasis upon the fields of land use, transportation, housing, water and sewerage, economic and industrial development, community facilities and general improvement of living conditions and environment. 
(7)  To hire professional planners and to establish and maintain a permanent staff for the purpose of assisting the commission with its planning activities. 
(Ord. No. 39-1968, § 3, 12-18-68) 
Sec. 20-23. - Powers. 
    The commission is hereby granted all powers conferred under the provisions of R.S. 33:135. 
(Ord. No. 39-1968, § 10, 12-18-68) 
Sec. 20-24. - Bylaws. 
    The commission may adopt bylaws designating the officers of the commission, providing for the conduct of its business, the manner and method of securing any local funds that may be necessary, and the manner and method by which voting on projects by the commission shall be determined. Such bylaws shall be ratified by each member unit of the commission after their adoption by the commission before they become binding upon the respective governmental bodies who have collaborated in the forming of this planning area and commission. 
(Ord. No. 39-1968, § 5, 12-18-68) 
Sec. 20-25. - Finance-Receipt and expenditure of funds, etc. 
    The commission may accept and expend funds, grants, gifts and services from the United States of America or its agencies, from the State of Louisiana, or its departments, agencies or instrumentalities, from any governmental unit whether or not participating in the council, and from private and civic sources. 
(Ord. No. 39-1968, § 4, 12-18-68) 
Sec. 20-26. - Same-Obtaining grants; pro rata contributions by member units. 
    With respect to the financing of the planning commission and its work, the commission and the governmental bodies composing same, shall make all reasonable efforts to obtain such federal and state grants or subsidies as may be available; that the balance of the cost of operation shall be borne proportionately by the governmental bodies composing the commission and in this respect it is agreed that the contribution of the respective bodies shall be according to population and that the City of Pineville shall pay an amount proportionate to what its population bears to the population in the entire planning area, and the City of Alexandria shall pay the percentage which its population bears to the entire population of the planning area and the balance shall be paid by the police jury and/or any other governmental bodies which may subsequently decide to participate. 
(Ord. No. 39-1968, § 6, 12-18-68) 
Sec. 20-27. - Withdrawal of member units. 
    Any of the governmental bodies which have collaborated to form the commission may, if dissatisfied with the work of the commission, withdraw from participation therein upon sixty (60) days written notice to the chairman of the commission subsequent to formal action by its governing body. 
(Ord. No. 39-1968, § 7, 12-18-68) 
Sec. 20-28. - Dissolution of commission. 
    The governmental units forming the area and commission may by mutual agreement and by proper ordinance dissolve the commission. 
(Ord. No. 39-1968, § 8, 12-18-68) 
Secs. 20-29-20-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONVENTIONS COMMISSION 

Sec. 20-40. - Commission created. 
    There is hereby created a commission to be known as the Alexandria-Pineville-Rapides Conventions Commission, pursuant to the authority of Act No. 101 of the Louisiana Legislature of 1964. 
(Ord. No. 9-1975, § 1, 2-3-75) 
Sec. 20-41. - Commissioners. 
(a)  The commission shall be composed of all of the members of the board of directors of the Chamber of Commerce of the Alexandria-Pineville Area, Inc. 
(b)  The members of the commission shall not receive any salaries or per diem for their services, but shall be allowed necessary expenses in connection with their duties as members of said commission. 
(c)  The terms of office of each of the members of the Alexandria-Pineville-Rapides Conventions Commission herein created shall be co-extensive with their term of office as a member of the board of directors of the Chamber of Commerce of the Alexandria-Pineville Area, Inc. 
(Ord. No. 9-1975, §§ 2, 5, 8, 2-3-75) 
Sec. 20-42. - Officers. 
    The officers of the Alexandria-Pineville-Rapides Conventions Commission shall be those of said board of directors. 
(Ord. No. 9-1975, § 3, 2-3-75) 
Sec. 20-43. - Meetings. 
    Following the organization of the commission, it shall meet regularly once a month or it may meet on call of its chairman at any time. 
(Ord. No. 9-1975, § 6, 2-3-75) 
Sec. 20-44. - Records and reports. 
    The commission shall keep an accurate record of all its meetings, and shall at the end of each year's operation have its financial records audited, and submit in writing a detailed report of its operations to the police jury of Rapides Parish, Louisiana, and the cities of Alexandria and Pineville, and to any other municipality that contributes financially. 
(Ord. No. 9-1975, § 7, 2-3-75) 
Sec. 20-45. - Finance-Accepting donations, etc. 
    The Alexandria-Pineville-Rapides Conventions Commission may accept donations, contributions and financial support from individuals and corporations. 
(Ord. No. 9-1975, § 9, 2-3-75) 
Sec. 20-46. - Same-Deposit and withdrawal of funds. 
    All funds of the Alexandria-Pineville-Rapides Conventions Commission shall be deposited by said commission in a fiscal depository to be selected by the commission and shall only be withdrawn on properly preserved vouchers countersigned by the chairman and treasurer of said Alexandria-Pineville-Rapides Conventions Commission. 
(Ord. No. 9-1975, § 10, 2-3-75) 
Sec. 20-47. - Same-Bonds of director, treasurer and employees. 
    The commission shall exact of the director appointed by it and the treasurer, surety bonds written by an insurance company authorized to do business in the state, to guarantee the faithful performance of their duties as such. The commission shall likewise have the right and power to exact such bonds of any of its other employees, premiums of said bonds to be paid by the commission. 
(Ord. No. 9-1975, § 11, 2-3-75) 
Sec. 20-48. - Legal advisors. 
    The district attorney of the Ninth Judicial District of Louisiana, his assistant, and the city attorney for the City of Alexandria, shall be the legal advisors of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 9-1975, § 14, 2-3-75) 
Sec. 20-49. - Purpose and powers-General. 
    The Alexandria-Pineville-Rapides Conventions Commission herein created shall have the purpose of attracting tourists and other groups to visit, convene, and meet in said cities and parish, and shall have the right to sue and be sued, make and enter into contracts, employ a director for said commission, and such other employees as in the judgment of the commission may be necessary to the efficient and proper operation of said commission. 
(Ord. No. 9-1975, § 4, 2-3-75) 
Sec. 20-50. - Same-Administration of commission. 
    The Alexandria-Pineville-Rapides Conventions Commission shall have full power and authority to administer the affairs of the commission in all respects, including the salaries of all employees, the expending of all funds available to it for the purpose for which the commission is created and, generally, to do everything necessary for the efficient operation of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 9-1975, § 12, 2-3-75) 
Sec. 20-51. - Same-Delegation of powers of member units. 
    This article is to be adopted in accordance with the laws providing for intergovernmental relations and all powers and authority which may be delegated to such a commission by a political subdivision, is hereby delegated to the Alexandria-Pineville-Rapides Conventions Commission. 
(Ord. No. 9-1975, § 13, 2-3-75) 
Chapter 22 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Vehicles with lugs, etc., § 25-156; dragging vehicle load, § 25-28. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Public street defined. 
    The term "public street" as used in this chapter is hereby defined to mean the entire area dedicated to or acquired by the city for street purposes including the area for curbs, sidewalks and all other territory lying between private property lines along the various streets, except where the context requires otherwise. 
(Code 1956, § 24-1) 
Cross reference- Definition of public place, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-2. - Numbering of buildings-Declaration of policy. 
    It is declared to be the general policy of the city for buildings and premises within the city to be numbered in a systematic and orderly manner; and accordingly they carry an even number on one side of the street and a corresponding odd number on the opposite side; and the buildings and premises shall be numbered systematically in separate brackets of one hundred (100) for each block beginning at some designated point and increasing in consecutive order to the end of the street. 
(Code 1956, § 24-8) 
Sec. 22-3. - Same-Procedure on designated streets. 
    The municipal numbering of buildings and premises on the hereinafter named streets shall be carried out and enforced as indicated below: 
(1)  For Third Street, begin at the corner of Third and Monroe streets and run in a southerly direction along Third Street, the buildings and premises to be numbered consecutively by blocks beginning with one hundred (100) for the first block. 
(2)  For Jackson Street, begin at the Red River Levee and run in a westerly direction out Jackson Street, the buildings and premises to be numbered consecutively by blocks beginning with one hundred (100) for the first block. 
(3)  For Bolton Avenue, begin at the intersection of Bolton Avenue and Rapides Avenue and run in a southerly direction along Bolton Avenue and the buildings and premises between Bolton Avenue and Levin Street to be numbered between one (1) and ninety-nine (99) and those from Levin Street to Lee Street to be numbered consecutively by blocks beginning with one hundred (100) for the first block and ending with twelve hundred (1200) for the last block at Lee Street. 
(4)  For North Bolton Avenue, begin at the intersection of North Bolton Avenue and Rapides Avenue and run in a northerly direction along North Bolton Avenue, the buildings and premises to be numbered consecutively by blocks beginning with one hundred (100) for the first block and ending with three hundred (300) for the last block at the city limits. 
(5)  For North Sixteenth Street, begin at the intersection of Rapides Avenue and North Sixteenth Street and run in a northerly direction along North Sixteenth Street, the buildings and premises to be numbered consecutively by blocks beginning with one hundred (100) for the first block and ending with one thousand (1000) for the last block at the city limits. 
(6)  For Florence Avenue, begin at the intersection of Florence Avenue and Rapides Avenue and run in a southerly direction along Florence Avenue, the buildings and premises between Rapides Avenue and Monroe Street to be numbered between one (1) and ninety-nine (99) and those from Monroe Street to Albert Street to be numbered consecutively by blocks beginning with one hundred (100) for the first block and ending with eight hundred (800) for the last block at Albert Street. 
(7)  For Chester Street, begin at the intersection of Chester Street and Rapides Avenue and run in a southerly direction along Chester Street, the buildings and premises between Rapides Avenue and Monroe Street to be numbered between one (1) and ninety-nine (99) and those from Monroe Street to Vance Avenue to be numbered consecutively by blocks beginning with one hundred (100) for the first block and ending with fifteen hundred (1500) for the last block at Vance Avenue. 
(8)  For Texas Avenue, begin at the intersection of Texas Avenue and Rapides Avenue and run in a southerly direction along Texas Avenue, the buildings and premises between Rapides Avenue and Monroe Street to be numbered between one (1) and ninety-nine (99) and those from Monroe Street to Masonic Drive to be numbered consecutively by blocks beginning with one hundred (100) for the first block and ending with twenty-one hundred (2100) for the last block at Masonic Drive. 
(9)  For East Texas Avenue, begin at the intersection of East Texas Avenue and Houston Street and run in the direction of Masonic Drive, the buildings and premises to be numbered consecutively by blocks beginning with fourteen hundred (1400) for the first block and ending with twenty-five hundred (2500) for the last block at Masonic Drive. 
(10)  For Lee Street, begin at the Red River Levee and run in a westerly direction out Lee Street, the buildings and premises to be numbered consecutively by blocks beginning with one hundred (100) for the first block. 
(11)  For Shirland Avenue, begin at the intersection of Shirland Avenue and North Twelfth Street and run in a westerly direction along Shirland Avenue, the buildings and premises to be numbered consecutively by blocks beginning with twelve hundred (1200) for the first block and ending with eighteen hundred (1800) for the last block at North Eighteenth Street. 
(12)  For Beech Street, begin at the intersection of Beech Street and Turner Street and run in the direction of City Park, the buildings and premises to be numbered consecutively by blocks beginning with thirteen hundred (1300) for the first block and ending with eighteen hundred (1800) for the last block at City Park. 
(Code 1956, § 24-9) 
Sec. 22-4. - Same-Director of planning authorized to effect provisions of sections 22-2 and 22-3. 
    The director of planning is authorized to carry into effect the provisions of sections 22-2 and 22-3 by notifying the property owners where any numbering is required to be installed or changed and generally to take such other steps and perform such other acts as may be necessary or proper to carry out the purposes and intent of such sections. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with the instructions of the director of planning in connection with the carrying into effect of the provisions of such sections. 
(Code 1956, § 24-10; Ord. No. 89-1989, § 2, 5-16-89) 
Sec. 22-5. - Interference with street workers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with or prevent any employee of the city, either by threats, or by actual violence, from working on the streets of the city, or draining or cutting the ditches of same, when such employee is acting under the instructions of the director of public works or city engineer or other competent authority of the city. 
(Code 1956, § 18-27) 
Sec. 22-6. - Private use or occupancy. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make private use of or occupy any portion of a public street in the city. 
(b)  The private use or occupancy herein prohibited includes, but is not limited to, the following: The planting of trees, shrubbery, or flowers, or vegetables or other crops; the construction or installation of any building or structure; the plowing or tilling of the soil. 
(Code 1956, § 24-2) 
Cross reference- Use of streets for business, § 17-6. 
Sec. 22-7. - Excavations, cuts, ditches, obstructions-Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than city personnel in the performance of their duties, to make, or cause to be made any excavation, cut or ditch, or to place any obstruction, in any of the streets of the city, except in connection with work authorized by the city, for which work a permit shall first be obtained from the city engineer; provided, this section shall not apply to shade trees growing at least two and one-half (21/2) feet from the outer edge of sidewalks. 
(Code 1956, §§ 24-3, 24-4) 
Sec. 22-8. - Same-Issuance of permit; bond. 
    The city engineer may allow, by written permit, any person to make a temporary excavation, cut or ditch, for necessary purposes of utility, or to place obstructions of a temporary character, such as building material, in or upon the streets, where the same is necessary in the conduct of any work under progress; provided, such obstructions or excavations shall be made under the direction and supervision of the city engineer; provided further, the city engineer may in all cases require the applicant to furnish bond and surety to hold the city harmless in the event of any damage resulting to any party by reason of such excavation, cut, ditch or obstruction; and, provided further, in all such cases red lanterns shall be placed and kept at both ends and at intervals along such excavation, cut, ditch or obstruction from 6:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. 
(Code 1956, § 24-5) 
Sec. 22-9. - Drainage or deposit of waters. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drain hydrant water into or upon the streets, or to deposit water upon any street, in such manner and in such quantity that the same may become injurious to health, or offensive to smell, or to create any pool or pond of water or offensive wet place on any street. 
(Code 1956, § 24-6) 
Sec. 22-10. - Attaching advertising matter, notices, pictures, etc., to public buildings, poles, street signs, etc., prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a duly authorized public agency, to nail, tie, paste or in any manner fasten or place signs, pictures, circulars, posters, advertisements, notices or other things of a similar nature on any of the publicly owned buildings, structures, poles, posts, street signs or other public property of the city. 
(Code 1956, § 3-1) 
Cross reference- Litter in public places generally, § 13-7. 
Sec. 22-11. - Swinging signs or banners. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hang or suspend any swinging sign or banner over the streets of the city, except on special occasions and for a limited time in which event a permit must first be obtained from the mayor. 
(Code 1956, § 3-2) 
Sec. 22-12. - Use of public places for wrecking, dismantling or storage-Generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to wreck, dismantle or store, for commercial purposes, any motor vehicle or trailer or iron or steel junk on the streets, sidewalks and other public places of the city. 
(Code 1956, § 18-4.1) 
Cross reference- Enclosure of junkyard, § 17-10; parking disabled vehicle on public property, § 25-116. 
State Law reference- Authority and procedure in removal of abandoned vehicles from public or private property, R.S. 32:474 et seq. 
Sec. 22-13. - Same-Storage of motor vehicles or trailers by garages, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person operating any garage, or engaged in any of the businesses of buying, selling, storing or repairing motor vehicles or trailers, to use the streets, sidewalks or other public places of the city for storing motor vehicles or trailers while such vehicles are being kept for repair, sale or storage. 
(b)  Any person owning, conducting or operating any garage or business of buying, selling, storing or repairing motor vehicles or trailers who shall permit any such motor vehicle or trailer kept for sale, storage, repair or for any other purpose than actual use by owners or employees of such person owning and conducting such businesses, to remain on the streets, sidewalks or other public places of the city for a period longer than two (2) hours at any one time, shall be guilty of violating this section. 
(Code 1956, § 18-4) 
Sec. 22-14. - Climbing upon trees and shrubs in public parks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to climb any tree or shrub located in any of the public parks of the city. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to agents and employees of the city engaged in the discharge of their duties. 
(Code 1956, § 18-45) 
Secs. 22-15-22-25. - Reserved. 
Note- See the editor's footnote to Art. II. 
ARTICLE II. - DRIVEWAYS AND SIDEWALKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- The land development ordinance, adopted Aug. 18, 1992, § 28-1.6, repealed §§ 22-20-22-25 and 22-33-22-37 which had been codified as portions of Art. II. Prior to repeal, such sections pertained to construction, permits, and specifications for driveways and sidewalks and were derived from the 1956 Code, §§ 24-11, 24-11.1-24-11.10, as subsequently amended (see the Code Comparative Table at the back of this volume). 

Sec. 22-26. - Maintenance by property owners. 
    The owners of property abutting on streets where there are paved sidewalks, curbings or gutters, shall be jointly and severally responsible for causing the paved sidewalks, sidewalk area (including driveways and the grass strip), curbings and gutters abutting said property to be kept in repair and free from nuisance. 
(Code 1956, § 24-12) 
Sec. 22-27. - Notice to repair-Service on owners. 
    Whenever the city engineer shall find that any sidewalk or curbing should be constructed or that any paved sidewalk, sidewalk area (including driveways and the grass strip), curbing or gutter is not in repair or is not free from nuisance, he shall notify the owner of the abutting property, in writing, to have the necessary construction, reconstruction or repairs made. He shall cause such notice to be served on the owner by registered mail addressed to such owner at the address to which tax bills are sent. 
(Code 1956, § 24-12.1) 
Sec. 22-28. - Same-Contents. 
    The notice shall identify the property, give the location of the sidewalk, and set out the construction, reconstruction or repairs to be made and the period of time allowed the property owner to have the work done by private contract. Such time shall be reasonable, but shall not be less than thirty (30) days from date of the mailing of the registered notice. 
(Code 1956, § 24-12.2) 
Sec. 22-29. - Same-Failure to comply; construction, reconstruction or repairing by city at expense of property owner. 
    If a sidewalk, driveway, curb or gutter is not constructed, or if a defective sidewalk, driveway, curb or gutter is not reconstructed or repaired, or freed from nuisance within the period of time permitted by the notice to the owner of the abutting property, the city engineer shall cause the work to be done by a local contractor or the city crews and the entire cost shall be charged against such property. 
(Code 1956, § 24-12.4) 
Sec. 22-30. - Emergency repairs; costs charged against abutting property. 
    In case of emergency, the city engineer is authorized to have temporary repairs made, or to barricade and redlight the area, or otherwise provide for the public safety. The cost of all such emergency repair and protection shall be charged against the abutting property and shall be collected as provided hereafter. 
(Code 1956, § 24-12.5) 
Sec. 22-31. - Board to hear protests filed by property owners. 
    A board consisting of the director of public works, the city attorney and one person appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation of the council, shall serve as a board to hear and determine any protests filed by the property owners as to sidewalks, sidewalk areas (including driveways and the grass strips), curbing and gutter construction, reconstruction or repair. 
(Code 1956, § 24-12.3) 
Sec. 22-32. - Billing. 
(a)  Upon completion of any work done under either section 22-29 or section 22-30, the owner of the abutting property shall be billed for the cost and expense of the work. Such bills shall include: 
(1)  All construction costs, including all costs of temporary repairs, barricading and redlighting in emergency cases; 
(2)  All permits fees; 
(3)  A charge for administrative costs of five dollars ($5.00) or ten (10) per cent of the construction costs, whichever is larger. 
(b)  Bills issued under this section shall be payable within thirty (30) days from the date of such bill. Bills not paid within thirty (30) days shall be reported to the city council for assessment against the abutting property owners. 
(Code 1956, §§ 24-12.6, 24-12.7) 
Chapter 24.5 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS[1]

(Ord. No. 131-1993, § 1, 7-9-93)

    The City of Alexandria hereby adopts Federal Communication Commission rules concerning cable subscriber rate regulations. 
(Ord. No. 131-1993, § 1, 7-9-93)

ARTICLE II. - CABLE TELEVISION FRANCHISE REGULATIONS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Arts. I-IV), adopted Oct. 4, 1988, did not specify manner of codification; hence, such provisions have been included herein by the editor with the city's concurrence as Art. II, §§ 24.5-16-24.5-19, 24.5-26-24.5-37; 24.5-46-24.5-48; 24.5-56-24.5-58. 
Cross reference- Construction regulations re television apparatus or equipment, § 7-150 et seq.; television and radio distribution systems and master antenna systems, § 7-165 et seq.; streets and sidewalks generally, Ch. 22; television installation in motor vehicles, § 25-155. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 24.5-16. - Definitions. 
    [As used in this article the following words and terms shall have the meaning ascribed thereto:] 
    Alexandria shall mean the City of Alexandria, a municipal corporation of the State of Louisiana, as presently constituted and including any area henceforth added thereto during the term of any franchise granted hereunder. 
    Applicant means any applicant for a franchise pursuant to this article. 
    Cable television system or cable system has the same meaning as given in 47 U.S.C. § 522. 
    Franchise is an authorization granted under this article to construct, operate and maintain a cable television system within the city. 
    Franchise authority is the city council of the City of Alexandria or any future body constituting the legislative body of the city. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. I, § 1), 10-4-88) 
Sec. 24.5-17. - Franchise to operate necessary; penalty for violation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to commence or engage in the construction, operation or maintenance of a cable television system without a franchise issued by the franchise authority. This section shall not be deemed to require the grant of a franchise to any particular person or to prohibit the franchise authority from restricting the number of grantees should it determine such a restriction would be in the public interest. 
(b)  Any persons violating this section shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day or by imprisonment for not more than sixty (60) days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. I, § 2), 10-4-88) 
Sec. 24.5-18. - Term of franchise. 
    Any franchise granted by the franchise authority shall be for a term of twelve (12) years. The franchise authority may renew the franchise for successive ten-year period(s). 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. I, § 3), 10-4-88) 
Sec. 24.5-19. - Limitations of franchise. 
(a)  Any franchise granted under this article shall be nonexclusive and nothing herein shall be construed to prevent the franchise authority from granting identical franchises to more than one (1) person. 
(b)  All privileges prescribed by the franchise granted to any new grantee shall be conditioned on the requirement that such new grantee shall indemnify and hold harmless the franchise authority, applicable utilities and any existing grantee from and against all costs and expenses resulting from the activities of such new grantee. 
(c)  Any franchise granted under this article shall not authorize an additional grantee to operate within the franchise area of any existing grantee on terms or conditions more favorable or less burdensome to such new grantee than those being applied to any existing grantee at the time the new franchise is granted. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. I, § 4), 10-4-88) 
Secs. 24.5-20-24.5-25. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - APPLICATION PROCEDURES AND CONTENTS 

Sec. 24.5-26. - Initial fee. 
    Application for a new franchise shall be submitted to the mayor or his designee with an initial application fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). To the extent that the franchising authority's cost of processing the application do not exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00), the difference will be refunded to the applicant. To the extent such costs exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00), such costs shall be paid by the applicant prior to final consideration of the request by the franchise authority. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. II, § 1), 10-4-88) 
Sec. 24.5-27. - Timing of applications. 
    The franchise authority will consider any applications for a new franchise which may be submitted during a thirty-one-days period commencing July 1 and ending at noon on July 31 of each calendar year. In the event an application is filed proposing a franchise area which overlaps, in whole or in part, an existing grantee's franchise area, a copy of such application shall be served by the applicant, by registered or certified mail, upon any current grantee. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. II, § 2), 10-4-88) 
Sec. 24.5-28. - Scope and contents. 
    All applications for a new franchise shall be filed in conformance with and subject to the provisions of this article. This article shall not be construed to prescribe the detail in which the applicant shall make its presentation nor in any way to restrict the scope of its presentation. However, at a minimum, the following matters must be carefully covered and in such detail that the franchise authority can make fully informed judgments concerning the adequacy of the proposal and applicant's legal, character, financial, technical and other qualifications to construct and operate a cable television system in Alexandria. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. II, § 3), 10-4-88) 
Sec. 24.5-29. - Franchise area. 
    The applicant shall submit sufficiently detailed information to allow the franchise authority to determine whether the size of the requested franchise is in the public interest, considering the size of the area requested relative to the technical, fiscal and legal qualifications of the applicant; the potential for development in the near future for the area requested; and the extent to which existing cable operators have installed facilities and equipment in the area. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. II, § 4), 10-4-88) 
Sec. 24.5-30. - Legal qualifications. 
(a)  Identification of applicant. All applications shall contain the name, address and telephone number of the applicant and of the principal or the representative to whom inquiries should be made. 
(b)  Ownership information. The applicant shall identify persons or other entities having ownership interest in the applicant, and for each such entity shall provide information as to names, addresses, amount of interest, type of interest, basis for acquiring ownership, existence of any buy-out agreements, and ownership interests in other media. 
(c)  Affiliates, subscribers and parent companies. [The applicant shall] provide full identification and ownership details, as in paragraph (b) above, for all affiliates, subsidiaries and parent companies of the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. II, § 5), 10-4-88) 
Sec. 24.5-31. - Character qualifications. 
(a)  Litigation and proceedings. The applicant shall supply all records applicable to any past or current involvement of the applicant or any of its principals or managers as a party in criminal or civil proceedings. The application shall also supply detailed information concerning whether the applicant or any principal, owner, director or manager of the applicant has ever been subject to a penalty for failure to comply with any cable television franchise, has been involved in any legal action involving any franchising authority, or has ever had any license of any type revoked or suspended, or had renewal denied. 
(b)  Other cable system operations. [The applicant shall] provide information as to other cable systems (including SMATV) owned by or affiliated with such applicant, the principals, or managers, including, location, miles of plant, percent completed, density of area served, number of homes passed, number of subscribers, channel capacity, services offered, rates charged and market penetration. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. II, § 6), 10-4-88) 
Sec. 24.5-32. - Financial qualifications and pro forma financial statements. 
(a)  Financial plan. Each application must describe in detail the financing plan for the construction and initial operation of the proposed cable communications system and provide proof of financial capability. Proof of financial capability shall include: 
(1)  A showing of sources and amount of equity capital. If equity contribution is borrowed, describe collateral and terms of the loan. All equity commitments must be evidenced by appropriate documentation. 
(2)  A showing of sources, amount and terms of debt capital, both primary and secondary accompanied by appropriate documentation. If funding is to be provided by any parent or affiliated equity, its source of funding must also be documented. 
(b)  Pro forma financial statements. Pro forma financial statements are required for a minimum of five (5) years beginning with the date the franchise is accepted. Such pro formas shall include income statements, sources and uses of funds, loan amortization information, anticipated capital expenditures, construction costs, depreciation schedules, and operating expenses, along with detailed assumptions on which the projections are based. 
(c)  If the applicant is an existing entity, a certified annual report for the last two (2) years shall be submitted or, if existing for less than two (2) years, for such period of existence. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. II, § 7), 10-4-88) 
Sec. 24.5-33. - Technical qualifications. 
    [The applicant shall] describe any qualifications and cable system experience, including, but not limited to, the ownership, construction, management, and operation of other cable communications systems specifying the manner in which the applicant participated; available personnel with technical qualifications and experience committed to the proposed system design, construction and operation; construction contractors to be used, if any; and technical consultants, if any. Indicate the type of participation and the qualifications of persons, consultants, contractors, etc. whose services will be utilized. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. II, § 8), 10-4-88) 
Sec. 24.5-34. - System construction plan. 
    The applicant shall submit to the office of the mayor or his designee a detailed construction plan supported by detailed maps indicating areas of construction and projected timeframes in six-month increments and showing the location of the facilities of any existing grantee within or immediately adjacent to these areas. The applicant shall demonstrate that sufficient pole and conduit space exists for the placement of its facilities and shall provide a copy of any agreement between the applicant and the utility providing for the use of any utility facilities. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. II, § 9), 10-4-88) 
Sec. 24.5-35. - System design; layout and equipment. 
    The franchise authority seeks a comprehensive, but concise, description of the proposed system design. Such description shall include the system configuration, the manufacturer and model of each type of equipment used, a spectrum utilization chart, and a complete list of all services, video or otherwise which will be offered. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. II, § 10), 10-4-88) 
Sec. 24.5-36. - Customer services. 
    The applicant shall set forth detailed plans for system maintenance, customer complaints, billing procedures and inquiries, subscriber privacy, and policies related to outages. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. II, § 11), 10-4-88) 
Sec. 24.5-37. - Impact of an additional grantee. 
    To assist the franchise authority in making its evaluation of the impact of additional grantees, the applicant shall provide detailed information relating to: 
(1)  The extent of installation of facilities and equipment of existing cable operators, detailing the per-strand-mile density of areas served, unserved areas and the per-strand-mile density of such and the location of the facilities and equipment of the existing operators in the area for which the applicant is applying; 
(2)  The per-strand-mile densities of the areas the applicant proposes to serve and the extent to which the applicant intends to utilize bulk contracts. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. II, § 12), 10-4-88) 
Secs. 24.5-38-24.5-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - REVIEW OF APPLICATION 

Sec. 24.5-46. - Initial review. 
    Upon the submission of an application for a franchise, the mayor or his designee shall review the application to ensure that all information provided is correct and that the applicant has the financial, technical and managerial background and resources to provide the proposed services. If necessary, the mayor or his designee may request an applicant to provide additional information. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. III, § 1), 10-4-88) 
Sec. 24.5-47. - Completeness of application. 
    The mayor or his designee shall accept, reject as incomplete or deficient, or accept with conditions, the application. Within sixty (60) days of receipt of the application, the mayor or his designee shall notify the applicant as to any facial deficiencies. Upon acceptance or, if accepted with conditions, upon the conditions being met, the mayor or his designee shall notify the city clerk to advertise the public hearing at which the franchise authority will consider the application. Existing grantee(s) and members of the public will be given an opportunity to submit relevant comments and the advertisement shall provide for at least a thirty-day period for the submission of such material. The public hearing shall commence after acceptance of the application by the mayor or his designee, or if accepted with conditions, after all conditions are met, but in no event sooner than thirty (30) days following the date on which written comments are due. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. III, § 2), 10-4-88) 
Sec. 24.5-48. - Summary report. 
    The mayor or his designee shall issue, or cause to be issued, a report summarizing the application which shall contain a recommendation to the franchise authority as to approval, denial, or approval with conditions. The franchise authority may obtain a consultant to perform studies and reviews to assist the mayor or his designee. In the event an application is filed proposing a franchise area which overlaps, in whole or in part, an existing grantee's franchise area, a consultant's report shall be obtained to address the factors set forth in section 24.5-57. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. III, § 3), 10-4-88) 
Secs. 24.5-49-24.5-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CONSIDERATION BY FRANCHISE AUTHORITY 

Sec. 24.5-56. - General evaluation criteria by franchise authority. 
    The franchise authority may consider the information and criteria set forth in section 24.5-26 et seq., and any other information it deems appropriate in determining whether to award a franchise. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. IV, § 1), 10-4-88) 
Sec. 24.5-57. - Evaluation criteria; desirability of an additional grantee. 
    In the event an application is filed proposing a franchise area which overlaps, in whole or in part, an existing grantee's franchise area, the franchise authority, in considering such application, shall take into account: 
(1)  The availability of space on existing poles and conduits; 
(2)  The likelihood that more than one (1) grantee can maintain financially feasible operations over an extended period of time so as to provide long-term benefits to subscribers; 
(3)  The impact on the financial and operating capability of existing grantees; 
(4)  The ability of the franchise authority to regulate multiple grantees; 
(5)  The disruption of public and private property by multiple grantees; 
(6)  The loss of uniformity of service as may be provided by a single grantee; 
(7)  The lack of economic viability of grantees to ensure the availability of high-quality cable service and other public benefits to the greatest number of Alexandria residents at the lowest economically feasible price; and 
(8)  Whether access to cable service might be denied to certain potential subscribers based on the income of residents of a particular area. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. IV, § 2), 10-4-88) 
Sec. 24.5-58. - Action by franchise authority. 
    Upon consideration of all relevant information and completion of the public hearing process, the franchise authority may reject the application, or award a franchise with or without conditions. 
(Ord. No. 229-1988, § 2(Art. IV, § 3), 10-4-88) 
Chapter 25 - TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Creation of noise with vehicles, § 13-31(b)(1), (5), (7), (10); throwing litter from vehicles, § 13-12; regulation of vehicles for hire, Ch. 27; soliciting patronage at bus station by driver of vehicle for hire, § 27-33. 
State Law reference- Prosecution of offense of driving while under influence, R.S. 13:1894.1. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 25-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, except where the context requires a different meaning, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
    Authorized emergency vehicle: Vehicles of the fire department, police vehicles, such ambulances designated or authorized by the chief of police, emergency repair trucks of the city, and doctors and physicians upon calls of necessity wherein life is imperiled. 
    Bicycle: A device having two (2) or three (3) wheels, with tires twenty (20) inches or more in diameter, connected by a frame of metal or wood and arranged to be propelled by human power. This definition does not apply to toy bicycles or velocipedes, or bicycles equipped with tires of less than twenty (20) inches in diameter. 
    Crosswalk: The portion of a roadway ordinarily included within the prolongation or connection of curb and property lines at intersections, or any other portion of a roadway clearly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on surface. 
    Curb: The lateral boundary of that portion of a street designated for the use of vehicles, whether marked by curbstones or not so marked. 
    Curb loading zone: A space adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passenger or materials. 
    Daytime: The time between one-half (1/2) hour before sunrise and one-half (1/2) hour after sunset. 
    Department : The Alexandria Police Department of the City of Alexandria Public Safety Division, its successor, or an authorized representative as determined by the chief of police. 
    Double parking: The parking of a vehicle outside of another vehicle which is parked at the curb. 
    Driver: Any driver, rider or leader of a horse or mule, and a person driving, operating or in charge of a vehicle. 
    Intersection: 
(1)  The area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curblines, or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of the roadways or two (2) highways which join one another at or approximately at right angles, or the area within which vehicles traveling upon different highways joining at any other angle may come in conflict. 
(2)  Where a highway includes two (2) roadways thirty (30) feet or more apart, then every crossing of each roadway of such divided highway by an intersecting highway shall be regarded as a separate intersection. In the event such intersecting highway also includes two (2) roadways thirty (30) feet or more apart, then every crossing of two (2) roadways of such highways shall be regarded as separate intersections. 
    Laned roadway: A roadway which is divided into two (2) or more clearly marked lanes for vehicular traffic. 
    Limit lines: Chalk, paint or whitewash, or similar lines marked upon the pavement, curb or sidewalks to indicate directions to be observed by drivers of vehicles or by pedestrians. 
    Motorcycle: Any motor vehicle having a saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor. 
    Motor vehicle: Any vehicle propelled on the streets of this city by mechanical power. 
    Nighttime: The time between one-half (1/2) hour after sunset and one-half (1/2) hour before sunrise. 
    Official traffic-control devices: All signs, signals, markings and devices not inconsistent with this chapter placed or erected by the authority of the mayor or city council for the purpose of regulating warning, or guiding traffic. 
    Owner : The owner of a motor vehicle as shown on the motor vehicle registration records of the Louisiana Department of Public Safety, Office of Motor Vehicles, or the analogous department or agency of another state or country. 
    Park: The standing of a vehicle, whether or not occupied, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading. 
    Pedestrian: Any person afoot or an infant or invalid in a carriage or wheel chair.
