    Photographic traffic signal enforcement system or system : A system that: 
(1)  Consists of a still camera system and full motion video camera system (thirty (30) frames per second or greater) installed to work in conjunction with an electrically operated traffic-control signal; and 
(2)  Is capable of producing at least three (3) separate recorded images 1) depicting the rear of a vehicle prior to entering the intersection on a red signal; 2) an image of the rear of the vehicle showing the license plate; and 3) an image of the rear of the vehicle in or through the intersection with the red signal visible that is not operated in compliance with the red-displays of the traffic-control signal. 
(3)  All images must be synchronized to a single time source and provide the elapsed time between the first, second and third photographs or digital images specified in subsection (2) above. 
    Photographic vehicle speed enforcement system : A system: 
(1)  Consisting of an electronic system; 
(2)  Capable of producing at least two (2) recorded images depicting the license plate attached to the rear of a vehicle being operated at a speed in excess of the speed limit on the subject roadway. 
    Police officer: Every officer of the police department or any officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic or to make arrests for violations of traffic regulations. 
    Private road or driveway: Every road or driveway not open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
    Railroad: A carrier of persons or property upon cars, other than streetcars, operated upon stationary rails. 
    Recorded image means an image recorded by a photographic traffic monitoring system depicting the rear of a motor vehicle and is automatically recorded as a photograph or digital image. 
    Right-of-way: The privilege of the immediate use of the roadway. 
    Roadway: The portion of a street or highway improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel. In the event a highway includes two (2) or more separate roadways the term "roadway" as used herein shall refer to any such roadway separately, but not to all such roadways collectively. 
    Safety zone: The area or space officially set apart within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians and which is protected or is so marked or indicated by adequate signs as to be plainly visible at all times while set apart as a safety zone. 
    Sidewalk: The portion of a street between the curblines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Sign: A device bearing printed or painted instructions which advise the public of any traffic regulation. 
    Signal: A visible sign given by hand or mechanical device or by automatic signal. 
    Standing: Any stopping of a vehicle, whether occupied or not. 
    Stop: When required, means complete cessation of movement. 
    Stop or stopping: When prohibited, means any stopping of a vehicle except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police officer or traffic-control sign or signal. 
    Street or highway: Any way or place of whatever nature open to the use of the public, as a matter of right for purpose of vehicular travel. 
    System location means the approach to an intersection where a photographic traffic signal enforcement system is directed and in operation. 
    Through street: Any street or highway or portion thereof at the entrances to which vehicular traffic from intersecting streets or highways is required by law to stop before entering or crossing the same and when stop signs are erected as provided in this chapter. 
    Traffic: Pedestrians, ridden, driven or herded animals, vehicles and other conveyances, either singly or together while using any street for purposes of travel. 
    Traffic-control signal: Any device, whether manually, electrically or mechanically operated, by which traffic is alternately directed to stop or proceed or is directed to proceed with caution. 
    Vehicle: Any conveyance used for the transportation of persons or merchandise running on wheels or rollers, including a draft or riding animal, whether driven, ridden or led, except a baby carriage or toy operated by a child, and an invalid chair. 
(Code 1956, §§ 6-2, 26-1; Ord. No. 87-2007, § 2, 3-28-2007) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:1. 
Sec. 25-2. - State law adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted by reference the provisions of Title 32, Chapter 1, Revised Statutes of Louisiana, being the Highway Regulatory Act, and all regulations of the state department of transportation and development and the director of public safety or other appropriate officer adopted pursuant thereto, except for such provisions and regulations as by their nature can have no application in the city, and except as otherwise provided in this Code or by ordinance. Any person violating said provisions or regulations shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
State Law reference- Power of city to adopt traffic code by reference, R.S. 32:41. 
Sec. 25-3. - Compliance with chapter. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate, or cause to be driven or operated, any motor or other vehicle upon the streets of the city in violation of the terms or provisions of this chapter or any traffic rule or regulation; punishment for such violations shall be as provided in section 1-8, except as otherwise provided herein. 
(Code 1956, §§ 26-2, 26-135) 
Sec. 25-4. - Powers and duties of city council to regulate traffic by signs, signals and markers, and to promulgate regulations. 
(a)  The city council shall have power to regulate the operation and parking of vehicles within the city by causing the erection or placing of proper signs and markers indicating limited or prohibited parking, restricted speed areas, parking meters, through or arterial streets, stop streets, U-turns, play streets, school zones, hospital zones, quiet zones, prohibited turns, or other signs or markers indicating the place and manner of operating or parking vehicles within the city; and shall have further power to designate crosswalks, safety zones, bus stops and taxicab stands and to erect signs prohibiting the parking of vehicles other than buses and taxicabs in such stands. The city council shall also have power to designate truck routes and to regulate the parking of vehicles of various sizes and weights. 
(b)  The council shall have power to cause all such necessary signs or markers to be erected or placed on any street or part of a street when it deems such action necessary. It shall also be the general duty of the city council to determine the installation and proper timing and maintenance of traffic-control signals. 
(c)  The council shall have power to mark off traffic lanes on streets and parts of streets indicating and directing the flow of traffic, when in its judgment such action is necessary. 
(d)  The city council shall have power, when it deems it in the interest of public safety or convenience, temporarily to close any street, alley or portion of the same to vehicular or foot traffic, or to divert such traffic therefrom. 
(e)  The existence of such signs, signals or markers at any place within the city shall be prima facie evidence that such signs, signals or markers were erected or placed by and at the direction of the city council and in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to comply with the directions indicated by any sign, signal or marker erected or placed in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(g)  Any regulations promulgated by the council shall become effective upon the erection of signs on the affected streets giving notice thereof. 
(h)  For administrative purposes, the council may delegate the authority to accomplish acts listed in paragraphs (a) through (d) to the administrative branch, by resolution. 
(Code 1956, § 26-3; Ord. No. 105-1981, § 1, 6-9-81) 
State Law reference- Powers of municipal authorities, R.S. 32:41; authority to establish traffic violations bureau, R.S. 13:1900. 
Sec. 25-5. - Enforcement by police; compliance with directions of police. 
(a)  The chief of police shall enforce the provisions of this chapter, all state vehicle laws applicable to street traffic in the city, and the rules and regulations adopted by the city council hereunder. 
(b)  A driver must at all times comply with any direction from a police officer by hand, voice, whistle or mechanical device. 
(c)  A police officer in order to expedite traffic or safeguard pedestrians, may disregard any traffic light, signal or established regulation when in his opinion an emergency exists. 
(Code 1956, §§ 26-4, 26-38) 
State Law reference- Authority of law enforcement officers to enforce state traffic laws, R.S. 32:5; obedience to police officers, R.S. 32:56. 
Sec. 25-6. - Authority of police and firemen in emergencies. 
(a)  Officers of the police department or such officers as are assigned by the chief of police are hereby authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand or signal in conformance with traffic laws, provided that, in the event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police department may direct traffic as conditions may require notwithstanding the provisions of the traffic laws. 
(b)  Officers of the fire department, when at the scene of a fire, may direct or assist the police in directing traffic thereat or in the immediate vicinity. 
(Code 1956, § 26-5) 
Sec. 25-7. - Notices and tickets from police department-Ignoring or failing to appear declared misdemeanor. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ignore a written notice or ticket from the police department signed by any officer thereof, directing such person to appear at the city police station and it shall be unlawful for any person to fail to appear at the city police station in response to a charge of violating any of the traffic ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1956, § 26-26) 
State Law reference- Similar provision as to violation of statute, R.S. 32:391; uniform traffic citations, R.S. 32:398.1 et seq. 
Sec. 25-8. - Same-Response by appearance within time designated; payment of fine or entering plea and requesting trial. 
    Where any such written notice or ticket has been issued, the party involved must respond to the notice, in person or through an authorized representative by appearing at the police station and paying the fine or by pleading not guilty and requesting that the case be placed on the docket of the city court for trial. Such appearance must be made within the time directed in the notice or ticket and failure to appear within such time shall be a violation of section 25-7 and this section. 
(Code 1956, § 26-27) 
Sec. 25-9. - Same-Penalty for violating sections. 
    Anyone who fails to appear in answer to such notice or otherwise violates section 25-7 or section 25-8 shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-8, regardless of the disposition of the charge upon which he was originally arrested or cited to appear. 
(Code 1956, § 26-28) 
Sec. 25-10. - State driver's license required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate any motor vehicle within the city unless such person has a valid license as an operator or chauffeur of a motor vehicle as required by R.S. 32:401 through R.S. 32:426, as amended. 
(Code 1956, § 26-29) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, R.S. 32:52. 
Sec. 25-11. - Age requirements for operation of motor vehicle, motorized bicycle or vehicle for hire. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person who is under the age of fifteen (15) years to operate a motor vehicle or motorized bicycle upon the streets of the city; provided that no person under the age of seventeen (17) years for a Class B license or under the age of eighteen (18) years for a license other than Class B chauffeur's license shall be permitted to operate any motor vehicle engaged in the transfer of persons or property for hire. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or knowingly permit his or her child or ward who is under the prohibited ages herein mentioned to operate a motor vehicle or motorized bicycle contrary to the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1956, § 26-37) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:198, 32:401 et seq. 
Sec. 25-12. - State license tag and registration. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, except those exempt by law, to drive or operate any motor vehicle upon the streets or public ways within the city unless such motor vehicle shall have attached thereto a valid vehicle license tag and registration issued by the state, if said person is a resident of the state, or duly issued by the state of the residence of said person if a nonresident of the state. 
(Code 1956, § 26-30) 
Cross reference- See also, §§ 25-150, 27-29. 
State Law reference- Similar provision, R.S. 32:51. 
Sec. 25-13. - Permits, licenses, registration, payment of taxes-Prerequisite to operation of vehicle. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle on the streets of the city or to permit the operation until all permits or licenses have been obtained, all taxes, if any, have been paid, and the vehicle has been properly registered as required by this chapter or any ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1956, § 26-33) 
Cross reference- See also, § 25-150. 
Sec. 25-14. - Same-Transfer trucks; payment of annual city license prerequisite to operating permit; fee; duration. 
    Every person, owning or operating any truck or other motor vehicle and engaged in the transfer of freight or property for hire on the streets of the city shall on or before March first of each year pay an annual license of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each vehicle so operating and shall before such date register each of such vehicles at police headquarters in the city and secure therefrom a permit to operate same over the streets of the city; permit shall not be granted until the license herein provided for has been paid. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to register the said motor vehicle and obtain the permit as hereinabove provided. 
(Code 1956, § 26-35) 
State Law reference- State registration and licensing, R.S. 47:461 et seq. 
Sec. 25-15. - Same-Authority of mayor to revoke permits for enumerated causes; appeal. 
    Any permit issued either to a private person or one operating trucks or other vehicles in the transfer of freight or property for hire shall be issued under authority of the mayor and may be revoked by him for habitual speeding, drunken driving, reckless driving or other legal cause, or such permits may be temporarily suspended by him. The owner or operator of any vehicle whose permit has been suspended or revoked may appeal to the city council within thirty (30) days after such suspension or revocation for a review of his case and shall have the right to be represented by counsel at any such hearing. 
(Code 1956, § 26-36) 
Sec. 25-16. - Reasonable care to be exercised to prevent accidents. 
    Nothing contained in or omitted from this chapter shall be construed or held to relieve any person using, traveling or being upon any street, for any purpose whatsoever, from exercising all reasonable care to avoid or prevent injury or damage through collision with all other persons and vehicles. 
(Code 1956, § 26-32) 
Cross reference- Reckless driving, § 25-45; duty in event of accident, § 15-5. 
State Law reference- Reasonable and proper control of vehicle, R.S. 32:58. 
Sec. 25-17. - Persons riding or driving animals to obey traffic regulations. 
    Every person riding an animal upon a street in the city, and every person driving any animal-drawn vehicle, shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the driver of any vehicle, except those provisions herein which by their very nature can have no application. 
(Code 1956, § 26-7) 
Cross reference- Compliance by bicycle riders, § 25-160. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:22. 
Sec. 25-18. - Use of coasters, roller skates and similar devices-Use of streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person upon roller skates or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device, to go upon any roadway except when crossing a street or a sidewalk. When so crossing, such person shall be granted all the rights of a pedestrian and shall be subject to all the duties applicable to pedestrians. This section shall not apply upon any street while set aside as a playstreet. 
(Code 1956, § 26-8) 
Sec. 25-19. - Same-Clinging to moving vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person riding upon any coaster, sled, roller skate or any toy vehicle to attach same or himself to any moving vehicle upon any roadway. 
(Code 1956, § 26-21) 
Cross reference- Towing of bicycle, etc., § 25-70; clinging by bicycle rider, § 25-163. 
Sec. 25-20. - Hitching or climbing onto moving vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hitch or climb on to any moving vehicle either with or without the consent of its operator; provided, this section shall not apply to the coupling of trailers or towing of other vehicles. 
(Code 1956, § 26-22) 
State Law reference- Clinging to vehicle, R.S. 32:191.2. 
Sec. 25-21. - Opening door of vehicle into line of traffic. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, whether entering or alighting from any vehicle, to open a door of such vehicle into a line of traffic, regardless of the position of the vehicle. 
(Code 1956, § 26-31) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, R.S. 32:283. 
Sec. 25-22. - Defacing or tearing down detour signs; driving onto closed streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to tear down or deface any detour sign, or to break down or to drive around any barricade erected for the purpose of closing any section of a street to traffic, or to drive over such section of street until again opened to public traffic; provided, however, this restriction shall not apply to the person in charge of any construction or repairs within such barricade, or any other person lawfully authorized to drive over such section. 
(Code 1956, § 26-10) 
Sec. 25-23. - Unnecessary noise from vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in charge or control of any vehicle to make with such vehicle, or any device connected therewith, any excessive noise to annoy the public, or unnecessarily race his motor while running idle, or to open the muffler on any vehicle, or to permit such vehicle, or any device thereon to cause the motor of such vehicle to backfire. 
(Code 1956, § 26-11) 
Cross reference- See also, § 13-31(b)(1), (5), (7), (10) and § 25-153(c). 
Sec. 25-24. - Parades; permit; driving through same; authority to route and close streets. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to plan, participate or otherwise engage in a parade unless permission for such parade shall have first been obtained from the mayor and the chief of police. The mayor and chief of police may designate the route of such parade. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or cause to be driven any vehicle through a parade or other procession except with the permission of a police officer. 
(c)  The mayor and/or chief of police may order any street or portion of street to be cleared of all vehicles during any parade, public gathering or celebration for which a permit has been issued. 
(Code 1956, § 26-12) 
Cross reference- Prohibited assemblies on streets, § 15-16. 
Sec. 25-25. - Transportation of explosives; permit required from city and state. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or driver of any vehicle transporting explosive substances or inflammable liquids to driver over the streets of the city without having first secured a special permit from the mayor, or his designated representative, covering such movement; and provided further that no vehicle transporting such explosive substances or inflammable liquids shall operate on the streets of the city until the owner or operator has obtained permission from the department of state police and has otherwise complied with the provisions of section 3 of Act 286 of 1938 regulating the transportation of such material. 
(Code 1956, § 26-15) 
State Law reference- Permit from department of public safety, R.S. 32:251. 
Sec. 25-26. - Height, width, length limits for vehicles and loads; red flag on end of extended loads; permits required when size exceeds specifications. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate any vehicle on the streets of the city having a total outside width exceeding ninety-six (96) inches; or having a height, whether loaded or unloaded, exceeding twelve (12) feet six (6) inches; or having a length exceeding thirty-three (33) feet, provided that no combination or train of vehicles shall exceed a total length of forty-five (45) feet. 
(b)  No vehicle shall carry a load extending more than six (6) inches beyond the fender line of the vehicle provided that the all-over width shall not exceed ninety-six (96) inches as heretofore provided. 
(c)  No vehicle or train of vehicles shall carry any load extending beyond the front thereof, nor more than eight (8) feet beyond the rear thereof, provided that whenever the load or any part extends beyond the rear of the body of the vehicle, there shall be displayed at the end of such load a red flag, or between sunset and sunrise a red light plainly visible. 
(d)  The mayor is authorized in case of emergency to grant a special permit for the operation of vehicles in excess of the width, height or length authorized herein provided that such permission is given in writing and is issued for a single trip or a specific movement and the route to be traveled is prescribed in such permission and proper precautions are taken to avoid injury or damage to person or property. 
(Code 1956, § 26-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:380, 32:381, 32:382; weight limitations, R.S. 32:386; flag and light required, R.S. 32:313. 
Sec. 25-27. - Dragging vehicle part or load upon paved street. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person driving any vehicle or contrivance to allow such vehicle or contrivance or any part of same, or any load or portion of load carried thereon, to drag upon any paved street in the city. 
(Code 1956, § 26-9) 
Sec. 25-28. - Vehicles discharging dense smoke. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, suffer or allow dense smoke to be discharged from any motor vehicle within the city. 
(Code 1956, § 26-23) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, R.S. 32:352, C. 
Sec. 25-29. - Meddling, interfering with, damaging or moving of vehicle by other than owner prohibited; exception. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who is not the owner, driver or operator of a vehicle to meddle, interfere with, damage or move said vehicle unless the vehicle is blocking a driveway, in which case any citizen may move the vehicle provided the moving is done without damage to the vehicle. However, any vehicle may be moved by or under the direction of a police officer by or under the direction of a fireman engaged in fighting a fire. 
(Code 1956, § 26-17) 
Cross reference- Damage to property generally, § 15-10. 
Sec. 25-30. - Riding on portions of vehicles not designed for passengers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ride on any motor vehicle or any portion thereof not designed or intended for the use of passengers, or for any operator of such vehicle to permit any person to ride on any portion not designed or intended for the use of passengers. This provision shall not apply to a person engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty, or to persons riding within truck bodies in spaces intended for merchandise. 
(Code 1956, § 26-19) 
Cross reference- Riding in lap of driver, § 25-43; riding on bicycle, § 25-164. 
State Law reference- Riding on fenders, etc., R.S. 32:284. 
Sec. 25-31. - Use of construction as an approach to driveways. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, maintain or use any kind of construction as an approach or entrance to any driveway which extends beyond the curb into any paved street in the city whether same is paved with brick, concrete or asphalt, or consists of planks, stones or other material. 
(Code 1956, § 26-20) 
Sec. 25-32. - Railroads-Maximum speed within city. 
    It shall be unlawful to run or cause to be run, any railroad engine, locomotive, car or train within the city at a speed exceeding forty-five (45) miles per hour. 
(Code 1956, § 26-24) 
Sec. 25-33. - Same-Blocking crossings; time limit; reblocking within specified time; application to through trains. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any railroad company, or its employees, or any other person, to block any public crossing over any railroad tracks within the city, or to obstruct or impede public passage over any of such public crossings with cars, engines or rolling stock of any such railroad company, or any other manner, for a longer period than five (5) minutes continuously; and having once blocked or obstructed the public crossing, it shall be unlawful for such railroad company, or its employees, or any other person, to reblock or reobstruct such public crossing until ten (10) minutes have elapsed. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not be so construed as to apply to through trains running over public crossings, provided that such trains, or any portion thereof, do not remain stationary upon such public crossing, or any part thereof. 
(Code 1956, § 26-25) 
State Law reference- Obstruction of highways, R.S. 45:324. 
Secs. 25-34-25-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Driving on rims, § 25-156. 

Sec. 25-40. - Driving while mentally or physically deficient. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a motor vehicle on the streets of the city who is mentally or physically deficient to such an extent as to be unable to properly and safely operate such vehicle. 
(Code 1956, § 26-41) 
Sec. 25-41. - Operation of motorcycles, motor-driven cycles, etc. 
(a)  All motor-driven cycles, motorcycles and machines of a similar nature shall be driven or operated on the right side of the center line of the street. 
(b)  No such machines shall be operated or driven two (2) or more abreast, but shall be operated or driven in single file. 
(c)  No such machine shall be operated upon the sidewalks. 
(d)  Every operator of a motorcycle, motor bicycle or similar machine shall at all times maintain perfect control of the machine and is prohibited from coasting or taking both hands from the handlebars or steering mechanism when riding or driving such machine. 
(Code 1956, § 26-133) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:191.1. 
Sec. 25-42. - Number of persons in front seat restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver or the person in charge of any motor vehicle to permit more than three (3) persons, including the driver, to ride in the front or driver's seat of a motor vehicle. 
(Code 1956, § 26-13) 
State Law reference- See R.S. 32:282. 
Sec. 25-43. - Persons in lap of driver; driver in lap of other person. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, adult or minor, to be in the lap of the driver of any motor vehicle in the city while the motor vehicle is in operation, including any stopping in a roadway. 
(b)  It shall also be unlawful for the driver of a motor vehicle to be seated in the lap of any other person while the motor vehicle is in operation, including any stopping in a roadway. 
(Code 1956, § 26-14) 
Sec. 25-44. - Number of riders on motorcycles, etc. 
    Not more than one person shall ride upon any motor-driven cycle, motorcycle or machine of a similar nature, unless and except a regulation seat is provided for an additional passenger as manufactured and approved by the Standard Motorcycle Manufacturers, except that passengers may be carried in a side car attached to the machine, and then no more persons shall ride on the machine than provision is made for by proper seating arrangement on the machine itself or in the side car. 
(Code 1956, § 26-134) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:191, 32:192. 
Sec. 25-45. - Reckless driving; excessive speed. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle upon the streets of the city carelessly and heedlessly in disregard of the rights or the safety of others. Regardless of the maximum speed limits authorized in this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate any vehicle upon the streets of the city at any speed that is not prudent and proper, having due regard to the traffic, the nature of the street, the location, the neighborhood and other conditions or circumstances existing. 
(Code 1956, § 26-42) 
Cross reference- Exercise of care to prevent accident, § 25-16. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:99; drag racing, racing, R.S. 32:65; reasonable and proper control, R.S. 32:58. 
Sec. 25-46. - Speed limits generally; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate any motor vehicle on the streets of the city at any place within the corporate limits at rates of speed higher than those established by this article. 
(b)  The mayor is authorized to post speed limits within the city limits in accordance with the following guidelines. 
(1)  Speed limits on residential streets in the city shall not exceed twenty-five (25) miles per hour. 
(2)  Speed limits on collector streets shall not exceed thirty-five (35) miles per hour. 
(3)  Speed limits on arterial streets shall not exceed forty-five (45) miles per hour. 
(c)  The mayor may reduce these limits on particular streets if safety conditions warrant. 
(d)  This article applies only to nonstate routes within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1956, §§ 26-43, 26-132; Ord. No. 71-2002, § I, 3-5-2002) 
Cross reference- Speed in parks, § 25-65; speed of trains, § 25-32; speed of bicycles, § 25-164. 
State Law reference- Reasonable and prudent speed, R.S. 32:64. 
Sec. 25-47. - Reserved. 
Sec. 25-48. - Exemption from speed limits for emergency vehicles. 
    The speed limitation set forth herein shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles. This exemption shall not however, protect the driver or operator of such vehicles from the consequences of a reckless disregard of the safety of others. 
(Code 1956, § 26-45) 
Sec. 25-49. - Following another vehicle. 
    The driver of a motor vehicle shall not follow another vehicle more closely than is reasonable and prudent having due regard to the speed of such vehicle and the traffic upon the street. The driver of a vehicle following another must operate at such speed and at such a distance behind that he can stop without striking the vehicle in front of him should the latter come to a sudden stop. 
(Code 1956, § 26-48) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:81. 
Sec. 25-50. - Driving on right side of road; procedure in passing vehicles proceeding in same direction and opposite direction. 
(a)  Except upon one-way streets, the operator of a vehicle shall drive the same upon the right of the center line of the street, and if the vehicle is operating at a very slow speed the driver thereof shall keep as close to the right-hand curb of such street as possible. This regulation shall not apply where it is impractical to travel on the right side of the street or when overtaking and passing another vehicle going in the same direction. 
(b)  Drivers of vehicles proceeding in opposite directions shall pass each other to the right. 
(c)  The driver of any vehicle overtaking another proceeding in the same direction shall pass same to the left and at a safe distance therefrom and shall not again drive to the right side of the street until clear of the overtaken vehicle. 
(Code 1956, § 26-46) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:71, 32:72, 32:73, 32:74. 
Sec. 25-51. - Overtaking and passing on left in hazardous zones prohibited. 
    On those portions of the streets of the city where overtaking and passing, or driving to the left of the roadway would be hazardous, and where appropriate signs or markings on the roadway indicate the beginning and end of such zones, and when such signs and markings are clearly visible to an ordinarily observant person, every driver shall obey the directions thereof; and where signs or markings are in place to define a no passing zone, no driver shall at any time drive on the left side of the roadway within such zone, or on the left side of any pavement striping, designated to mark such no passing zone, throughout its length. 
(Code 1956, § 26-42.1) 
State Law reference- Limitations on passing on left, R.S. 32:75, 32:76. 
Sec. 25-52. - Passing vehicle proceeding in same direction; passing at certain places prohibited; overtaken vehicle to give way; procedure when meeting school bus. 
(a)  The driver of an overtaking vehicle in passing a vehicle proceeding in the same direction shall not drive to the left of the center line of the street unless the left side of the street is visible and free from oncoming traffic for a sufficient distance ahead to permit such passing to be made in safety. 
(b)  The driver of a vehicle shall not under any circumstances overtake or pass another vehicle at any railroad grade crossing or any street intersection. 
(c)  The driver of a vehicle who has been given adequate warning by an overtaking vehicle approaching from the rear shall promptly give way to the right in favor of such passing vehicle and shall not increase the speed of his vehicle until it has been overtaken and passed. 
(d)  The driver of any vehicle meeting or overtaking any school bus which has stopped or is about to stop for the purpose of discharging or receiving school children shall bring his vehicle to a full and complete stop at least thirty (30) feet from the rear or front of such bus as the case may be and shall remain stationary until those alighting therefrom have reached the sidewalk or entered the bus and shall not proceed until every precaution has been taken to avoid any possible injury to such children, and in compliance with state law. 
(Code 1956, § 26-47) 
State Law reference- See R.S. 32:75, 32:76, 32:80. 
Sec. 25-53. - Turning at intersections. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle intending to turn at an intersection shall make such turn at a speed not exceeding ten (10) miles per hour. 
(b)  When the turn is to the right, the driver shall approach the intersection in the lane of traffic nearest the right-hand side of the street and in turning shall keep as close as practical to the right-hand curb of the street. 
(c)  When the turn is to the left, the driver shall approach the intersection in the lane of traffic nearest to the center of the street and shall not cut the corner but shall, before turning, pass beyond the center of the intersecting streets. 
(Code 1956, § 26-49) 
State Law reference- See R.S. 32:101 et seq. 
Sec. 25-54. - "U" turns. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make a "U" turn or a complete turn in the street with any vehicle. 
(Code 1956, § 26-79) 
Sec. 25-55. - Starting, stopping or turning from direct line; hand signals. 
    The driver of a vehicle upon the streets of the city before starting or turning from a direct line, or from a parked position, shall first see and ascertain if such movement can be made in safety; and if any pedestrian may be affected by such movement the driver of the vehicle shall give a signal by sounding his horn. Whenever the operation of any other vehicle on the street may be affected by such movement, the driver shall give a signal of his intention to make such movement, either by using an electrical or mechanical signalling device installed upon his vehicle, clearly indicating his proposed movement, or by extending his arm from the driver's side of the vehicle in the following manner: for a left turn the arm to be extended horizontally, and for a right turn, the arm to be extended upward at an angle of forty-five (45) degrees, and for a start or stop the arm to be extended downward at an angle of forty-five (45) degrees, with the hand open and the back of the hand to the rear. 
(Code 1956, §§ 26-50, 26-66.1, 26-131) 
State Law reference- See R.S. 32:104 et seq. 
Sec. 25-56. - Yielding right-of-way at intersections for other vehicles, pedestrians, emergency vehicles. 
(a)  When two (2) vehicles approach or enter an intersection at approximately the same time where both streets have equal right-of-way, the driver approaching from the right shall have the right-of-way. The driver of a vehicle approaching but not having entered an intersection shall yield the right-of-way to a vehicle within such intersection. 
(b)  The driver of any vehicle shall yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian lawfully crossing the street at any regular pedestrian crossing except in cases where the movement of traffic is being regulated by traffic officers or traffic signals. Every pedestrian crossing a street at any point other than a regular pedestrian crossing or intersection shall yield the right-of-way to vehicles on the streets. 
(c)  The driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way to police and fire department vehicles and hospital ambulances when operated upon official business or emergency errands provided the drivers thereof have given audible signal by bell, siren or whistle. 
(Code 1956, § 26-51) 
State Law reference- Yielding right-of-way, R.S. 32:122, 32:211 et seq. 
Sec. 25-57. - Operation of vehicles on approach of authorized emergency vehicle; following or parking within specified distance. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the driver of every vehicle on the streets of the city upon the approach of any police or fire department vehicle or hospital ambulance which is giving an audible signal, to immediately drive to a position as near as possible to the right-hand edge of the curb or side of the street clear of any intersection and to stop and remain in such position until the police or fire department vehicle or hospital ambulance shall have passed and the way is clear. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle other than one on official business to follow any authorized emergency vehicle traveling in response to an official call of duty closer than five hundred (500) feet, or to drive into or park such vehicle within the block where such vehicle has stopped in answer to an official call. 
(Code 1956, § 26-52) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:125, 32:286. 
Sec. 25-58. - Driving over fire hose. 
    It shall be unlawful for any driver or operator of any vehicle to drive same over any unprotected fire hose without the consent of the fire department official in command. 
(Code 1956, § 26-54) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, R.S. 32:287. 
Sec. 25-59. - Operation of private, passenger and bus vehicles at railroad crossings. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to cross any grade crossing of a public street and a railroad when warned by automatic signals, crossing gates, flagman, traffic officers or any other means of the immediate approach of a railroad train or car. 
(b)  The driver of any motor bus or other vehicle carrying passengers for hire, or the driver of any school bus or other vehicle transporting school teachers or children to or from any institution of learning, shall under no circumstances traverse such crossing when warned by signals of the approach of a railway train or car, nor shall the driver of such a vehicle traverse such crossing where his view is obstructed without stopping and making certain that no train or car is approaching such crossing. 
(Code 1956, § 26-53) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:171 et seq. 
Sec. 25-60. - Operation of vehicles passing churches holding services, hospitals or quiet zones. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver or operator of any vehicle while passing churches, during the progress of services, or hospitals, or quiet zones, where signs are displayed showing the nature of the neighborhood, to make any unnecessary noises by the blowing of horns, racing of motors or other disturbing noises. 
(Code 1956, § 26-55) 
Sec. 25-61. - Driving through procession. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person except the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle to drive a motor or other vehicle through a procession unless by permission of a police or traffic officer. This provision shall not apply at intersections where traffic is controlled by police officers. 
(Code 1956, § 26-56) 
Sec. 25-62. - Driving in processions. 
    Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the right-hand edge of the roadway as practical and shall follow the vehicle ahead as closely as is practical and safe. 
(Code 1956, § 26-57) 
Sec. 25-63. - Limitations on backing. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle shall not back the same unless such movement can be made with reasonable safety and without interfering with other traffic. 
(b)  The driver of a vehicle shall not back the same upon any shoulder or roadway of any controlled-access highway except as a result of an emergency caused by an accident or breakdown of a motor vehicle. 
(Code 1956, §§ 26-66.1(d), 26-80) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:281. 
Sec. 25-64. - Driving on sidewalks, grounds of public parks, or areas not open to traffic. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate any vehicle upon the sidewalks of the city or over or across any corner or portion thereof or for any person to drive or operate any vehicle upon or across the grounds of any of the public parks of the city or upon any areas not open to traffic or upon any other places except the streets, driveways and parking areas which are opened and designated for use by vehicles. 
(Code 1956, § 26-59) 
Sec. 25-65. - Regulations in public parks-Speed limit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate any motor vehicle at a rate of speed exceeding fifteen (15) miles per hour on any of the streets, driveways and roads within any of the public parks of the city, provided that this provision shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles. 
(Code 1956, § 26-60) 
Sec. 25-66. - Same-Operation of vehicle at stop or safety zone signs. 
    All motor and other vehicles approaching any street, road or other intersection within the public parks of the city at which intersections there have been placed "Stop" or safety zone signs, shall be brought to a full stop at or near enough to such intersections and the driver shall not proceed until the way is clear. 
(Code 1956, § 26-61) 
Sec. 25-67. - Vehicle projecting into crosswalk. 
    It shall be unlawful for vehicles which are required to stop for any street or park road intersection to have any part of said vehicle projecting into the boundaries of the crosswalk reserved for pedestrians. 
(Code 1956, § 26-61) 
Sec. 25-68. - Emerging from alley or private driveway. 
    The driver of a vehicle, emerging from an alley, driveway, or building, shall stop such vehicle immediately prior to driving onto a sidewalk, or onto the sidewalk area extending across any alleyway, yielding the right-of-way to any pedestrian as may be necessary to avoid collision, and upon entering the roadway shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on such roadway. 
(Code 1956, § 26-62) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:124. 
Sec. 25-69. - Blocking traffic. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to block traffic. 
(Code 1956, § 26-75) 
Cross reference- Stopping in street, § 25-96. 
Sec. 25-70. - Towing of motorcycles, motor-driven cycles or bicycles by motor vehicles. 
    Drivers, riders or operators of motor-driven cycles, motorized bicycles, bicycles, motorcycles or similar machines are prohibited from holding on and being pulled or towed by any vehicle, which prohibition applies to the drivers of the towing vehicle and the towed vehicle. 
(Code 1956, § 26-130) 
Cross reference- Clinging to vehicle, §§ 25-19, 25-163. 
State Law reference- Clinging, R.S. 32:191.2. 
Sec. 25-71. - Horseback riding on public property prohibited; exception. 
    Horseback riding is prohibited on the public rights-of-way and on all public property within the city limits of the City of Alexandria, including streets, sidewalks, alleyways, and parks. Provided further that this shall not apply to horses being ridden by members of the Alexandria Police Department while engaged in their official capacity or to horses being ridden in a permitted parade. 
(Ord. No. 129-1999, § 1, 6-15-99) 
Sec. 25-72. - Crossing or traversing a police barricade or traffic-control device or warning or disregarding orders or directions during flooding or other natural disasters or other events. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any for any person to drive or operate a motor vehicle and cross or traverse a police barricade or traffic-control device or warning or disregard orders or directions during flooding or other natural disasters or other events, except pursuant to a lawful order from a police officer. For the purpose of this section a police barricade or traffic-control device or warning means any impediment or structure erected or established by a police officer or traffic control officer to prevent and/or obstruct the passage of motor vehicles on a city street during flooding, natural disasters or other such events, including traffic-control devices such as a barricade or other sign or warning, including but not limited to, wooden, rope, cable, wire or metal barricades or cordons, traffic control devices specified by the uniform manual for traffic control devices or other warnings or barricades posted by police officers or city employees during times of flooding, natural disasters or other similar events. 
(b)  Violation, penalty. Any person violating the provision of this section shall, upon conviction, be fined five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not exceeding sixty (60) days or be sentenced to both such fine or imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 78-2009, § I, 4-7-09) 
Secs. 25-73-25-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIGNS, SIGNALS AND MARKERS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Powers of mayor to use, § 25-4. 

Sec. 25-80. - Ratification of those existing. 
    The location and existence of all traffic-control signs, signals, devices and markings which are in place on the adoption date of this Code of Ordinances are hereby ratified and confirmed and such signs, signals, etc., shall be considered to have been authorized by the city council. 
Sec. 25-81. - Obedience to traffic-control devices. 
    The driver of any vehicle shall obey the instructions of any official traffic-control device applicable thereto placed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter or any ordinance, unless otherwise directed by a traffic or police officer, subject to the exceptions granted the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle in this chapter. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:231. 
Sec. 25-82. - Traffic lights-Signal legend. 
    The following rules shall govern the movement of traffic at those street intersections where such semaphore or light signals are maintained: 
(1)  Steady red light. When a steady red light shows on such signal, traffic moving in the direction of the light shall stop and remain stopped as long as the light is showing, except that, unless a sign indicates to the contrary, after stopping, the driver of the vehicle may turn right against a steady red light and a driver of a vehicle on a one-way street may, in addition, turn left, provided that in either case the driver has yielded the right-of-way to other vehicles and pedestrians and can execute the turn safely in such a manner that the vehicle's movement does not interfere with vehicles and pedestrians crossing on the green light, which vehicles and pedestrians shall have the right-of-way. 
(2)  Green light. When a green light shows on any such traffic signal, traffic moving in the direction of said light shall proceed and remain in motion as long as the green signal is shown. It shall be unlawful for anyone to stop a vehicle while moving in the direction of a green light, unless traffic is obstructed before, at or immediately beyond the intersection, in such driver's lane. 
(3)  Amber or yellow light. When amber or yellow shows on any traffic signal, it shall indicate that a change is about to be made in the direction of the flow of traffic. Vehicles which have not already entered the intersection shall stop when the amber light shows. Vehicles which are already in the intersection shall continue to move forward until clear of the intersection. It shall be unlawful to enter an intersection while the amber light is on. 
(Code 1956, § 26-67; Ord. No. 14-1978, § 1, 1-24-78) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:232. 
Sec. 25-83. - Same-Blinker lights. 
    At those street intersections where amber or caution blinker lights are installed, it shall be the duty of the driver or operator of a vehicle to slow down and bring the vehicle under complete control so as to be able to come to an immediate stop. Where such blinker lights are red, the driver thereof shall bring the vehicle to a full stop and then not proceed until the way is clear. 
(Code 1956, § 26-69) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:234. 
Sec. 25-84. - Same-Red signal at railroad crossing. 
    At railroad crossings where the light signals show red, the driver or operator of any vehicle approaching such crossing must come to a full stop and remain stopped as long as such light is showing. It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to approach nearer than fifteen (15) feet of any track at such crossing while the red light is showing. 
(Code 1956, § 26-68) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:171. 
Sec. 25-85. - Same-Attempting to evade signals. 
    The establishment and operation of traffic light signals are for the protection of the traveling public, both vehicular and pedestrian, and it shall be unlawful for any person to attempt to evade the effect of such signals by any subterfuge. It is accordingly unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to drive through any corner filling station or any other vacant corner when either the red or amber light is showing at the intersection in the direction in which such vehicle is traveling. 
(Code 1956, § 26-70) 
Sec. 25-85.1. - Imposition of civil penalty for violations enforced by photographic traffic signal or vehicle speed enforcement system. 
(a)  The city council finds and determines vehicles exceeding the speed limit or proceeding into an intersection when the traffic control signal for that vehicle's direction of travel is emitting a steady red signal damages the public by endangering motor vehicle operators and pedestrians alike, by decreasing the efficiency of traffic control and traffic flow efforts, and by increasing the number of serious traffic crashes to which public safety agencies must respond at the expense of the taxpayers. 
(b)  Except as provided in subsections (c) and (d) below, the owner of a motor vehicle is liable for a civil penalty of one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00) if the motor vehicle proceeds into an intersection at a system location when the traffic control signal for that motor vehicle's direction of travel is emitting a steady red signal or for civil penalty as shown in the following table if the vehicle is traveling at a speed in miles per hour (mph) greater than the speed limit on the subject roadway: 
5-10 mph over speed limit $25.00 civil penalty 11-15 mph over speed limit $50.00 civil penalty 16-20 mph over speed limit $100.00 civil penalty Greater than 20 mph over speed limit $150.00 civil penalty  
(c)  For a second or subsequent traffic signal violation of the same motor vehicle during any twelve-month period, the amount of the civil penalty assessed to the owner of that vehicle shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) for a red light violation. For a second or subsequent speed limit violation of the same motor vehicle during any twelve-month period, the amount of the civil penalty assessed to the owner of that vehicle shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) in addition to the applicable civil penalty set forth in the above table. 
(d)  An owner who fails to timely pay a civil penalty shall be subject to an additional late payment penalty of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) in addition to the original violation penalty. 
(Ord. No. 87-2007, § 2, 3-28-2007) 
Sec. 25-85.2. - Enforcement; procedures. 
(a)  The department is responsible for the enforcement and administration of sections 25-85.1 through 25-85.5 inclusive. The department may enforce and administer sections 25-85.1 through 25-85.5, or any parts thereof, through one (1) or more contractors selected in accordance with applicable law. If the department uses a contractor for any portion of the enforcement or administration of this article, except an administrative hearing officer as described in subsection 25-85.2(b), then the contractor shall meet the following minimum criteria: (1) The contractor selected by the department must be able to demonstrate five (5) years of continuous operations of similar digital photo enforcement programs in municipalities in the United States; (2) Must have three (3) years of audited financials that show acceptable profitability; (3) Must have sufficient financial resources to perform the contract or provide the services; and (4) Must be able to provide a performance bond comparable to the scope of the photo enforcement program. 
(b)  The actions which can be used to enforce the payment of this civil penalty and related fees may consist of but not be limited to immobilization of vehicles (booting), reporting the debt to collection agencies/credit reporting agencies, and/or initiating actions through the appropriate court. 
(c)  In order to impose a civil penalty under this article, the department shall mail a notice of violation to the owner of the motor vehicle liable for the civil penalty not later than the fourteenth calendar day inclusive of legal holidays and weekends after the date the violation is alleged to have occurred. 
(d)  A notice of violation issued under this article shall contain the following: 
(1)  A description of the violation alleged; 
(2)  The date, time, and location of the violation; 
(3)  A copy of a recorded image of the vehicle involved in the violation; 
(4)  The amount of the civil penalty to be imposed for the violation; 
(5)  The date by which the civil penalty must be paid; 
(6)  A statement the person named in the notice of violation may pay the civil penalty in lieu of appearing at an administrative adjudication hearing; 
(7)  Information informing the person named in the notice of violation: 
a.  Of the right to contest the imposition of the civil penalty in an administrative adjudication; 
b.  Of the manner and time in which to contest the imposition of the civil penalty; and 
c.  Failure to pay the civil penalty or to contest liability is a waiver of the right to appeal. 
(8)  A statement that a recorded image is evidence in a proceeding for the imposition of a civil penalty; 
(9)  A statement indicating failure to pay the civil penalty within the time allowed shall result in the imposition of an additional late penalty of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for each violation; and 
(10)  Any other information deemed necessary by the department. 
(e)  A notice of violation under this article is presumed to have been received on the tenth calendar day inclusive of weekends and legal holidays after the date the notice of violation is mailed. 
(f)  Once an intersection or roadway has been equipped with a photographic traffic signal enforcement system or a photographic vehicle speed enforcement system, the city council shall adopt by resolution a date for the department to begin issuing civil citations. Prior to this established date, the department may issue warning notices of the alleged violations as part of an education/ public notification effort. 
(Ord. No. 87-2007, § 2, 3-28-2007) 
Sec. 25-85.3. - Administrative adjudication hearing. 
(a)  A person who receives a notice of violation may contest the imposition of the civil penalty by a request in writing for an administrative adjudication of the civil penalty within thirty (30) calendar days inclusive of weekends and legal holidays after receipt of the notice of violation and posting a cash bond for the total amount due plus thirty dollars ($30.00), including late penalty. Upon receipt of a timely request and cash bond, the department shall notify the person of the date and time of the administrative adjudication hearing. 
(b)  Administrative adjudications of violations of section 25-85.1 shall be conducted by the city attorney who shall serve as administrative hearing officer or who may designate an administrative hearing officer(s) who shall preside at all hearings provided in this section. Any officer so designated shall be a duly licensed attorney in good standing who has been admitted to practice law in this state. 
(c)  Failure to pay a civil penalty or to contest liability in a timely manner is a waiver of the right to appeal under subsection 25-85.3(h). 
(d)  The civil penalty shall not be assessed if after a hearing, the hearing officer enters a finding of no liability. 
(e)  In an administrative adjudication hearing, the issues must be proved at the hearing by a preponderance of the evidence. The reliability of the system used to produce the recorded image of the violation may be attested to in an administrative adjudication hearing by affidavit of an officer of the department or of the superintendent of traffic, department of public works. An affidavit from a sworn law enforcement officer or from the traffic superintendent that alleges a violation based on an inspection of the pertinent recorded image is admissible in a proceeding under this article and is evidence of the facts contained in the affidavit. 
(f)  A person who is found liable after an administrative adjudication hearing or who requests an administrative adjudication hearing and thereafter fails to appear at the time and place of the hearing shall forfeit their cash bond amount noted in subsection 25-85.3(a). 
(g)  It shall be an affirmative defense to the imposition of civil liability under this article, to be proven by a preponderance of the evidence, that: 
(1)  As to red light violations, the traffic-control signal was not in proper position and sufficiently legible to an ordinarily observant person; 
(2)  The operator of the motor vehicle was acting in compliance with the lawful order or direction of a law enforcement or public safety officer; 
(3)  As to red light violations, the operator of the motor vehicle violated the instructions of the traffic-control signal so as to yield the right-of-way to an immediately approaching authorized emergency vehicle; 
(4)  The motor vehicle was being operated as an authorized emergency vehicle under La. R.S. 32:24, and the operator was acting in compliance with La. R.S. 32:24; 
(5)  The motor vehicle was being operated by a person other than the owner of the vehicle without the effective consent of the owner; 
(6)  The license plate depicted in the recorded image of the violation was a stolen plate and being displayed on a motor vehicle other than the motor vehicle for which the plate had been issued; 
(7)  The presence of ice, snow, unusual amounts of rain or other unusually hazardous road conditions existed that would make compliance with this article more dangerous under the circumstances than non-compliance; 
(8)  The person who received the notice of violation was not the owner of the motor vehicle at the time of the violation; or 
(9)  At the time of the violation the motor vehicle was a stolen vehicle or the license plate displayed on the motor vehicle was a stolen plate, which must include proof acceptable to the hearing officer that the theft of the vehicle or license plate had been timely reported to the appropriate law enforcement agency. 
(h)  Notwithstanding anything in this article to the contrary, a person who fails to pay the amount of a civil penalty or to contest liability in a timely manner is entitled to an administrative adjudication hearing on the violation if: 
(1)  The person files an affidavit with the hearing officer stating the date on which the person received the notice of violation mailed to the person; and 
(2)  The person files a request for an administrative hearing within thirty (30) days from the date of receipt of the notice of violation, as stated in the affidavit. 
(i)  The decision of the hearing officer shall be the final decision by the city. A person or persons aggrieved by a decision may file a petition for judicial review to the District Court of the Parish of Rapides, within thirty (30) days after the date of entry of the decision. 
(Ord. No. 87-2007, § 2, 3-28-2007) 
Sec. 25-85.4. - Order of hearing officer. 
    The hearing officer at any administrative adjudication hearing under this article shall issue an order stating: 
(1)  Whether the person charged with the violation is liable for the violation; and 
(2)  The amount of any civil penalty, late penalty, and administrative adjudication cost assessed against the person. 
(Ord. No. 87-2007, § 2, 3-28-2007) 
Sec. 25-85.5. - Effect of liability; exclusion of civil remedy. 
(a)  The imposition of a civil penalty under this article shall not be considered a criminal conviction. 
(b)  A civil penalty may not be imposed under this article upon the owner of a motor vehicle if the operator of the vehicle was arrested or was issued a citation and notice to appear by a law or public safety officer as a violation of applicable state or municipal law pertaining to traffic control obedience or speed limit violations, if such violation was captured by the System. 
(c)  The city attorney is authorized to file suit to enforce collection of unpaid fines and/or related fees and penalties imposed hereunder by lawful means to secure such payments. 
(Ord. No. 87-2007, § 2, 3-28-2007) 
Sec. 25-86. - Same-Application. 
    Sections 25-82 through 25-85 shall apply to motor vehicles and also to bicycles, horse drawn vehicles and every other form of vehicular travel, and to pedestrians where appropriate. 
(Code 1956, § 26-71) 
Sec. 25-87. - Display of unauthorized signs, signals or markers. 
(a)  No person shall place, maintain or display upon or in view of any street or highway any unauthorized sign, signal, marking or device, defined as one which is not an official device, authorized by public authority, which purports to be or is an imitation of or resembles an official traffic-control device or railroad sign or signal, or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic, or which hides from view or interferes with the effectiveness of any traffic-control device or any railroad sign or signal; and no person shall place or maintain nor shall any public authority permit upon any street any traffic signal or sign bearing thereon any commercial advertising. This shall not be deemed to prohibit the erection on private property adjacent to streets of signs giving useful directional information and of a type that cannot be mistaken for official signs, nor to prohibit authorized construction barricades or warnings. 
(b)  Every such prohibited sign, signal or marking is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and the chief of police is hereby empowered to remove the same or cause it to be removed without notice. 
(Code 1956, § 26-72) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:236. 
Sec. 25-88. - Interference with signs. 
    It shall be unlawful to willfully and without legal authority move, destroy, deface, change the wording of, or otherwise interfere with any sign erected or established by the city or the authorities thereof. 
(Code 1956, § 26-73) 
Secs. 25-89-25-94. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 25-95. - Leaving motor of vehicle running while unattended. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to allow or permit the machinery of any motor vehicle driven or operated or caused to be driven or operated by him to run while such vehicle is standing or parked in any street or public place without an attendant. 
(Code 1956, § 26-58) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:145. 
Sec. 25-96. - Stopping in street. 
    Except in an emergency or for the purpose of allowing another vehicle or pedestrian to cross, no vehicle shall be permitted to stop in any street or public way in the city, other than in designated parking spaces near the curb. When it is desired to stop any vehicle being driven along the street, before such vehicle is stopped the driver shall give the signal in the manner provided in section 25-55 which shall plainly indicate an intention and desire to stop the vehicle of which he is in charge. 
(Code 1956, § 26-74) 
Cross reference- Blocking traffic, § 25-69. 
State Law reference- See R.S. 32:141. 
Sec. 25-97. - Double parking. 
    Double parking is prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to stop or permit to stand on the street any vehicle when there is another vehicle between it and the curb, except where same is necessary in the observance of traffic signals or is unavoidable because of the presence of another vehicle ahead. 
(Code 1956, § 26-77) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, R.S. 32:143, A (12). 
Sec. 25-98. - Parking, stopping or standing within intersection. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park or stop or permit to stand any vehicle within any street intersection. 
(Code 1956, § 26-78) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, R.S. 32:143, A (3). 
Sec. 25-99. - Parking backed to curb. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver or operator of any vehicle to allow said vehicle to stand backed up at any angle to the curb, except while actually loading and unloading. 
(Code 1956, § 26-81) 
Sec. 25-100. - Parking in alleys. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten (10) feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic, and no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such a position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. 
(Code 1956, § 26-82) 
Sec. 25-101. - Stopping, standing or parking in passenger curb loading zone. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger curb loading zone during the hours when the regulations applicable to such curb loading zone are effective. 
(Code 1956, § 26-83) 
Sec. 25-102. - Parking or stopping within area designated as a bus stop. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park or stop any vehicle within any area designated as a bus stop for vehicles of the municipal bus system. 
(Code 1956, § 26-85) 
Sec. 25-103. - Stopping, standing or parking in freight loading zones. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading, delivery or pick-up of materials in any place marked as a freight curb loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect. 
(Code 1956, § 26-84) 
Sec. 25-104. - Parking on sidewalks, lawns, playgrounds of school property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle on the sidewalks, lawns or playgrounds of public school property in the city. 
(Code 1956, § 26-89) 
Sec. 25-105. - Parking within specified distance of fire hydrant. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave any vehicle unattended within fifteen (15) feet of any fire plug; provided, this section shall not apply to vehicles belonging to the fire department of the city or any other authorized vehicles. 
(Code 1956, § 26-91) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 32:143, A(4), (10). 
Sec. 25-106. - Fire lanes, etc., on private property-Definitions. 
    The following terms and their derivations shall have the respective meanings given herein: 
    Fire lane: An unobstructed lane to be used as access for fire-fighting and emergency vehicles or equipment. 
    Fire protection device: Any sprinkler and standpipe fire department connection, fire hose, cabinet or shed, fire extinguisher, or any other device so marked and designed for fire protection or fire department use. 
(Code 1956, § 11-9; Ord. No. 157-1981, § 1, 9-15-81) 
Sec. 25-107. - Same-Establishment of fire lanes on private property, devoted to public use. 
    Fire lanes on private property, devoted to public use, as authorized by the fire prevention code herein adopted, are hereby established as those areas designated by the fire department fire prevention bureau of the City of Alexandria, including but not limited to the driveways, parking areas, entrances, exits, and loading zones of any shopping center, mall, bowling alley, theater, hospital, church, apartment complex, institution, or any other location deemed necessary by the said fire prevention bureau of the City of Alexandria for the protection of life and property from fire or explosion. 
(Code 1956, § 11-9.1; Ord. No. 157-1981, § 1, 9-15-81) 
Sec. 25-108. - Same-Designation of areas by property owner. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner/or manager of the property to pay for and provide fire lanes in accordance with the National Fire Protection Association's Fire Prevention Code except as amended. Letters shall be a minimum of four (4) inches in height and white or yellow in color. Stripes shall be a minimum of four (4) inches wide and red in color as approved by the fire prevention bureau. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner and operator to see that the fire lanes of the areas designated is maintained according to bureau requirements for visibility, and its signs are replaced when necessary. 
(Code 1956, § 11-9.5; Ord. No. 157-1981, § 1, 9-15-81; Ord. No. 207-2000, §§ I, II, 10-17-2000) 
Sec. 25-109. - Same-Obstructions. 
    The parking, standing, or placing of any cars, trucks, trailers, apparatus, vehicles, portable buildings, or any item deemed as an obstruction by the fire prevention bureau which obstructs the fire lanes, fire hydrants, or fire protection devices on private property shall be prohibited at all times to preserve the health, welfare and safety of the general public. 
(Code 1956, § 11-9.2; Ord. No. 157-1981, § 1, 9-15-81) 
Cross reference- Prohibition of, and fine for, parking therein, § 25-119. 
State Law reference- Obstructing firemen, R.S. 14:327. 
Sec. 25-110. - Reserved. 
Sec. 25-111. - Same-Violation. 
    The owner of any vehicle or property found to be obstructing a fire lane, fire hydrant, or fire protection device shall be subject to a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), imprisonment not to exceed thirty (30) days or both. Each day's violation of the provisions hereof shall be deemed a separate offense. 
    Any car, truck, trailer, vehicle or portable building found parked, standing or placed in a designated fire lane, or area shall be towed away and impounded by any police officer, fire inspector, or authorized representative. The owner of said car, truck, trailer, vehicle or portable building shall be responsible for all costs of impounding and storage of said property. Upon the payment of such costs, the owner shall be entitled to have said property released. 
(Code 1956, § 11-9.3; Ord. No. 157-1981, § 1, 9-15-81) 
Sec. 25-112. - Same-Utilization of fire lanes by property owner. 
(a)  The owner or proprietor of any business establishment is authorized to utilize the area immediately adjacent to his loading dock or service entrance for the purpose of loading and unloading delivery trucks, service vehicles or other vehicles used in connection with the operation of his business. 
(b)  The owner or proprietor of any business establishment is authorized to utilize the area adjacent to an entrance to load or unload customer vehicles where heavy or bulky merchandise must be handled. However, in all cases the driver of a customer vehicle must attend the vehicle while the merchandise is being loaded or unloaded and such loading and unloading area must be designated and marked as such. 
(c)  The above service vehicles, trucks, customer vehicles, etc., shall be moved from such area when loaded and/or unloaded. 
(Code 1956, § 11-9.4) 
Sec. 25-113. - Obstructing driveways; leaving on lots-Parking in front of driveways. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver or operator of any vehicle to park same in front of a driveway or any part thereof whether same serves a residence or place of business. 
(Code 1956, § 26-92) 
Sec. 25-114. - Same-Parking in or obstructing; leaving vehicle on private lot without invitation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to park or leave a vehicle in any private driveway or to obstruct in any manner the free entrance to and use of such driveway by the owner or occupant of the premises or those authorized, invited or permitted to make use thereof. 
(b)  It shall likewise be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle and leave same unattended on any private lot or parking place except at the invitation of or permission of the owner, occupant or lessee of such property. 
(Code 1956, § 26-94) 
Sec. 25-115. - Parking within certain distance of corners prohibited; exception; corner defined. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle within a distance of ten (10) feet of the corner of any street, such corner being defined as the point where the curblines of crossing streets intersect each other, provided that trucks may park in the zones marked for that purpose. 
(Code 1956, § 26-93) 
State Law reference- See R.S. 32:143, A(15). 
Sec. 25-116. - Parking of disabled vehicles on public property. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any disabled vehicle to park, or suffer, permit or allow said vehicle to be parked for a longer period of time than twenty-four (24) hours on any of the streets, alleys, sidewalks or public property of the city. 
(Code 1956, § 26-93.1) 
Cross reference- Storing on streets, §§ 22-12, 22-13. 
Sec. 25-117. - Parking in areas reserved for pedestrian use. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle in or on spaces or areas normally reserved for pedestrian traffic and use. 
(Code 1956, § 26-95) 
State Law reference- Parking on crosswalk, R.S. 32:143, A(5). 
Sec. 25-118. - Parking which-creates hazard for other vehicles or pedestrians. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park vehicle in a manner that shall provide a hazard to other vehicular or pedestrian traffic. 
(Code 1956, § 26-96) 
Sec. 25-119. - Parking on city-owned property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, except those specifically authorized, to park a motor vehicle on city-owned public property in a parking space reserved for city use. 
(Ord. No. 145-2004, § II, 5-11-2004) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 157-1981, § 1, adopted Sept. 15, 1981, amended the Code by repealing § 25-119 which had pertained to parking in fire lanes as derived from the 1956 Code, § 26-99. 
Sec. 25-120. - Overparking in two hour zone. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park motor vehicle on the streets for any time in excess of two (2) hours in any area or street of the city where two (2) hour free parking is allowed. 
(Code 1956, § 26-98) 
Sec. 25-121. - Parking limits in residential zones. 
(a)  Twenty-four hour limit established. Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) hereof, it shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle for a longer period of time than twenty-four (24) hours on any of the streets within the residential section of the city known as "SF-1, SF-2, SF-3, MF-1, MF-2, and MF-2" Residential and according to the designation of same in Chapter 28, Zoning. 
(b)  Exception for designated vehicles. The above restriction does not apply to any privately owned and operated passenger automobile which belongs to the owner or occupant of the premises abutting upon that portion of the street where such vehicle is parked nor to any such vehicle which is so parked by a guest or visitor of the owner or occupant of the premises, or which is so parked with the latter's knowledge and consent. 
(c)  Exception for persons attending public gatherings. This shall not be enforced against parking of vehicles in the residential area by those attending athletic contests, mass meetings or other gatherings to which the public in general is admitted, and on such occasions parking of vehicles shall be allowed while such activities are in progress. 
(d)  [ Commercial vehicles]. It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave standing any commercial vehicle in excess of one (1) ton, including school buses, on a public street or public easement in an area zoned for single-family residential use. This prohibition shall not apply to any commercial vehicle which is being loaded or unloaded in the normal course of business. 
(Code 1956, § 26-88; Ord. No. 91-1994, § 2, 4-26-94; Ord. No. 215-1995, §§ 1, 2, 9-26-95; Ord. No. 133-2009, § II, 5-19-2009) 
Sec. 25-122. - Penalty for violation of division. 
    Except as otherwise provided herein, any person violating any of the provisions of this division shall be fined twenty-five dollars ($25.00), and shall increase to fifty dollars ($50.00) if not paid within thirty (30) days of issuance. In default of payment of the fine, violator shall be imprisoned for two (2) days or both at the discretion of the court. 
(1)  On a second conviction, the offender shall be fined seventy-five dollars ($75.00), and in default, shall be imprisoned for up to three (3) days or both at the discretion of the court. 
(2)  On a third conviction, the offender shall be fined up to three hundred dollars ($300.00), not less than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00), and imprisoned for up to five (5) days or both at the discretion of the court. 
(3)  On a fourth conviction, the offender shall be fined five hundred dollars ($500.00), but not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00), and imprisoned up to ten (10) days in default or both at the discretion of the court. 
(4)  If, at anytime, an officer deems that a vehicle has been left unattended for over the parking limit posted, or deems that the vehicle is in violation of any code or ordinance, then at his/her discretion, can order the vehicle be towed at the owner's expense. 
(Code 1956, § 26-97; Ord. No. 21-1978, § 1, 2-7-78; Ord. No. 338-2004, § I, 10-12-2004) 
State Law reference- Authority, R.S. 32:473. 
Sec. 25-123. - Handicapped parking on private property devoted to public use.
